column10: F U M

ever seen a small animal, such as a crow, fox, or cat, investigate something with extreme amounts of caution? y'know, like a stray cat carefully going up to some dry food and backing off a bunch from the sound it makes from some of it coming down to fill in the space, or a magpie inspecting a wrapper dropped on the ground? rainworld gets you in [i]that[/i] headspace.
the thing is, though, that why animals tend to be like that, is because as far as they know, everything could be deadly. and guess what? in rainworld, it's like this too. and you'll enjoy it, because even though you're pretty weak, you'll figure out stuff on your own and learn how to live (mostly through trial and error).

[h1]A beautiful and unforgiving world that wishes to consume you whole (and pelt you to death with literal RAIN!)[/h1]
[h2]You truly feel alone in your journeys, and can die in the blink of an eye, as this game made me paranoid as hell (and schizophrenic.) [b]YOU WILL die, YOU WILL get lost, and last, you will probably feel like SISYPHUS at some point...[/b][/h2] [h3](and finally say f**k it then pick up a guide) [Don't feel ashamed doing that in a game like this, [b]trust me...[/b]] [/h3]
[u]The game does support remote multiplayer campaign/arena using steam's REMOTE PLAY, (JOLLY CO-OP mod in steam workshop, also automatically installed when you get the DLC) [/u]

It's said that the DLC will modify the base campaigns, changing/adding to the map layout and a few other things, as well as Easter eggs and possible endings, so do your own research and decide for yourself if you want to buy the DLC and/or enable it on your VANILLA CAMPAIGN playthroughs. (Monk, Survivor, and Hunter)
[h3][u]I do however, recommend that you buy it if you do enjoy the base game and are willing to dedicate yourself and your time, as the vanilla campaigns already demand alot of it.[/u][/h3]

Rainworld is a beautiful experience. The atmosphere whilst navigating the run-down, desolate landscape is truly unique and the intermittent ambient soundtrack adds to it all.

The gameplay is amazing, with so many hidden options and ways to experiment. The combat feels fluid is much the same - there's so much you can do with it *I'm just not skilled enough to do it*

On my first clear of the game I met all the echoes and ascended by sheer coincidence of where I chose to go, however I'd missed the majority of the game by doing so. I'd missed so many regions. This game is HUGE and the incredible DLC completely adds to that with the new campaigns and expedition game mode

When I first started Rain World, I struggled... A LOT. There is a massive learning curve and can be very frustrating at times. I can not express how much it is worth it to stick it through, though. This game is unlike any other game I've ever played. The A.I. in this game is spectacular, the art is beautiful, the lore is awesome, and the movement is simple, yet so complex at the same time. There are 7 actions, but there is tons of complex movement if you really get into it! The more I played this game, the more I grew to appreciate and enjoy it.

Rain World is one of the best games I've ever played, and I am so glad to have stumbled across it.

A game with the highest highs and the lowest lows. During the best of times you will feel pure wonder at the world around you. at the history of this game and at your relative insignificance in the grand scheme of things, and during the worst of times you will be painfully reminded of this insignificance as you navigate hostile environments with enemies at every corner, where progression can feel like it results from pure dumb luck. Rain World's best and worst moments go hand in hand, as without overwhelming adversity Rain World's best moments would lack meaning. [spoiler] Rain World constantly reminds you that this world does not revolve around you, as the die was cast and the point of no return crossed long before you come around. The beauty of this game lies in what little you can do and what small ripples you can make in this stagnant pool of a world that will make it a slightly better place before the inevitable. [/spoiler] Rain World is a game that you will either love or hate, but I believe you should attempt to make the journey regardless. Also Downpour DLC adds a staggering amount of content to the game so if you find the amount of content slightly underwhelming after the first playthrough I strongly advise you try it out.
It's fun to experience the future. I love the great detail, from radioactive lizards to ruined architecture- it really makes me feel at home.

While I have a lot to praise for this game's environmental and direct storytelling, and its art direction, unique mechanics, and fascinating (albeit sparse) characters, I have a lot to complain about too, and that's why this review is so hard to write. 

I played this game for 120 hours before I was able to barf up this review. Yet again, I wish steam had a neutral review option. Will you like this game? I genuinely don't know. 
 
To summarize, Rain World is a game you will (probably) hate while you play, but love in hindsight. Rain World is the dark chocolate of games. Either you think it's bitter and gross, or you admire it for some unique sensation, through a deep understanding of an abstract concept that may or may not tangibly exist. 

And to get into detail...

First, Rain World is hard. Like really hard. You'd have more fun playing dark souls drunk than this game. This game will throw bullsh*t at you and laugh while it watches you die, and then mock you for fun when you respawn in your shelter for the 400th time. For any casual player, the gameplay of Rain World is abysmal. You will not like it, and I genuinely do not suggest you get it if you aren't willing to dedicate hours upon hours to this game with little progress. While this helplessness is arguably a core component of the player being just another middle-of-the-food-chain animal in their broken ecosystem, it's not fun for the average Joe, and this is a fact that any seasoned player should reasonably agree with.

Secondly, if you like a narrative that leads you on, you don't get that either. I praise the story later in this review, but if you are coming into this looking for a story to be told, you won't actually get one. You have to [i]find[/i] the story on your own by just happening along the right path - a path which tries especially hard to make you turn back with its absurd difficulty, and which the game provides no indication towards whatsoever. For some campaigns, the circumstances you have to satisfy to get the full and complete story are so specific that any other game would reserve those steps for an easter egg or secret bonus. In Rain World, that's just how the world works, that is the norm. You'd better have damn good intuition if you wanna get this done fully.

So onto the positive.

Rain world is (or at least, feels like) a technical marvel; it is the dream every aspiring new dev hopes to achieve, complexity made from simple and elegant parts. The amount of image based graphics in this game for characters is tiny, with most objects being composed out of primitive, rigid parts and shapes. The AI follow a simple set of archaic rules much like a simple animal in the real world would. It's hard to describe this game's artstyle and presentation. If you were around on the internet and did gaming in the early 2000s, do you remember when a popular artstyle of game menus or flash animations/art were made out of really cool mechanisms and machines? Rain World is just the embodiment of that artstyle as a professionally designed game. If you like micro-mechanisms dotting every part of the world, this [i]is[/i] that vibe. If you like abandoned infrastructure, this game is that vibe.

The storyline of Rain World is also super enticing, unlike any other I have seen in a game. The world is abandoned, but not for some mysterious reason. The reason is very well known, well documented, and very directly intentional. There is no mystery to why the world is as it is, yet somehow, there is something presented in this story much more interesting than any "the world was abandoned" mystery could ever hope to achieve. The story of this game is by far one of my favorites of all time, and for good reason. The way certain characters are depicted, the way they are developed, the way their motives are so unique and flavorful. I can't help but to empathize with each in their on distinct, special way. This game tells a wonderful story of a fascinating tragedy that you will never forget. ...If you can find it.

All around, I don't know what to think of this game. I like it. I like it enough to have contributed significantly to its modding community (even to the point of having my mod code recognized officially). But it's just so hostile to new players that I don't know if I would recommend it to someone looking to play. It's more of an "eh". By all means, try it if you are feeling up to it, you could like it a lot. But go in expecting a bit of a shock of bitter taste that you may or may not get used to.

Through and through I will ultimately give this game a +1, on a 51% yes to 49% no type ratio though. It's a hard decision to make.

This game is really good in many respects. The aesthetic is phenomenal. You play as a slugcat, a fantastical species of small but smart predators who try to survive in a world that is constantly getting flooded, hence the name of the game. However, you are just a small fish in an ocean of vastly scarier creatures, most of them predatory. To that end, you need to orient yourself in a foreign ecosystem and survive whatever creatures live in the graveyard of a civilisation that used to rule the world. The screenshots speak for themselves, and is more or less what it says on the tin.

Why am I not recommending this game? There are a few issues, but I will address the biggest one first. The game is by design minimalistic and is intended to be enjoyed with minimum amount of prior information about how the game works or what it contains. This is actually the main reason why I decided to try this game. Exploring an ecosystem of an alien world with minimal guidance on what you are doing is, on its face, a genius video game concept.

There is a major issue that sets back the gameplay, though, and that is the issue of lives. Now, everyone who has played the game and is experienced in it will probably scratch their head. "Lives? There are no lives in the game, what are you talking about?" I will get to that in a moment.

The game is gruellingly difficult, which is fair, but if you have lives to contend with, this makes the game largely not fun to play. Whenever you die and you have not eaten a sufficient amount of food, you will lose a life. You will replenish a life if you eat a sufficient amount of food and go back to a safehouse to hibernate for the cycle (when the world floods). Cycles are very short. You have to go out of your safehouse, avoid dangerous predators who are plentiful, eat food, and then try to explore the next section of the world in search of a new safehouse that gets you closer towards whatever gets you out of the hellhole. This is annoying and obnoxious, and a few hours into the game I just called it quits as I was getting cornered in the same few spots over and over again, trying to conserve my lives.

Now, as I made clear, this is not actually how the game works. The game is minimalistic, and the very minimal tutorial at the beginning of the game does not explain that the karma system, which is what I described, is not actually a lives system. This very prominently-shown feature that flashes in your face at full screen whenever you die or hibernate is, in fact... for opening doors. That's it. It serves no other purpose. I found this out only when looking up the wiki.

Why did I think this is how it worked? There's every reason to think this:
[list]
    [*] The game is very difficult. It is tagged on Steam as "Difficult." One of the characters that you can play as in the game will permanently die if he dies even once.
    [*] Slugcats hibernate. What happens if a creature hibernates without sufficient food? They starve to death. This is a game of survival. The game is tagged as "Survival" on Steam.
    [*] It is extremely prominently featured whenever you die, and looks ominous.
[/list]

It would be both illogical and irrational to assume that if the counter goes to zero and you die, you don't permanently die. Yet it turns out that it is a completely minor feature that has zero impact until you hit a door, which requires you to have a certain amount of karma to open. I already knew it opened doors, but I assumed it was one of many secondary functions of this supposed lives system.

I was punished by the game for coming to a perfectly logical and rational conclusion, making my own experience with the game significantly worse. Once I realised this by looking up information on the wiki, I had zero desire to ever play the game again. This type of minimalistic game only makes sense if you don't trick your players for following common sense. This is why I don't recommend the game. If I knew the karma system was not a lives system, I would have just played the game the way you are supposed to: die a lot and experiment.

Other issues, although they weren't a complete dealbreaker for me, pertain to controls. The game uses, if you will, an alien control scheme that is unlike any other platformer. It is very clunky. I would have preferred if crouching was just a toggle like in other games, but instead it's the very finger-twisting up and down movement keys that toggle it. Never understood what the point of it was. Sometimes grabbing onto ledges and other parkour actions do not work as expected. I kind of started to get a feel for it before I quit playing, but it never felt right.

Lastly, the predator variety is kind of middling as soon as you finish the first section of the game, although I guess if I wasn't tricked into playing cautiously and embraced an aggressive approach, I would have gone through the world sections significantly faster. Still, there's a lot of predatory lizards and not enough of other creatures.

All in all, impressive game, but I do not like being tricked into playing the game wrong for applying sound reasoning and logic.

[strike]I will never achieve stabbing down while doing a back flip[/strike]. 10/10
Never mind. I finally did it and I feel amazing.

In all seriousness though. This is not a game about progressing and becoming stronger. This game is brutal.
You are at the bottom of the food chain. The only thing lower than you are small bugs and mice. And it stays that way the whole game. Even as it gets harder and harder you stay the same. Instead you have to use knowledge through experimentation, success or failure and cunning and luck.
You can kill things higher up the food chain with these things. Or go through a pipe straight into open jaws because this game can be as fair as life itself. So patience is also a good thing to have playing this. Try to experience it and it's ecosystem, learn the feel of movement (because it is unusual and complex), not rush to reach the end. It's a survival game, not a beat each level game.
And I love it. Such a breath of fresh air. Really unique. But even in saying that. It's not for everyone.

Added note: This game does seem to crash here and there. But that seems like an issue across all platforms.

this game is like nothing you've ever played before but it WILL kick your ass in a way that celeste, hollow knight, and dark souls never could. very strong gameplay loop, gorgeous style, incredibly rich atmosphere, surprisingly deep lore. game's biggest flaw is readability, but the remix options does a lot to address these issues, and if you find yourself struggling, there are some well thought-out accessibility features as well. highly recommend, but with the caveat that this game very well might not be for you. still, worth a shot -- or two, or three. this game has a reputation for a reason.

There is no other game, to my knowledge, that does what Rain World does. There is no game that can create an environment this alien, alive, and enthralling, besides Rain World. This game will not be to everyone's liking, especially considering it will make you feel small and helpless. But the experience of learning, overcoming, and adapting to this world is so immense, that there is no reason you shouldn't at least try.

I think Rain World is a one-of-a-kind type of video game that often isn't really seen much. If I were to describe its genre I guess I'd call it a survival platformer set in a long-abandoned, sort-of sci-fi world (that's my best attempt at it anyways)? But not survival like the many survival games with crafting and stuff that exist, it's survival in the sense that you're an animal pretty low on the food chain that's just trying not to get eaten while scrounging up enough food to hibernate before the rain comes again. I don't think a specific kind of genre really fits it fully anyways, as its game play is genuinely something I don't know if I've seen before.

Admittedly, that game play is something I think will alienate a lot of people if they go into the game completely blind. You're told pretty much nothing except the basic controls for movement (and oh God can the movement get complex) and picking up and throwing objects, the game expects you to experiment a bunch to figure out how things work yourself, which while it can be fun I also know a lot of people don't really like that level of vagueness. The game also *tries* to guide players on a specific route, but I really don't think the way the game does it does a good job at that, nevermind if a player can even figure out what's trying to guide them. I have seen several instances of people not knowing where they're supposed to be going or what they're supposed to be doing, and I have seen them wander into regions they really are not prepared for, and its something that happened to me at first too. 

Despite that though, I do think Rain World is a game people should not give up on as that vagueness can offer a very special kind of gaming experience when you figure out what x item does or just generally exploring the world. The game is also just fun in my opinion even when you know what everything does, and there are additional challenges within the game and community to complete, as well as lore to discover and theorize on (trust me, the lore is vague as fuck so theories are going to need to fill the gaps where information doesn't). My advice is to buy the base game first, give yourself some time with it and see if you like it, and if you do I recommend buying Downpour as well.

I was going to originally give this game an ironic review, but I really can't. This game is singlehandedly one of the biggest love letters to immersive simulators ever (if not, THE biggest love letter).

This game is brutal-it's so goddamn unforgiving that scratching out your corneas with a hot, piercing needle would be less painful and in fact probably very pleasant. But this game is meant to be an immersive simulator, not a traditional game like most. I remember first playing this game and setting it down for months, unable to progress past Industrial Complex, but then the game started growing on me. Slowly, over months of spotted progress, I'd finally beat the game. After witnessing the ending, I knew this game was something special. There's so much beauty. Everywhere. Every single room of this game is breathtaking (besides filtration system) and the combat always keeps you on your toes. Dominating the ecosystem is something more rewarding than earning a diploma or having a family. 

Hopefully my beautiful use of yappanese is enough to explain my sheer love for this game. The game is brutal, but please, for the love of God, BUY IT. Even if you don't like it, just swallow the pill and trudge through it. The sheer gorgeousness in some rooms alone are more than worth it.

Imagine Sisyphus trying to roll the damned boulder up a hill. He keeps getting really close but the rock just rolls right back down. Now imagine that the boulder is your progress, and your - the player - are Sisyphus. 

This is a very roundabout way of pretty much saying that the game is  i n c r e d i b l y  d i f f i c u l t. 

It does however have a lot going for it, the main feature being its ecosystem simulation which creates very interesting gameplay that can vary greatly from attempt to attempt. The game also has a very in depth movement system and a highly exploration based gameplay loop.

The learning curve on the game is very steep as only the most basic of mechanics are taught to you and the rest are expected to be learned through tooltips or just through your own experimentation. 

The story of the game is excellent however it takes a while to understand it and find out the full lore of the game. 


Overall the game is best suited for those that can deal with a challenge and enjoy highly exploration based gameplay.

Incredibly difficult, borderline unfair at times, but somehow still one of the best games I have ever had the pleasure to play. The story is amazing (especially if you take the DLC into account) and the lore is super interesting. The artstyle is beautiful and breathtaking. Gameplay is probably the thing that will put most people off. Sometimes it feels like the character doesn't do what you tell it to do, and the amount of times I have died over and over again because some creature decided to camp outside the place I need to go, or because the AI had some other type of brainfart is astounding. But somehow, as a whole, it still works. You play as a slugcat, a creature who in the grand scheme of things isn't that important. You are equally as important as the lizards that try to eat you, and as the batflies that you swallow. You are a creature with limited ablities, in a dare I say objectivly unfair environment. The best way I can describe this game is as a simulated ecosystem, and it is cruel, and unforgiving, and frustrating. But it feels so incredibly satisfying to conquer and survive, and to learn how to best navigate the environments you are faced with. The game is definitely not for everyone, but I still have to give it a 10/10

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Started playing Rain World back when it released in 2017 and it sure is a game.

Survival is simple; get food, sleep, don't die in the process. But the combat and movement of Rain World is deep and complex, having countless numbers of tech and nuance to it. Not all of it is told to you directly, but it is taught through experimentation with your surroundings and during moments of strife(or the 100+ page movement guide lol). The world is vast and complex, having many branching paths and connections, as well as many places to get lost. Combine this with its strange wildlife and you got the equivalent of an interactive alien ant farm. Every prominent area has unique identifying geometry and creatures, ensuring that exploration never gets old. The soundtrack is inviting and serves as an important game mechanic at times, adding to the intensity of encounters with layering and the mystique of discovering new areas. Progression is abnormal, as there is little to no permanent upgrades. This is a game with a heavy focus on skill and self-improvement as opposed to the average metroidvania that gradually makes you a demigod. The more you play this game, the better you will become.

The free Remix update also adds an abundance of toggle-able quality-of-life changes(visibility, hud settings, difficulty) to tailor your playthrough to your liking. Improvements such as uncapped framerates and fixes to common crashes add even more polish to this already slick game. [b]They even added helpful tutorial messages during gameplay with visuals to help relay useful hints. Rain World is an amazing game, don't get me wrong. It has beautiful art, amazing AI, and leaves a lot of questions about what this world really is. Despite this, I have noticed one very fatal flaw in this game. I'm a skill issue. I mean, it can pretty much be summarized that way. You can die in a LOT of B.S ways in this game, and by that, I don't mean to say "oh I'm just bad". See, you're pretty much living in an ecosystem. You're near the bottom of the food chain and you gotta survive. Wanna know something funny about nature? it's unfair. It's dangerous, and not something you can play around in. In that sense, this game is AMAZING at resembling an actual ecosystem, but it also leads to a *lot* of frustrating deaths that you couldn't really do much about. You require a lot of luck in this game, probably more so then you do actual skill. You can be the best player, but with bad enough luck, you could die. You could be really bad at avoiding the enemies and surviving, but with enough good luck, you don't even come close to death. Again, call me a skill issue, because that's fair enough, but this game has an incredibly high skill ceiling, and if you're not starting off skilled at games, you will probably have a very frustrating time throughout many parts of this game. Though, it's worth mentioning I came into this game with an idea that doesn't fit what the game actually is, and while the product I received didn't make me hate the game, I can't say just yet if it was worth the purchase. I compare the games difficulty to getting over it, personally. (For background knowledge, I have played that game as well)

[b] [i] TL;DR: Not for everyone. A lot of the fun is in discovering how the creatures act in a breathing, functioning, autonomous ecosystem, not in the survival itself. [/i] [/b]


Let me preface this by saying this game is not for everyone. It's for a niche. If you are not a part of that niche, this game is disappointing. If you are a part of it, this is a very unique masterpiece of a game.

The gameplay is relatively straightforward. You wake up, eat food, try not to become food, find shelter, sleep, repeat. This sounds boring, but it isn't. If you don't know how to progress, just pull up the map and you can see where you haven't been yet, and go there. That's basically it. That's the gameplay. Repeat that until you find the end and you're done. There are no bossfights, no quests, no upgrades, nothing. That's it.

However, this game is still a masterpiece. A part of the fun of the game lies in trying to decipher all the characteristics and quirks of each and every plant and creature you see, all the while trying to stay alive.
That's the fun of the game: seeing every creature interact with the world. Every creature has predators, prey, weaknesses and abilities. There is an entire ecosystem in this game, with an entire food chain and fight-or-flight response built into every creature.

Every time you enter a room, there is a chance you get ambushed by a gang of lizards, but also a chance the entire room is devoid of life. All rooms in an area are active (creatures can move and act in them without interaction). This means you can enter a room and see a group of lizards fight one another.

Lizards for example, try to hunt you, but will fight other lizards over food and territory, but will run away when something higher up in the food chain arrives. There is even a reputation system built into these things. Even within the same species of lizards (yes, there are multiple species with different abilities and AI), there can be different personalities of lizards.

What also helps with this is the animation: nothing is rigid. Everything is fluid and dynamic, because every single animation is procedural: done by code. This really adds onto the feeling of a breathing world, but can also sometimes have some weird quirks (sometimes lizards just spin around eternally or have an epileptic attack for no reason).

All of this makes it immensely entertaining to just discover the AI of each creature. I beat the game, and have genuinely have a 101 page document with the behaviour and weaknesses I discovered of each creature I met (granted 79 of those pages are just screenshots I thought could be lore). I have spent a lot of time just lurking in a tunnel, trying to see what the new lizard does, or just see a creature hunt something you thought was higher up in the food chain.

The only thing that I despise about this game is a compliment to the developers: they managed to make me feel icky with so many creatures. The absolute horror I felt after trying to grab a pole only for it to be a mimic and suck me in, is insane. Hollow Knight deepnest is a Teletubbies episode compared to this game's ick. The animation and AI on some of these abominations is immaculately disgusting and I love it. (Take this entire paragraph with a grain of salt though, as I am not the bravest. At least 20% of the times I exited the game was because I felt too icky to touch my keyboard after having slimy amalgamations kill me)

Some people say this game is too hard, but that's not true in my opinion. Sure, you will die a lot, sometimes it will feel slightly unfair (like when a lizard dropkicks you and eats you), but every time you learn (except for the dropkicking lizard scenarios. Scenario is plural because it happened twice). The only time I thought the game was unfair was when the only way out of a room had multiple enemies, which only happened rarely.

IMO a good game, very much definitely worth the price.

This game is a work of art. It does not care about how much fun you're having, or how frustrated you are, all it cares about is fulfilling its artistic goal. This goal is to be an amazing world, filled with an incredible ecosystem, wonderful lore and stunning views - all of which it achieves.

TL;DR:
the absolute best storytelling, AI, and art. just play it trust me

Rain World is the best dying simulator in the gaming industry. you are a Slugcat in a mysterious world after being separated from your family. your lost, confused, and hungry. you look for food and then find shelter, only to be greeted by fierce predators. it is your fate weather you survive or not.

The ecosystem and AI in Rain World is the smartest AI in any game, its like a real ecosystem playing out right in front of you. predators hunting prey, prey running or hiding, then you. the creatures sometimes make mistakes. like bumping into walls, falling, or missing their attacks. thats what makes the AI feel so alive. they also fight each other over food, which is what you are. if you get caught by a predator and "die", not all hope is lost. theres a chance another hungry predator will come over and fight over you. giving you the chance to escape alive.

 The story in Rain World is very confusing yet interesting. the games way of telling you the lore is very subtle but nice. you know nothing at first but as you progress through the map, you start to see what might have happened to this dying, broken world. even i dont know even close to all the lore but after playing 3 campaigns (2 in the downpour DLC) its so cool seeing it connect and it just keeps you hooked.

The movement system is very versatile yet unimportant at times. there are COUNTLESS movement techs and tricks. sliding, flipping, rolling, etc. these 3 i just listed are in my opinion the most important tricks to know for your survival. but if you looked into it from what i know there are 80+ movement tricks. its bonkers.

THE ART is so god damn incredible, just gonna say that.

(editing a day after cause i forgot) The music, the OST, whatever you wanna call it. is indescribably good. It fits the tone of the world so perfectly, weather in danger or not, it always keeps you on your toes. if you you went on the playlist for the entire OST on youtube or something, i guarantee you would find good songs to listen to. The OST for the Downpour DLC is just as good if not better as well. im not good at explaining how good things are so just take my word for it.

so Rain World in my opinion is a must play for those who like platformer games or not. this is 100% the best platformer game out there. if you play Rain World and are stuck dying or getting lost, please dont give up and give this masterpiece a chance. its so worth it in the end and it will give you a great time if you pull through.
btw buy the Downpour DLC :)))))

game

ok this game is deserving of an edit to my review

genuinely if i had to pick a favorite game ever, slowly over the years i think rain world has eclipsed the others in my list. as much as i love terraria (and in fact, have put more hours in by over double) and risk of rain 2, and despite how I'll never love playing rain world as much as i used to, i think I'm comfortable saying its my favorite game ever. 

what i mean by "never love playing it as much as i used to" is.. well, quite simple, yet quite complicated. in basic terms, rain world is a FANTASTIC game to get yourself lost in. to suck at this game, to overcome hardships, to discover the world, the lore, and even the music... its indescribable. the fact that i'll never get to do all that over again is.. depressing, to me; which is why i don't have more hours on this game. I've found that I've gotten too good at the game, I've explored everything, done just about everything I can do.

regardless of all that, this game will always, ALWAYS have a special place in my heart, and I personally don't see anything else taking the number one spot, at least for a long time. this game truly is a masterpiece, and I always recommend it to people who love a good challenge in their games, love RICH lore and worldbuilding, and adore those silly little wawas. 

I still will continue to play rain world, and i encourage you to, as well. don't look up any guides- this game is best played without them, despite how difficult and directionless it may seem; because that's part of the experience. it's understandable to not have the time to throw yourself at a wall over and over, and i get that. my recommendation for that is to find someone who can watch your progress, and trickle down little hints to keep you going. if you're a person that likes some kind of direction in a game, i think that's the best compromise.

You're an adorable little creature in a beautiful, ancient, broken world filled with intricate lore and an entire procedurally-animated ecosystem. While dying a lot is a normal part of the experience, you can easily tweak the difficulty with lots of settings and mods.
Clunk

This is one of Those Games. Kinda like Subnautica, or Outer Wilds,  Hollow Knight, or Return of the Obra Dinn. Almost every time I've played a game like this, I get frustrated with it at the very beginning, put it down, and eventually digest what the game asks of me before returning to what will soon be one of my favorite digital experiences. It's a game that gives you very little direction, even though you know there's things to "beat," or complete. However, these objectives simply exist, regardless of whether or not you want to engage with them, with no pressure or real guidance to completing them. In fact, the main hurdle to completing them is even knowing they exist and then knowing how to even begin. Rain World is probably the most egregiously one of Those Games than any other.

Nearly every "objective" is a brutal survival challenge filled with arbitrary skill tests and sudden road blocks and the only reward is understanding more of the world, and even just barely that. You are being led on a wild goose chase from the get-go, which you can try to follow or quickly abandon because you couldn't figure out how to get past that platforming room, or you got scared by a vulture or lizard forcing you to take a detour that leads you to entirely new areas to get lost in. You will get lost a lot. Even when you do figure something out, you might mess up and do something that angers powers out of your league that either requires a restart (although you will always keep your map between game files) or extensive procedures only vaguely hinted at to recoup. The game does not make itself trust worthy and you may very well decide to ignore the directions it sends you in, and you will still stumble upon what you need to do to complete the game eventually if you keep wandering.

Because the point of the game is to get lost. There is no other real objective. Sure, there are things you can do that will help you learn the world, but like almost all of Those Games, there is no reward but knowledge that may help you find even more understanding. However, at the end of the day, you're just a slugcat. A random creature in a world built around adaptation to unfortunate and ill-fitting circumstances. If you just want to beat games, and want to do so efficiently from the start in order to get on to the next game, Rain World is probably not for you. Funnily enough, if you are good at the game and know exactly where you are going, you could probably beat it in 5-7 hours, give or take some moments of getting stuck, but if you play the game blind, it would probably take you 15-30 hours to get to your first ending depending on how much you like to explore and learn about the world.

Unfortunately, this all hinges on a reward that no one can really tell you anything about outside of "it's cool." The only thing I or anyone can say about what makes this game great is "trust me on this" without spoiling what makes the game great. My only advice is to lean into the atmosphere of the game as much as possible: get into the headspace of being a tiny but intelligent little nimble rodent in a huge, hostile world. That and try to follow the little yellow guide when it shows you little flashbacks if you want to move towards the ending. Lastly, it's okay to put the game down and pick it back up again. If you need a second to wonder about it, to be frustrated with it, to be deeply confused, take a second and digest. The entirety of Rain World will sit there, indifferent. Try to return to it, however, because gosh what a world that is!

[h1]Rating[/h1]
8/10 (A-tier)
A brutal yet super unique and interesting experience.

[h1]Details[/h1]
[list]
[*]A large world inhabited by many creatures with unique behaviors. They also interact with each other (even when you're not close-by) instead of only caring about you. It creates the impression of a real ecosystem which you're simply a tiny part of
[*]The creatures and environments are very interesting and creative. Their AI is also mostly very good
[*]Besides an initial cutscene and a short introduction to the controls / basic mechanics you don't get much information. Rain World is mostly about exploring and figuring things out on your own
[*]The game is very unforgiving and it can be frustrating when you die repeatedly trying to get out of a dangerous area. However, it feels somewhat nice how the game doesn't pull any punches. Your life in this game is just as expendable as that of all the other creatures. It feels raw and brutal in a good way. And while dying sucks it also doesn't really have any drastic or permanent consequences
[*]The achievements provide neat side goals. A whole bunch of them even grant you ingame benefits
[*]Having to constantly escape the rain and avoid the numerous dangers of the game's world keeps you on your toes most of the time. When there's nothing going on the game can actually be quite calming though
[*]The sound design and music is good. While it's pretty quiet most of the time I think that fits the game well
[*]The controls feel a bit clunky and are unintuitive at first but there are actually many advanced tricks at your disposal. Once you get familiar with the game the movement can be very satisfying (except when you want to grab an item but the game keeps making you grab the corpse next to it instead...)
[*]The interactions with "enemies" are quite fun. Every encounter is a question of: What will it do and how should I proceed? Dodge, escape, fight or sneak around? You have to make quick decisions based on the room layout, available tools and the creature AI. It's gonna take a lot of deaths to get good at this though, especially because the AI is rather hard to predict. But at the same time that's also what keeps it interesting
[*]I like the graphics a lot but I was bewildered by the strangely limited resolution options in the settings. Luckily there is a mod called "Sharpener" you can install that lets you upscale the game. It also allows you to play in borderless windowed mode!
[*]Funky lore that is not thrown at your face
[*]There is a decently-sized modding community making very cool stuff
[*]The DLC is very good, lifting the game up to a 9/10 for me
[/list]

I'll be real with you - it will crush you, destroy you at every given moment. Wildlife is unforgiving (platforming too) and you'll die again and again and again. You will be frustrated, lost, you will not know what the hell you are supposed to do.

And yet this is the most unique and memorable experiences, hands down.
It's fine if you find the game difficult and unfair, but do try to see it as a passion project, where you are supposed to be a little part of the ecosystem and not a big hero of the day.

(DLC is strongly recommended. It made the game 3 times bigger!!! Maybe even more if you include challenges and expeditions.)

This is one of the most unique games i have ever played in my life. Its firmly cemented itself as my all time favorite indie game, and just one of my favorite games in general. The story is extremely interesting and leaves so much room for you to fill in the blanks with headcanon and sh*t. The visuals are f*cking breathtaking, the soundtrack goes perfectly with every single part of this game, the movement is amazing even disregarding all the movement tech you can do. If this game interests you even slightly, I urge you to pick it up and at least play through one campaign. If you do pick it up, do pick up the Downpour dlc as the game is almost incomplete without it. It give so much more to the lore and story of RainWorld. Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going to continue endlessly hyperfixating on this game.

This game is a grind. It's tutorial doesn't tell you absolutely everything about the game, most of the ecosystem wants you dead and all you can do is run, hide, or fight back with a glorified toothpick.
You see unfathomable horrors, crawl through pipes, and encounter giant birds that very few creatures will even stick around to encounter.

It's brutally difficult at first, and a lot of people claim it's a failure sim. 

The biggest difference (from someone who hasn't even beaten the game yet) is all the small details in this game.
There's a ton of video essays and lore dumps in the wiki that tell you how complex the ecosystem is, and you can tell just by playing this game for a few hours. The world feels alive, exploration is heavily encouraged, and learning is just another death away.

I can't recommend this game enough for anyone who has the spare 20$ to spend on a game they're interested in.

Don't spoil it for yourself, enjoy the game as slowly and easily as you prefer. I may have a relatively short playtime with this game, but it's a blast to play, whether I'm surviving for a long time or dying every few minutes, I'm always learning something new and getting better with the game. Lots of things to discover, like creature behaviours, item interaction and even a reputation system (with more than just the enemies). Try it out if you get the chance, maybe watch a spoiler free video. It's worth a chance.

This game makes me want to commit die in the best way possible. I'll start off by saying the usual to people who want to check out Rainworld. Don't buy this game if you think you're here to be a hero, you're just a part of the ecosystem and honestly pretty low on the food chain. While yes you can figure out ways to climb the ranks of prey to predator, every creature has the capability of taking you down in one move. Now, after saying all that, I personally would say this is a solid game to play if you want something truly new. The world, the environments, the story and the characters are all such high quality, I enjoyed exploring the areas and then watching videos to go into more details on how and why things happen throughout the timeline. This isn't really a normal game, as much as it's just an experience to play through and not enjoy, but understand. Also slugcat can do a backflip so that's just about enough evidence as you need to buy it.

If you love putting yourself through hell this is the game for you, it is HARD, but addicting. Dying is apart of this game, but it can stop your progress for so long at times. It doesn't seem to have a over arching goal till later down the line in gameplay, which I personally enjoy but I know others may not! There is so much I could say about this game, and I think alot of it would sound insulting but I truly do adore this game, there is nothing quite like rain worlding.

There is nothing like the feeling of getting good at this game, it is wonderfully well made and if you're willing to put in the time and enjoy platforming and survival games this is the game for you! If you dislike grinding, failing ALOT, quote on quote "gitting gud" as I saw someone put it, or being set back on progress enough where it just ruins the game for you, this is not the game for you. But overall I enjoy it even if playing it at times feels like walking on hot coals, and would totally recommend it if you like games along the lines of rainworld!

This game is a perfect recreation of a living breathing world, indifferent to life and merciless in nature it will not care for you nor for the creatures it harbors. If you take upon yourself the challenge of not being at the top of the food chain then you must steel yourself and be ready to be torn to shreds by even the smallest of mistakes.
 As you play you might utter "This is hard" or more commonly "This is unfair" and you are correct, life is not easy, life is not fair, you may encounter obstacles along the way. A creature stands in the way of your objective? Either find another route or fight on through, You are starving and don't have food? Venture out into the unknown hoping to find sustenance or die trying.
 As I have stated, this world is indifferent to your existance, much like ours, you must learn how to live in such a hostile enviroment on your own. Maybe you'll make friends along the way trying to survive the same hostile enviroment you find yourself in. But, eventually, you'll master your movement abilities and use wit and caution as your greatest assets, becoming part of this world's ecosystem and unraveling the mysteries of its past. After all, how much longer can this world bear the weight of so many past lifes?

This game will kill you by falling, getting stabbed, eaten, mauled, drowned, electrocuted, exploded, being frozen,  trampled, dissolved, torn apart, and by the rain. Yet, this game is a masterpiece with a beautiful ecosystem and movement. Get this game it is 100% worth the price.

It's an interesting game idea, but it fails to be fun.

Exploring the world is somewhat interesting. There is a bit of architecture, some gates that require you to be there on a specific day. Seeing the interactions of the other life forms makes the place feel (creepily) alive. But that's all there seems to be to it. 

Because the world is so opaque, there is a little helper-hologram(?) to show you along, giving you at least some hint on what to do next. If you need something like that in a game - man, it's way to unclear what you are supposed to do!

If you evade the predators, you can have a nice sleep and do the same exploring again. Or get eaten or get washed away in the rain... ... and do the exploring again.

I don't feel like this game is "too hard". Difficulty is a measure of how much you struggle between where you are and where you want to be. And in this game, I have no idea where I want to be. There could be no predators walking about and I would still struggle to see the point in going anywhere.

Rainworld: "We purposefully designed the camera to not move with your character as an artistic choice."

The most popular and most subscribed mod of the game: "Yeah, so this mod makes the camera move with you and nothing else."

Sometimes you just gotta admit you made a dumb decision.

Technical issues hurt what is otherwise a great game.

In the space of a couple hours I experienced:

Bugged enemy movement blocking only path
Bugged map not showing scouted tunnel
Input non-reg on long jump
Ambiguous environment, foreground vs slightly faded background platform
Platforming where the camera cuts between jumps

Honestly makes for a pretty annoying experience when it feels like you're fighting the controls and design choices, rather than the actual game mechanics

Rain World is a game where you [u][i]become[/i][/u] a slugcat in a very realistic world that acts on its own and will react to your actions, with animals fleeing and chasing you, but also potentially fighting each other. Everyone is struggling for their own survival and you are just one of many. The world will also hint at a story but I do not know the ending to it. 

Pretty good game, but punishing if you do not run and hide well enough. No real combat is available other than catching and eating small things like bats, leading enemies away and potentially to death, and your ability to throw some things like rebar and rocks which deal some damage (no health bars though).

Good luck if you play!, you will need it.

There's no game quite like this. This is one of those games you can play for many hours before realizing it has a very in depth Mario64-like movement system that is incredibly satisfying and rewarding to master. Seriously, if you compare how you play Rain World in its opening hours versus how you play it 40+ hours in, it can be night and day. The only difference is in the players knowledge of all the many intricacies that the game hides from you. 

Exploration, discovery, failure, frustration, accomplishment, and satisfaction is how I would describe Rain World.

starting this with a disclaimer that if you don't like games with a sharp learning curve and the possibility of failure, this probably won't be a good game for you.

but yeah anyways this game blew me away once i figured out what i was doing. it's often given as an example of an ecosystem simulator, and while i don't know that it's quite that, you do certainly feel like a prey animal. so many things are hazardous, the world is vast, and you feel disempowered in a way that makes achieving anything (a passage, progress in an area, killing a dangerous enemy, etc) feel very rewarding. the world itself is beautiful, and every area has its own neat risk/reward feedback loop. except shaded citadel. fuck shaded citadel. also the ending and another moment in the middle of the game gave me chills, can't remember the last time a video game did that to me even once.

there are some drawbacks though, like how hard it is to get into. it's easy to get lost, also the lore is unfortunately kinda sparse for how interesting it is and for what it has to say. the way a lot of information is disseminated (especially without playing through the dlc) is via small, easily missed items scattered across the map that have to be brought allll the way back to one room at the far end of the world, one at a time. and for reference, you get a few fast travels from gameplay that are one use each, but there are more pearls than there are passages. speaking of the game world's size, it's very easy to get lost. when following the intended route of the original three campaigns, npcs will guide you, but they can be flippant about what they guide you towards or not show up sometimes.

still a really good game. if you're curious give it a shot.

It puts you into a really dynamic environment where the player is just apart of the food chain, all the movements that can be seen look natural, and things happen off screen, it also feels like lizards are aggressive to certain things depending on the type of lizard they are. I just think this is a game that aims to keeps you on your toes with death around every corner no matter how skilled you are and just immerses you into an environment with a complex food chain and diverse areas. Its going to be challenging at the start because that's how it would be in a real natural environment, if you introduce an animal into an environment its never been in before, it's going to be confused at first, then its going to learn more things about the environment and do better. This game does a really good job at doing that but with the player.

Because of the experience I had during my playtime, I was not initially going to recommend this game. Rain World was incredibly infuriating at times. The movement feels clunky until you've put in enough hours to reach the end of the game and I feel like a lot of its mechanics are just executed so poorly that they end up working against themselves. 

All of that being said, I am so glad I played it and followed this journey to its end. The destination  [spoiler] was so inexplicably beautiful that I actually cried [/spoiler]. It helped to look at a spoiler-free story location order guide, just using area names, as a nudge towards consistent progression when things felt futile. If you're willing to put up with its faults, if you have the patience, maybe see where it takes you.

This game is extremely fun, not only because it is challenging but also because there are so many secrets to uncover. There is lore, secrets, challenges, and even ways to play as the enemies in game! And if you're too lazy to work so hard to unlock all of the lore and secrets, there are FREE cheats (Rain World Remix, already part of the game and doesn't need to be downloaded externally) that allow you to configure basic game controls, perks, settings, and even secrets! THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE! It's an incredible game, with amazing art, music, ai, and region design, but it is also really unfair at times. You will probably rage quite several times, because some lizard fuck decided that he was going to camp a pipe and ambush you, but if you have the patience to get past that this game is easily a game of the year for me.

Finished the game, I liked this more than I thought I would. In fact, I'd go as far as to say I love it. No other game has ever made me feel so satisfied. Running, jumping, dodging while surrounded on all sides and living gives me a rush like no other.

The controls, while a bit out of standard, are easy to learn quickly. And while I am still far from mastering them, once I had really learned the controls, navigating my environment became a joy and adds to that satisfaction upon finally succeeding a bit I was stuck on.

The game was also far easier than people make it out to be. I'd recommend at least trying out the game. You never know if you'll like it or not otherwise.

Absolutely stellar game!

A bit hard to get into at first, especially if you struggle with difficult games.  You will die.  A lot.  You will play the exact same section over and over and over again until you get lucky and slip past the enemies and make it to the next shelter.  This game doesn't do much to tell you where to go, it only teaches you the bare minimum for survival through the tutorial section, and then you're on your own, in a brutal unforgiving environment where everything thinks you are a tasty snack.

However! If you can tough it out, and keep going, its SO rewarding! The lore is incredibly deep, the story is fulfilling, the characters are adorable and each of their campaigns is unique and interesting.  The modding scene is starting to take off with this as well, and there are many new regions, slugcats, and more to experience, adding hours to your gameplay! It took me about 150 hours to complete all of the main campaigns before dipping my toes into mods, and I can see already that I've got a few hundred hours to go just with story mode alone, and thats not even delving into expedition mode and arena, where there are new challenges and objectives to complete.

10/10 this is hands down my top game of all time, taking the crown from Hollow Knight.

For those of you just getting into it, I have one piece of advice: follow the little eyeball dude that's always watching you, that's your guide! Beyond that, have fun! It may seem impossible at times but there's a way around everything, you just have to experiment and find out!

Amazing, simply one of the most artistically and aesthetically pleasing games I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing.  The difficulty may scare new players, however the learning curve is immensely rewarding to master and the story is well worth the struggle. At no point did the game ever feel 'unfair', though it poised a unique challenge. Every death I died felt like more of the fault of me as a player than of the game, or as consequence of the realistic and dynamic environment. To that, I have no conception of how the developers programmed such a realistic ecosystem, and frankly, I'm content to believe that it was black magic. All in all I would wholeheartedly recommend and a solid 10/10.

Genuinely one of the best games I've ever played, and one of my favourite games of all time.
The atmosphere and art direction of this game is phenomenal. Every aspect is beautifully designed and thought out. The visuals are breathtaking, i will often find myself stopping to take in the environments while the incredible soundtrack plays in the background.  And the actual game-play elements are so well done and I enjoy every second of it.

The game can be quite challenging for new players, but that's by design. Getting to explore and learn how the world works for yourself alongside how to survive in this new environment is part of the experience, so please don't let it put you off from giving it a try.
If the difficulty really IS giving you a hard time, there's no shame in looking up guides, tutorials, or installing mods to make the experience more enjoyable for you.

And speaking of, the modding community for this community is great. The steam workshop integration means you can easily find a variety of mods to customise your game experience to your liking or spice things up a bit (not that the game doesn't already have a TON of replayability ). I myself play with a number of mods to to tune my experience to get the most personal enjoyment out of it. Although, I would still love and enjoy the game to pieces without them.
And speaking of the replayability, the AI for this game is incredible, it's everything it needs to be and more. I know it's been said to death but it absolutely does feel like you're a part of a living breathing ecosystem while playing the game, and I love it so much. A truly immersive ecosystem sim like this with creatures that feel alive is something I've always wanted in a game, and Rain World more than delivers.
This game also boasts deep lore with an interesting story and characters, if you're willing do dig a bit for it. Again, no shame in looking up stuff for yourself if you can't or don't want to try and figure out how to unlock all the story and lore bits for yourself. But it's definitely worth looking into either way.

The game features 3 campaigns to choose from in the base-game, and 8 (technically 9) in total with the DLC (which I HIGHLY recommend getting if you purchase Rain World, it more than doubles the amount of content in the game and is absolutely worth it.) meaning there are plenty of different ways you can play the game and so many hours of content. The intended way of playing the campaigns is by unlocking them, but if there's one you really don't like or one you want to do immediately you can use mods to unlock them all (though i highly recommend doing it the intended way).
There's also a lot of content to be found in the other game modes and Co-op.

TLDR; Rain World is an incredible experience worth trying out. It can be tough for new players but I highly recommend giving it a go anyways, and if it's too challenging you can always install mods or look up guides. The game is more than worth the money.

Rain world does not care about you. It will throw you into its world and expect you to just figure it out. Unlike most games that say they dont hold your hand, rain world really means it. To the point where this game has one of, if not THE coolest 2d platforming movesets ive seen, yet it doesnt even tell you the basic moves of it.

The world is also not designed for you. Theres paths that lead to nowhere, obvious routes that lead to areas you're way too inexperienced to clear, and enemies that roam freely, making navigation at times actually impossible
Oh, and its also hard as nuts. You'll die a lot, and for most of your first playthrough, plenty of those deaths will not really be your fault.
This game has so much traditionally bad game design that it SHOULD NOT work, yet its one of my all time favorite games.

The art and atmosphere is some of the best ive seen from a post-appocalyptic world.
The moveset is so varied and diverse, once you learn it you have tools for every situation
The enemies are absolutely exelent, and their ai is phenomenal, really making battles feel like a struggle between two (or more) creatures who just want to survive
The way the world is built up, while not traditionally amazing, makes for some of the most fun exploring ive had in a game
And the ammount of content and hours you get from this game rivals even hollow knight, especially with the downpour expansion

Despite its flaws, rain world is a true hidden gem. If you can overlook, or especially if you manage to embrace all its weird quirks, youre going to have an unforgettable experience.
There isn't, and probably never will be, another game like rain world. And for that i will always cherish it.

Good game

Some people like the difficulty and unfairness. I am no such person. Whether it's pixel perfect parkour that your slugcat will suicide off a pole for no reason or some dumbass fetch or delivery quest that forces you to abandon half your kit to transport an object (spearmaster).

Still leaving a positive review, loathe as i am to want to, because it's still a good game.

I typically don't play games like this and only really started in the first place because I could play it in coop with a friend of mine. The first 10 or so hours were hell and I didn't really care what was going on, I wandered around with aimlessly for god knows how long and ended up exactly where I didn't need to be. 

This game, visually, is beautiful. The environment has an ungodly amount of detail not just in appearance but contextually within the world. Appearance wise, the game's world aesthetic hits a similar part of my brain that the environments in Dr. Seuss books do. The music is relaxing and PERFECTLY captures the environments they're used in. That said, for me at the very least, it isn't enough to make my opinion of it positive alone, not even close. No amount of art, either visual or audible could ever be enough to break down the sheer amount of disdain I had for this game.

The game itself, initially, guides you to a place that you don't really need to be and its storytelling is vague to the point that it SOMEHOW blurs the line between having a story and not having one at all.

At least, that's how it felt at first.

After hours upon AGONISING hours of playing a game I almost certainly hated. A game, mind you that's set in a world fully out to tear you a new one in the same ways over and over and over and over and over again. 
You reach a point where finally you're finally able to properly question the world you're in. 

You keep going upwards into the sky, climbing higher and higher, and as you do things about the world that had, up until then just been, "Accept it, its a fictional world with its own rules.", start to give clues towards making sense of the whole situation. 
"Why is the whole world bombarded with rain so heavy that you can get crushed to death just standing in it for a few seconds?" 
"I don't know really, but the inside of this monolithic structure I've been climbing for the past 3 hours starts producing the ungodly amounts of lightning right before it starts to rain."

Then of course, proper answers are given, DIRECTLY, and it becomes painfully clear that there's a reason you've been hating playing this game, the game doesn't like you OR hate you.
To the rest of the world you might as well not exist, the player gets NO preferential treatment in any way, you could literally not exist and the world of the game would continue on without you.

And that's exactly why it's so tough, you have to use what little you can find around the world to survive in the same way you'd have to if you were dumped in the wild. The game won't help you, and if you want to progress you'll have to constantly be proving that your survival hasn't been a fluke, that those who chase you with the intent to eat you will in their own way have to prove they can continue to survive by either having to contend with your choice of fight or flight.

Gameplay wise this works incredibly well... IN THE LONG RUN. At the start you're still learning how to move, in a way you're no different to a toddler, trying to survive in a brand new world while not having a good understanding of what's happening, all you know is that you want food and to not die. 
In a way this contributes to how empty the first hours of the game can feel. Though the game does have a guide pointing you in A direction to go and helping you learn how the world works their help is 'limited' to say the least and while I could talk about the story reasons for that, I'd be getting off track.

For the most part you're on your own, wandering aimlessly and without reason or motivation beyond your own fluctuating curiosity. Travel, sleep, repeat.

Somewhat shockingly, once you eventually claw your way to where you need to be the aimlessness ends, you learn exactly what you need to do and on the travel you'll have gained ALL the skills you need to accomplish your goal.

Upon reaching the final goal you WILL have questions the primary of which will most likely be "What was any of that?"

And that's where the Rainworld experience truly begins. When you beat the first campaign, which, yes there are multiple stories, you'll have everything you need to start properly taking in the game from that point on. The first campaign doesn't tell much, it has a start and an end and everything in the middle is a really long roundabout journey.
The rest of the campaigns are a different story, they have much more direct story telling with some elements only making sense (clear sense mind you) because you've seen the differences from other points in time.

I LOVE this game, I love it for the truly strange, beautiful and outright depressing story that trickles in drop by agonising drop. I love the gameplay and the difficulty of said gameplay and how every victory is my own. I  love the environments and ecosystems and how the creatures that inhabit them make logical sense in the context of the world. I love the music and how each song effortlessly brings me back to the events that transpired around them (Seriously, if I allowed myself to, I could shed tears listening to "digital sundown", Speaking of which DO NOT EAT THE TINY FLOATING GLOWING WHITE THINGS YOU WILL GENUINELY REGRET IT FOR THE REST OF YOUR LIFE I AM NOT EVEN SLIGHTLY JOKING IF YOU DO THEN DROWN YOURSELF). 

One last thing. A big part of this game is the dying and retrying. I really hated that for the longest time. Then I just stopped hating it. I know saying "It's just part of the experience." Isn't what people who are tired of it don't want to hear but it literally doesn't bother me at all anymore, and it's not a desensitisation thing either, it's just that death is such a big part of this game that it changes from the traditional "Ow I'm being punished for being bad at the game" or "I can't believe this! I'm just an unlucky person and this game is unforgiving." to "Crap there's a lot of enemies that way and running through didn't work. Can I do anything about that this time or do I need to find another way around this?". Treat death differently to usual because the game does too.

TLDR: Rainworld is hard. There are reasons for everything. You are not important in the world and it treats you as such. The game and story is guaranteed to be really fun from at least the end of the first campaign onwards. DO NOT EAT THE GOD DAMN FLOATING WHITE THINGS I CANNOT IMPRESS UPON YOU HOW MUCH YOU WILL AS A PERSON REGRET DOING THAT SERIOUSLY DO NOT SAVE IF YOU DO THEY DON'T MAKE THE GAME HARDER THEY JUST MAKE YOU SADDER.

A truely unique and amazing game that I can't recommend to most people. I wish a review could be positive without being a recommendation.

Many of the reviews say the game is grueling and difficult, but it depends on your perspective. This isn't a metroidvania, a soulslike, or even a survival game; your only objective is to be a funny slugcat. Anything else you want to do -- exploration, finding specific places or NPCs, or "completing" the game -- are up to you. Funny slugcat is fragile, hungry, and dies a lot. But funny slugcat can also be sneaky, acrobatic, and lethally creative. The joy of this game is in improving piloting slugcat, experiencing the ever-changing world, and seeing a lot of weird and interesting sights. With time, you'll learn to turn the tables on the predators that hunt you... or maybe you'll get good at slipping past them by the skin of your teeth.

Before I start this, I must say that this game is not for everyone. While I believe Rain World is a gem of a game, it is very RNG heavy, and barely tells you anything at the start of the game. The AI is amazing, and the game looks like a work of art, but isn't perfect. The new player experience is admittedly horrible, but this trades into an amazing game, if you give it time. Even if you don't feel that you like it, play it for a while.

Slugcat my beloved

Edit after completing some slugcat playthroughs: I absolutely adore this game. Everything about it feels so right to me it clicks so well. While the game does frustrate me at times, it is wonderful. The world is so amazing, the creatures are so interesting, and the stories of the slugcats/ the overall world really hits me. I have currently finished the main endings for half the scugs and i just can't stop thinking about them. The art style is so great and when the music plays it reminds me to take in the world. The ai is extremely interactive and it really feels like you exist in an environment of living beings. It never stops being hair raising either, trying to make it to the next shelter before seeing the shadow of a vulture always makes me sprint to the safest spot. There are moments in this game that leave me in awe. There are moments where I can't help but laugh when a lizard bites me and as its carrying me to its den a vulture snatches it and flies away with both of us. There are moments in this game that scare me to death but making it out feels like the most rewarding thing out there. I love this game so much and it deserves all of its praises.

super unique game that scratches an itch nothing else has before. challenging learning curve and random chaos events that make it seem totally unfair at times. the vibe is one of a kind. The lore behind this game is very obscure, there is a lot of world building and backstory you may not understand even after completing your first play through. Soooo interesting and imaginative once you begin to piece together the clues(and maybe read some things online). gameplay is very immersive especially with headphones. The soundtrack and ambiance is amazing. Gameplay can be demoralizing and discouraging and may be taken best in small doses but once you learn that half the game is hiding and watching and learning and dying and learning more before you die again, its okay to die a lot, you're supposed to be vulnerable, its kind of fun to get eaten, it gets the blood pumping anyway. The whole beginning feels less anxious once you learn to play more on the side of curiosity than caution, you can expect to always find more new things and discover stuff but its a losing battle to stress over staying alive all the time, especially in the beginning areas. Curiosity killed the Slugcat but he always comes back, curious as ever!!

Rain World is one of the coolest survival and exploration games I've ever played. You can pretty much go anywhere on the map without being tied to actually be doing anything, even though a great story comes with the game.

The music in this game backed by the story makes for an awesome synergy. Not to mention the immersion with the different regions danger tracks.

It can become quite challenging at some points and even though you're up against the ticking clock of the cycles, you have to stop and think strategically of how to get through and past the dangers of Rain World.

The expansion Downpour is the best addition to this game. Expanded story and added replay value!
this game is SO MUCH FUN, exploring was really cool too since everything was so mysterious, though i would have liked it if i got taught the long jump earlier, and if subterranean had an easier exit
please the game won't let me leave

Very fun and addicting. It's an experience that truly encapsulates the feeling of being just another animal within the ecosystem, but also has fascinating lore that may not be apparent at first glance. The platforming can be quite fun, but also very tricky, sometimes a slip of your finger is enough to undo the progress made over the past chunk of time. The game is quite unforgiving, I will say, but the amount of mods and Remix options available can make the game to your liking, whether it's just quality-of-life or things that better suit your playstyle. Sadly, co-op is paywalled behind DLC and local only (unless you use steam remote play), but is fun when connection is good enough. 
If you have a low frustration tolerance, or aren't into the "survival" aspect, I would not recommend this game to you. However, if you like platformers, survival-type games, navigating mazes, exploring environments, learning as you go, and unforgiving difficulty, this may be up your alley.

I first downloaded this game after playing a bunch of 2d platformers, and metroidvania, and I expected this to be exactly like all of the Hollow Knights and Celestes, it was not. This game is an incredibly well made, failure simulator. You die, over and over again, and I almost quit, but I ended up going onto YouTube and seeing all of the things  you can do later, and this propelled me to play on wards, getting to one area after another, and even if I wasn't making progress, I still was, I learned how to fight back against the creatures of this world, killing lizards, befriending scavengers, and I was becoming ever more proficient at exploring this amazing world. There is no upgrades, only getting better, and that why I love this game. If you think about quitting, don't, please.

Rain World is the best piece of media ever created. Beating Rain World has had more of an effect on who I am as a person than any other art in the entire world. Rain World is not an easy game, Rain World isn't going to hold your hand. Making progress feels like you earned it. You could play ultrakill and hit crazy shots and have a lot of fun doing so, but after you stop playing, Rain World sticks with you, this is a feeling ive experienced from no other game. You don't just forget Rain World, every cycle is different and memorable. The story of Rain World is told through its environments. You work to learn the story and this makes it much more impactful.

One of the greatest games ever made. At the beginning it's really difficult though. It gives one of the most crudely fair experiences you can get in a game, and that may feel actually unfair sometimes. But in the end there is just you and the game. You end up getting used to it's mechanics and the interactions available. It's an amazing recreation of an ecosystem that will make you feel like a small piece in a greater puzzle that you don't understand. You'll feel small, powerless, fearful, clueless... But you'll also feel inspired, intrigued, you'll want to learn more and get better at understanding and managing yourself in this world. And the level of satisfaction you'll get from getting better and from exploring is just unlike anything else I've ever experienced.

I normally wait until a game is completely finished to write a review. However, this game is so amazing I decided to write A review about it before I finished it. If you like the idea of existing in a world instead of a world existing around you like most video games, this game would be perfect for you. The whole game revolves around you existing in a world and feeling like you have no control over your situation and eventually, you'll learn to be able to control the Impossible situations you find yourself in.
It's a crazy ecosystem and really fun to play :)

This is an absolutely unfair game. It will beat you down and kick you at every moment it can. You are at the bottom of the food chain and every thing around you knows that. You must learn to survive, you must adapt, you must overcome the challenges you face just like every creature before you. The satisfaction you gain when you do is immeasurable. When you finally see yourself at the top you will be able to see how far you have flown. So I would suggest a blind play through with very little help or maybe a friend to join your journey. If I could replay this again with no experience, I would...
