Fun but end game is annoying, repeating and unfair.

I had a blast with this game for about 20 hours. The most fun part of this experience is learning what you can do and practicing it. Exploring the first 8 or so zones of the game is also great. 

The bad part is when you start progressing into the late-game. The game is challenging and feeling like the underdog out thinking and out performing the AI and environment is super rewarding. But when you get to the leg the rest of the game is locked behind climbs where you will die at the same place more than 50 times. Too make it worse the game sends you there a second time after youve already got past it with sheer luck the first time. This ruins the whole experience since ive been stuck on this part for more than 16 hours total and i now quit the game and will not recommend it. Its so heart breaking to have a great experience like this ruined by bad level-design that is not consistent with the rest of the game. please fix the white lizard climb in the leg so i can recommend the game. This is the only awful part of the game. Except some of the movement quirks/bugs. 

If you want to love something then get extremely disappointed to the point of heart break this is the game for you.

EDIT: Finished the game. Feel the same way about it. Wish there was more to it. The expansion adds alot of stuff but i cant speak for that. I was missing small things throughout this massive living world. I saw these orange glowing food fungus that was growing close to green what looked like grass. So i figured maybe you could grow more by placing some of that fungus on the grass but nothing happened. Just something i wish was in the game. More small meningfull planed interactions with the world

This game is a true work of art.

Rain world has the most well crafted and in depth ecosystem i have ever seen in a video game, from the level design to the creatures that roam it, from the atmosphere and how insignificant you the player feel walking across this brutal and indifferent planet. Rain World is a masterclass on how to create worlds that feels immersive and alive.

Unfortunately all of that are locked behind a mountain of frustration and confusion that any player will have to overcome first.You the player arent given any instruction on on what to do or where to go, which wouldnt be a problem at all if you arent so brutally punished for your lack of understanding. It feels the game is making fun of you for being stupid while it itself doesnt give you much if any context on how the game operate,Rain World definitely breaks what you commonly expect from a video game and as much as i want to explore all its uniquely crafted world,the experience is just too frustrating and isnt rewarding enough for me.

As a videogame, Rain World falls very short and leave a lot to be desired.

A while ago, I made a review not recommending this game on the basis of its unfair difficulty and contradicting game design. That was when I had 28 hours in the game. At the time of writing, I now have 153. 
When I wrote my negative review, I was a weakling. A fool. A conglomeration of spite towards the unfair circumstances that this game would put you through. And had it not been for the semi-recent addition of the workshop, my review would've stayed that way, and my hours would've stayed at where they were. Thankfully, after tweaking the game's mechanics about a hundred times over utilizing about twenty different mods, I can safely say that I now enjoy this game and its features- while still retaining its difficult nature.
The sad fact was, I needed to get gud. As harsh of a game as it was, and how relatively low the skill ceiling was for some aspects of the combat system, by downloading workshop items that changed its most unfair features and enabling some of the "remix" options, it became a much easier game to learn and a much fairer experience to enjoy.
Now, instead of putting holes in my walls after losing 10+ minutes of progress to sheer luck, I can now put holes in my walls for me not being good enough to meet the challenge. 
I recommend this game with a catch: that people do the same as me and utilize the workshop in order to play it to the best extent and to enjoy what Rain World has to offer without the unnecessary impediments.
Oh, and FUCK the promo team, who have helped foster one of the CRINGIEST communities I have ever had the displeasure of dealing with. They, the team, commissioned actual artists to promote their game by putting up several pictures of a main character in a catsuit, and then following up with some of the most god-awful vomit inducing furry bait that has turned a quaint, philosophically deep and niche game into "OWO!!!! Me HAz Slugcatt~! Durrrrr durr durrrrrrrrr durrrrr!!!! Me am CUTE like main character animalll!!! durrrrrr!" It's too bad I'm a nihilist, because if I weren't, I would pray to god for him to forever torture these fuck wits in the eternal oblivion of hellfire, so I don't get looked at weird when I recommend this game to other people.
I still will, anyway.

A pretty chill games and the DLC completes it with more stories and additions to the original. Has some cool mechanics too like faking your death (although hardly happens).

It can be extremely annoying at times too, however. Enemies will kill you from off screen and send you back 5-10 minutes at least. Also when you die, your Reputation may fall below the required to progress, so you will have to also grind food that randomly spawns before you can even consider progressing again.

TLDR
Chances are you'll hate this game. You'll hate it's movement, it's AI and pretty much everything else. But you should sleep on this feeling and give it some 10 hours and all of a sudden it turns into a 10/10 game and you love all those things you hated.

This game isn't a typical platformer. It isn't even a game made to be difficult. It is a mystery game, a detective of sorts. Your semi-permanent quest is to figure out what to do. And the answer to this question is so elusive you actually have no clue for pretty much the entirety of your first run. Honestly, it made me drop this game for a month. Because even Hollow Knight does give you some directions and this game seemingly gives none. It is only when I came back to complete it after this long break I figured out there were always clues. And the biggest clue you get is the experience of the past.

The first run you do is supposed to be really long. It is this way for a reason and you'll have to trust the devs and me on this one. Once you complete your first run you essentially learn all you need to experience the same thing again and see how much it changes. Before you do this, the game is about "rain" and after, it is about the "world". I'd say the experience you get is 5 hours of "AAAAAAAHHH!!!", 10 hours of "does it work like this?" and some 20 hours of "Oh, I see now!". That last part is so worth it.

The Downpour DLC has some nice additions to the base game that make it easier. Notable mentions are a few visual indicators for common things, random occasional hints and QoL tweaks. I wouldn't pick it up while you are still in "AAAAAAAHHH!!!" stage, but if you get over it the DLC will help you get through the "does it work like this?" faster. And of course it adds 5 new stories about new unique characters with various difficulty. Just make sure to not to look in "Major Assists" tab of Remix Options so that you don't spoil yourself anything. Those are mostly for some really hard things and it is honestly best to experience them as is before tweaking them to your liking.

The "world" is magnificent. The visuals, the music, the atmosphere... Solid 10/10. The lore is deep and almost consistent, 9/10. The gameplay is really good but with a few quirks you need to get used to, 9/10. All in all, this one is among the best games I've played but it may repel you at first. 10/10

I have yet to finish a single run of this game, mostly because the game honestly quite hostile to that idea. Its part of the point. The ecosystem doesn't much appreciate you trying to escape it, but you can.

The difficulty of discovering it was really only made worth while by the blood and sweat the writer/s put in (who unfortunately remain unknown to me).

Good lord James Primate absolutely fucking killed it. [h1] (-(     l. )-) [/h1]

[h3]       . [/h3]
Once you start, you will immediately notice the amount of effort put into the game. The art style and music is one of the best parts of the game that you will notice straight away.

[h3]    . [/h3]
At the start, you may be confused at the controls, maybe thinking they are too simple or weird. After a while, you will notice that you can do flips and rolls. Maybe you find it out on accident, or just messing around. But the game never tells you any of this so you get better the more you play and learn.

[h3]    . [/h3]
Once you go out, there is a small tutorial of some sort, a little guide to guide you to food. It shows you where and how you get food, and later where the closest shelter is.
This might also be the time where you encounter one of the many enemy's in the game.
All from lizards to giant mechanical vultures flying about looking for prey like you.
At this point, you may notice that this game is not forgiving. All the enemy spawns are random every time with a mind of its own. Every enemy think on their own and make their own strategy on how to survive. So you have to outsmart them by using movement, weapons and strategy.

[h3]    . [/h3]
This is a game where the creatures aren't just there only killing you. Every creature has a mind of its own and attacks other creatures to survive. For example, you can get taken by a lizard, and another lizard may attack the first one to steal the food (you). This gives an open window to run away while they are fighting. There are also apex predators like vultures, that wear masks. That if stolen, you can wear to scare off lizards. The game does this a lot, and there are just way too many creatures to bring up. You just have to explore and find out on your own by trial and error.

[h3]   . [/h3]
The story of rain world is probably one you must experience before you just search it up.
It's a really interesting story to say it at that. And is a big focus for a lot of people.

[h3]  . [/h3]
The only real problem I had while playing was the confusion on what to do next. It's not just me too, I've seen a lot of people saying the same thing at the start. I sadly had to search up where to go and used an online map to experience the game. I had a lot of fun playing the game like this, but it might not feel like you played the game as intended. There is a little creature that tells you where to go but it just takes me to some random direction and at the end if it I was all the way in some dark, claustrophobic, red, maze like tubes. And the way I took to get there was so hard at the time to get to that I just started over. Of course others may have a different experience, but this was my first time playing, and I went in blind to not spoil myself. So I had no clue on where to go.

[h2]  . [/h2]
All in all, I think this is one of if not the best games I've ever played. The gameplay unique fun and addicting almost as you want to go to the next shelter without being eaten or before it starts raining.

"Unfortunate" doesn't begin to describe this development, this area rewards blind luck and nothing else, I am beyond convinced at this point. After getting completely tooled by maneuvering with Pebbles changing gravity on me last minute and refusing to provide warning prior to the moment of the shift as to when, dying this way somehow felt even worse than I had thought possible. My preparation was superior, my play was superior, and I died, so I don't see a reason to continue engaging in an activity where what is within my control is overwhelmingly outweighed by what is not. I am done with Five Pebbles, and you won't get a fond farewell. This superstructure is infected to its roots with a degenerative disease that grows stronger over time but stops short of killing its host. Areas used to have an difficult yet balanced spirit at their heart, this has been transplanted and replaced with an artificial organism that feeds on my slugcat and the sanity leaking from my brain that can't take many more deaths without fatally wounding my ego. The game we enjoyed has trapped us all like this in a vicious cycle, and escaping it requires acceptance of the harshest reality we all scramble to explain away, that none of the countless straining efforts we put ourselves through here will ever amount to escaping the skill issue allegations. (or I guess you could try jumping into the void sea). I would make this the end, but the campaign is still ongoing, and I would never leave so many other great parts of the game out to dry, so I'll suffer through a few more cycles for them. One last thing before I leave you all to react with tips, ridicule, or straight up agreement, before you screenshot my words and thoughts, box them up and shove them to some cobwebbed corner of the internet. From this moment on, nothing you say matters to me. The greatest arguments you hurl with intent to convince me this area is good will calmly settle at the earth before my feet, and the facts you supply will bring all the difference of a singular coalescipede spider. The Rot is worth less than anything you can conceive, while I carry on, brimming with joy distilled from going through Chimney Canopy instead.

Having played through almost the entire game, I can confidently say that is definitely not the hidden gem some make it out to be. If you're the type of person that likes suffering through the first 4 seasons of a show only for it to become tolerable later on, this may be for you, but I cannot state enough how disappointed I was with this game.

I'll get the positive things out of the way first. Rain world *does* have a very unique art style. A lot of the environments genuinely do look pleasing. The combination of industrial scrap and and alien wildlife is very pretty, and doesn't really compare to much else. However, the lack of antialiasing can make smooth or fluid things look jagged and pixelated, which is unpleasant.
All of the movement, both player and NPC, is physics based. While it can be very clunky and lead to frustrating deaths (more on that later) it is unique, and out side of the "rage game" niche -- which rain world arguably falls into -- is unseen in the industry. There's also a lot of movement tech that comes with basic player actions, but most of it is useless, not taught to the player, or both.
The creature AI is also fairly impressive for the most part. Enemies don't stay in place until they see the player, but wander around and look for food. They can get into fights with other creatures, can panic upon seeing the player, and sometimes flee if injured in combat. This does make interactions feel much more dynamic, but also largely unpredictable.

Now onto the negatives, which rain world has no shortage of. To start the map. The enviroment is similar to a metroidvania, extremely big and often loops back on itself. Despite all this space, most of it is useless, only containing enemies and rocks you can throw at them. No power-ups, no tools, no rewards except unlocking items in sandbox mode. Some paths actually lead you away from the game's linear progression, which obviously means getting lost is an inevitability. There is a map function, but despite the 2d geometry, the map is in 3d, with three different "layers" you can go between.  When exploring, there's no indication that this happens, until you check the map. This makes navigation exceedingly difficult, which can be frustrating when exploring, or at worst, outright lethal. This is because you have a time limit between saves, which if you exceed, you die. If you do not get back to a designated save point in time, rain will come and you will drown. This means general exploration is not only discouraged, but progress forward at times requires near flawless execution of difficult platforming and avoiding enemies. Even if you do complete this in time and make it to the next save point, food is a resource required to save. If you attempt to save without eating enough, not only will your game not be saved, but the food requirement for saving next time will be increased. Getting food is the only motivation to enter into the aforementioned "side areas", which are still largely optional, as food does spawn on the main path.
Of course, actually finding the way you're supposed to be heading is only a small part of the game. The platforming platforming is definitely part of it, and can feel frustrating when the movement is so clunky, but dealing with enemies can range from "challenging" to downright unfair. Enemy AI, as mentioned before, is complex and unpredictable, which makes fighting them even more challenging. Your only attacking option is to throw a maximum of two projectiles in a horizontal line. This can already be difficult to make work with how many walls and different vertical heights there are, but is only exacerbated by enemies erratic movements. For the most part, enemies can also tank far more damage than the player is capable of dealing, meaning players will have to find more objects to throw at their predator while they are being chased. Enemies can also play dead, and camp you out on the other side of doorways, which I shouldn't have to explain why either of those are frustrating. Even if you do manage to kill one, you aren't rewarded for it, unless playing on what's advertised by the game itself as the "hardest" difficulty. All of these issues are made ten times worse by the fact that every enemy in the game one-shots you. If you let them grab you, you *will* die. In my nearly thirty hours of playtime, I have not seen a single exception. This makes learning from your mistakes much harder, and while you could practice combat, in most scenarios its much easier to avoid them. This is the jump in the skill curve so large, its nearly vertical. Players get into the habit of avoiding enemies whenever possible, which can lead to frustrating deaths or roadblocks when one is in the way. Enemy location is largely random with a few exceptions, which to a player that hasn't practiced killing them (which is a behavior that is almost discouraged by the game itself) means that progress forward can feel like a matter of chance.
And of course, all of this challenge provides absolutely no reward. The story is paper thin and largely environmental, and the backgrounds are pretty but don't impact gameplay. The only thing you unlock through progression is more places to get killed. There is no satisfaction of a hard boss fight, no gauntlet you have to battle through, and a surprisingly low amount of platforming that is inherently difficult. So while subjective, satisfaction rarely comes into play. I found myself extremely disappointed when I managed to find my way forward, as I either wasn't sure if I was actually headed in the right direction, or I just happened to crawl through the right tunnel after hours of wandering. The ending, while abstract and beautiful, does not justify how long and arduous the steps to reach it were.

As much potential as it has, this is a game that is unfair, unfun, and unrewarding. If you are willing to sink hours into mastering it, you may be one of the few that develop sunk cost fallacy and manage to wrestle some enjoyment out of it, but for anyone with less commitment than that, I can't give it any more than a 2/10.

An incredible experience, which seems minimalistic at first, but gradually introduces its vastness and depth through new mechanics and tools, creatures with unusual designs and behavior, platforming mechanics with a very high skill ceiling (if you are into that; skill floor isn't that high)
The game looks and sounds great, has a huge open world with a variety of unique locations to explore, immersive sim-like approach to combat or traversal.

So after some careful deliberation, I decided I can only negatively review this game. After beating Survivor, I looked around at all the reviews, the lore videos, and even a few lets plays to try to understand why I felt drawn to the game despite it being a huge drag to play. I've seen many people call this game a failure simulator, an immersion sim, etc. Not a single one of them properly explained why they liked the game itself, despite knowing and talking about the huge amount of painful, cruel, repetition there is in it. It felt more like they were making excuses about the games bad points more than anything. 

I will not be holding back on spoilers regarding a majority of the games mechanics. I will leave the plot stuff to the side. But, if you are wondering, there is very little dialogue in this game. This game is more about the world than it is about specific character building. 

If you like torturing yourself, then you should absolutely play this game. With the DLC, there are 8 characters, each with somewhat different experiences and plot, many with different abilities and difficulty, most of which will torment you for probably hundreds of hours.
There is a lot this game does right. Beautiful backgrounds and colors, wonderful soundtrack that only plays rarely, which all help to immerse you in this cruel world, bizarre and interesting lore, a variety of enemies and monstrosities, different areas with their own maps, tons of little tricks you can learn by experimenting, and more! There is even a reputation system for all the creatures, you can befriend the or you can antagonize them. I heard if you try really hard, you can make an entire species run away from you at first sight. 
 
But onto my critique:
The fact is, the gameplay is not rewarding. 
Any complaints in this game are responded to with "Skill Issue", but I challenge that it isn't really about skill. It's about stubbornness. Knowing what threats will spawn where and how those threats behave, where to go in these huge sprawling maps that tie back into themselves (this is a big one) and knowing the hundred+ page google docs worth of movement skills that the game doesn't tell you are huge unfair advantages. You need to stubbornly repeat things over and over. But the problem is, that the core loop gets old quick, and then becomes a drag. 

Here is the basic gameplay loop:
You spend a huge amount of time repeating parts where there are no threats to get to the parts where there are threats, and the threats can all kill you in one hit. You can kill them (which yields you nothing but more enemies), hit them with a rock, avoid them, whatever it takes to get past them. Even then, they will chase you. You don't know where you are going, and you will waste a lot of effort going the wrong way, dying several times and repeating it from scratch, before realizing that you were going the wrong direction, and then having to do it all again. While you are traveling in the world, you can grab some food so you can actually save your progress if you find shelters. 
On an important note, there is a varying amount of time each life before the rain comes. And you need to be in a shelter before the rain comes.
The amount of shelters that let you save your progress are generally low, and if you end up going the wrong way you will have to backtrack through what you just did. Every time you rest, it is referred to as moving onto a new cycle. 

Every map has different combinations of enemies and threats that leads to you having to learn to handle something new, meaning that even though you are getting better, its offset by more dangerous/different enemies that you need to learn. 
The main problem is that they do not reward you with anything. You do not get stronger nor do you get any other abilities. This game is not a metroidvania, there are singularly correct answers as to where to go, and while on the Survivor Slugcat you can absolutely waste all your time and go anywhere you want to go, it gains you nothing to do so. 

Escaping the things that the fanbase would call "Skill Issues", I want to complain about Karma and the Hunter Slugcat.

Every time you gather enough food and sleep in a shelter, you gain a Karma, and every time you die, you lose a Karma. There are Flowers that allow you to avoid losing Karma on death once, which you will maybe see now and then. But on your first playthroughs, you will absolutely be at bottom karma from an excessive amount of dying. The starting range for Karma is 1-5.

Introducing Karma Gates: To go through one map to the next, you occasionally need to meet a requirement to even be allowed to move on. So, if after dying 30 times on one area, and you see a shelter behind a karma gate that requires a Karma of 4, you will need to spend your time feeding your slugcat, sleeping 3 times, and then doing that same run that you died on so many times already.
Karma Gates basically tell you "Okay, you DID make it. Do it right this time though. Waste 30 minutes, and then make it to me without dying." 
Which on Survivor is annoying but you can just grind your head infinitely until you complete the run. 
But on Hunter? You have 20 cycles to finish the whole game on Hunter. Even if you grind your head, you will game over and have to start from scratch. And for Hunter, there are no Karma saving flowers. If it were not for the Karma gates, you could theoretically speedrun huge chunks of the game by grinding your head at it (you have that timer I mentioned before about the rain), and 20 Cycles would be doable. But because of Karma, you will have to give up on run after run until you perfect it. 
Which is like the Karma gates, but on the scale of having to repeat the whole campaign. 

I suppose all this could also be considered a skill issue. But I do not consider most of those people skillful, just tryhards with a lot more time to kill than I do.

All this said, I liked the game. The lore videos slapped. The game has a charm to it. Still cannot recommend it.

Do not be fooled by the silly cutesy sh*tpost and creature.
The game is merciless and indifferent.

This game aims to build an ecosystem that feels tangible and natural where creatures seems to have a mind of their own, and are minding their business. They are not level design elements for you to have fun with, they are sentient beasts looking for their next meal. 
Unlike most games, this one isn't a playground built for you to master. It is a food chain you will never be on top of. You cannot dominate it, only find your place in it.
And the game isn't doing anything to assist you or make itself easy to understand. You have to find out and learn the hard way

What all this achieves, is that after a few hours, you feel a very strong sense of belonging to this world. You have fought hard and now you are part of it. And it is part of you.

This game is very, very good. (and admittedly quite hard but not as much as you might think)

I went into this game expecting some Darkest Dungeon levels of RNG and difficulty, and was pleasantly surprised when it turned out to be a lot easier--atleast in the earlier stages, than I expected. It is still quite a hard game especially if you're not used to the Live, Die, Learn, Repeat cycle that a lot of games seem to have embraced these days, and the game does rely on a lot of RNG, but I found that very little of it is blatantly unfair; given that Rain World is fundamentally a game about rolling with the punches the RNG never felt too insane either. 

Rain World is also just a lot of fun. The relatively tight platforming plus the emphasis on maneuverability and evasion against stronger enemies lead to a lot of fun moments of panic, thoughtfulness and split-second decisions, especially once you leave the starting areas and Rain World shows you what its truly capable of. I honestly can't put into words how cool it is to watch two animals fight while you try to sneak away and get food, or to see a "Bird" fly down and know that it will go after the biggest creature in the room (ie not you). The ecosystem of this game is really it's backbone.  

TL:DR Good game, buy if you're used to Live, Die, Learn, Repeat, not as difficult as advertised, RNG is (almost always) good and ok. Ecosystem and platforming is incredible and very cool. Lots of content

Take on the role of an adorable little creature known only as the slugcat and embark on a treacherous journey through the ruins of an ancient civilisation that has long fallen into mystery only to be taken over by the cruel mistress of nature in an exotic ecosystem rife with alien lifeforms. But linger just a little to take in some of the awe inspiring scenery at your own peril because if the predators don't get you first, the deadly rains will. Now with the addition of the Downpour DLC, this game becomes 5 times bigger and adds several different slugcats to the mix who each have their own specific variety of features that make them and their conquests truly unique to all the others. Better yet, this game has remote play so you can play together with your friends with only one of you ever needing to own the game.

Word Of Warning: This game is very difficult, unforgiving, unpredictable and expects you to use your wits in order figure everything out for yourself. Whilst I personally love it, I can understand that it's not for everyone.

Don't let the game journalists shown on meta critic, who are bad at playing video games, fool you. This is an amazing game. It is a incredibly fun platformer with survival elements in a living world that holds surprising depth to its game play. The AI is incredible and makes the world feel alive. It truly does create the sense this game is home to a living ecosystem. Every animal and living being in this game has their own life to live. They actively hunt, fight for territory, and explore regardless of whether you are there to see it or not. Some more intelligent creatures even remember how you treat them and communicate with you through body language and gestures that you might easily not notice your first play through. This all helps show you that you are not the center of the universe, you are just a part of it. In fact, rather than the hero that is here to save the day, you are near the bottom of food chain. This results in a lot of fun game play where you try to do everything in your power to stay alive while avoiding or fighting predators in a hostile environment and creates a lot of fun tension as you try to move through the world to advance the story. 

Rain World's difficulty helps communicate your low level on the food chain and reinforce its existential narrative focus and Buddhist pondering. Is life worth living when you are just one small piece of existence and it can be so difficult at times. If so, why? You're just a cute little slug cat that is just a part of nature trying to survive like everyone else. However, this doesn't mean you can't try to figure out what you need to truly flourish in life and achieve great accomplishments, or participate in things that transcend you. As you dig deeper and pay attention to your surroundings you will hear a very interesting story that essentially centers around the theme of Buddhism. It will be up to you how you respond to it and how much of the story you uncover and try to understand. 

However, if you like, you can just be clueless like any animal in our world likely is, survive, and bask in the amazement of the mysterious world around you. Rain World really does capture a feeling of awe and wonder very well at times and give you a feeling that there are much greater forces at play than yourself you can't even begin to understand. 

Overall, if you are up for a challenging but fun platformer where you play, in a complex, beautiful, and dynamic environment, a cute animal that is occasionally exposed to the philosophical ponderings of Buddhists, this is the game for you.

Rain World is a phenomenal experience, but it has a steep learning curve and can get quite frustrating.

After 1.5 hrs of playing I was even thinking about refunding, questioning myself if I even want to keep playing, but I stuck with it. I simply did not "get" the game yet.

You play as a small slugcat in a much bigger world and ecosystem. In this ecosystem you are nearly at the bottom of the food chain. The game is pretty unforgiving as you can often die in one hit or by falling into the void. Around every 10 minutes (it is slightly randomized) the downpour starts. The rain is so heavy and thick that it will crush or drown you. Until then you have to find a safe shelter and enough food to enter hibernation. This leads to a gameplay loop where you are looking for a shelter and food at nearly all times and when you forget about it you enter a panic state as you scramble to find something safe as the rain starts.

The game features not enemies and rather NPC-animals. They search for food to survive and may not be after you at all and may even be neutral. Occasionally you will find packs of lizards fighting or a feared enemy hiding from another more dangerous creature. All enemies act according to their senses. 
This is important: Learn how each animal "sees"! Some may only react to fast movement or only hear sounds.

This way you slowly make your way through this world as you follow the small yellow overseer (Follow him, trust me. I kind of did not follow him and ended up in a sewer system that made my early 1.5 hours hell). 

At first the story may not be that clear and you don't know what it is about. It seems like you are just searching for your family, but it is much more than that. This only becomes really clear at the halfwaypoint of the game, but I won't spoil it now. Just let me tell you: This sequence was one of my favorite moments in video games in recent memory.

The world is set in the ruins of some ancient civilization, which went extinct. You will explore abandoned suburbs, overgrown factories, crumbling megastructures whose purpose you don't understand. It all is presented in an absolutely stunning way with gorgeous pixel art.

The music of the game is another absolute highlight. The calm tunes play fairly rarely and chime in randomly. The tracks greatly add to the atmosphere of this game's melancholic and lonely atmosphere, but also instills a sense of awe as you stumble through the ruins of a once great civilisation.

Rain World's main story (survivor) took me 15 hours to complete. The ending was confusing at first, but makes sense in hindsight. It's one of those endings where you think about the game for hours afterwards.

It is a game I can recommend to at least try out. Some may bounce off immediately and refund, but some of you may stick through with it and get used to the games platforming, its gameplayloop and most importantly: the frustration. Yes, the game often was really hard and frustrating, but I kept trying again and again and in the end I must say: 
 It was not just a game, it was an experience. And this experience was absolutely worth it.

Over all i think that rainworld is very well made. It a beautiful game, unlike anything else i've played. The eco-systems and the intelligence/personalities of all the different creatures is really unique and well done. I think my issues with rainworld aren't really at the fault of the creators, but this game definitely isn't for everyone. I struggle when playing this game a lot, as one misclick of a key can send you flying off the edge of a cliff when you meant to grab onto a pole, and you then have to start over the cycle, sometimes very far from where you were. I often find myself very frustrated when playing and because of this i have to take frequent breaks. The game really doesnt give you any information about the world around you. In some ways I like that, and in others I hate it. I'm usually looking up the information that the game doesn't tell you. There is also only one save slot which I have issues with as i find myself stuck in certain areas sometimes and would like to be able to start a new game to practice new things i've learned. Overall rainworld is a beautiful game, but its very difficult, and the different "difficulties" dont really help make the game easier.

After 20 hours not knowing what to do on my switch and dying repeatedly and a further 5 hours on steam of the same, with a few years between, Ive finally finished the main campaign and the hard campaign, and working through the DLC. The feeling of finally figuring out where and what Im supposed to do and how to do it, and then finishing it, is exceptionally rewarding. This is my all time favourite game and Im glad I stuck with it through my very poor initial skill and lack of initial understanding. Cant recommend this game enough. Its very hard to master but worth the effort to get to that point. I still maintain a blind play through is best but looking up hints from time to time to get you going in the right direction is definitely not a bad idea

Curiosity will draw you in. Mastery will let you leave.

The game is for players that love to explore and experiment, but who are also willing to spend the time, willpower, and frustration to get better. Players that want a casual platformer will have their spirit broken inside of an hour or two. The game gives virtually no hand holding, wont apologize for the difficulty level, and won't even tell you how to win. You won't get any power ups, new abilities, experience points, level ups, or upgrades, and you start (and end) at the bottom of the food chain. Your reward for surviving this friendly nightmare is one of the best endings in video game history, a cool backstory, and the satisfaction of knowing that you can backflip-stab a giant lizard (about 30% of the time).

PROS: Huge world, fun ecosystem, lovely visual style and detail, emphasis on mastery, absolutely transcendental ending. Lots of replay value for lore hunters and completionists.

CONS: Floaty and sluggish (punz!) controls, occasional cheap deaths, "RNG moments", rage quits, awkward screen transitions, unhelpful map feature, wears out my patience if played more than an hour at a time. 

Notes: 

- It's not a reflexive twitch game, as videos would make it out to be. Most of the game is pretty chilled. i didn't feel i needed a sedative after playing it.

- Everything people say about the brutal difficult level is true... on "easy" mode. 

- I think the game overstays its welcome after a while. I felt i really just wanted to get to the next area. Not knowing where to go was frustrating. You need to really, truly LOVE exploration to like Rain World.

- The controls are really loose. Do not expect Mega Man or Celeste levels of precise platforming. Slugcat only does what i want about half the time. I feel like i'm "negotiating" with slugcat more than controlling slugcat.

- This is an exceptionally bad game for people with real claustrophobia. Most of the game is about shimmying through tiny pipes and cracks filled with water, in the dark, with things trying to eat you on both ends. But if you think that's cool, then it is cool.

- Despite the shortcomings, the many surreal experiences and the ending are worth struggling for. 

Tip: I recommend you skip playing as "Monk" (easy mode) and go straight to "Survivor" (Normal). Ironically, Survivor is probably easier and you get access to more of the lore.

I think i will have another go at it in the future, but i need to take the game in small doses for my personal sanity.

Thanks to the dev team for this labor of love!

Rain world is a game that is hard to review. It has great atmosphere, very rewarding game play, a story that I believe is literally perfect, and contributes to at least half of my favorite songs of all time. Yet the game fails miserably at difficulty scaling and game design so bad I almost can't recommend it. 

The way I see it, this game is perfect aside from difficulty scaling and level design. To determine whether you will like this game we have to look at each of these and figure out if you're willing to deal with them to be able to enjoy the rest of what this game has to offer.

The first thing we will tackle is difficulty scaling. Usually when people think a game is too hard, it's not the difficulty in it of itself that's the problem, it's that the game is either unfair or doesn't scale the properly. The problem with rain world is the latter. With over 200 hours I can confidently say the game is not unfair. If you play perfect or near perfect you will never die. With this being said, you will die. You will die a lot. The reason for this is the knowledge necessary to play perfect will require you to die. For this reason, progress in this game is not only based on physical location, but also on what you have learned throughout the game. Getting to the next shelter can be less useful than learning what this creature does. However, this can be very frustrating if you haven't realized this yet, or simply don't enjoy this kind of game play loop. If you're willing to take the time necessary to learn the game, than this isn't really an issue, and can actually make the game more enjoyable.

Now for the real problem. Game design. Probably the most universally disliked aspect of rain world is the camera scroll. In most games, the camera will follow the player, keeping them in the center and able to see everything around them. Rain world does not do this. Instead, the game is divided into "screens", where you can only see the screen you are in at any given time. This leads to situations where you will die to something that was just off screen and you couldn't see. These situations are the only times where a death will be actually unfair. 

the next problem is... level design? I don't know exactly what to call it, but the problem is this: the game is non-linear. This in it of itself is not a problem. However, there is clearly a way that you should be going. You can go to the endgame within 3 hours of playtime. You can get effectively soft locked. Yes, it is better to restart than to try and get out. The game would be so much better with less non-linearity, at least between regions. There are simply areas of the game you don't want to be in at certain points of the play through. There is something meant to guide you, but it's directions are cryptic at best and illegible at worst. This is the games biggest flaw, and it can ruin the game if you go the wrong way.

The best way to explain it is this: if you can get through the bad design, you will love the game. I can guarantee you.

Steam asks "Do you recommend this game?" when writing a review, and the reality is, I chose 'no' because Rain World is not a game. Thus I cannot recommend it as a game. 

Rain World is an immersive simulator, that disguises itself as a metroidvania-style game, when in reality it's a science experiment by a curious developer. What Rain World excels at is being a digital world-building masterpiece, where you truly feel the influence of the environment and surroundings on the life of the slug cat, a creature at the bottom of the food chain. What it doesn't excel at, is being a fun video game. Rain World has difficult to master controls, proven by the 20+ page movement Google Docs document that is considered essential to play the game, but referenced nowhere on the Steam page. You find yourself spending more time backtracking to your previous location after an unfair and impossible to get out of death due to invisible enemies, or simply difficult to comprehend AI. 

The design of Rain World as a video game is poor. The design of Rain World as an immersive simulator is excellent. 

If that's something that interests you, and you desire to take part in the developer's walking simulator science experiment, and don't mind the frustration of unfair deaths and poor game design, Rain World might be for you. 

But it isn't for me.

Despite this game being my favorite game ever, I don't think it's for everyone. It can be very difficult and sometimes feel unfair, also the fact that there is hardly any direction and it's very easy to get lost. But I think its a game that everyone should at least try playing. If you stick with it it can be incredibly rewarding. 

Learning the quirks of every enemy type like how to avoid them and their AI, exploring the giant beautiful world, learning how to improve your limited movement as you go along, it feels great.

Rain World does a really good job of creating an ecosystem that can go on and does go on without you. Enemies fight and kill each other without you interacting with them at all. It also does a good job of making you feel like the slugcat: lost and alone at least at the start and not on the top or bottom of the food chain. A skilled player can kill even some of Rain World's most dangerous enemies.
Then there's the world. It's massive, likely over 1000 rooms but that's just a guess. All of it is beautifully crafted with tons of small details everywhere. 
The music is incredible. idk what I can say about it besides that it's just incredible. 

All of this combined helps to make the game's atmosphere. Rain World creates a really good atmosphere. Also I did say there was hardly any direction but if you need some just follow where the yellow thing tells you to go. 






So should you get this game? Yes definitely, it is a really well built amazing game despite sometimes feeling a bit unfair and being very challenging I think its worth sticking with.

Wish Steam had a middle rating feature, would not like to give it a recommend but also not deserving of a negative review. This game has some very good aspects to it. The difficulty is great for those who like challenges, the system makes you feel like you are prey (which I think is the goal), and there are lots of places to advance to. The music too, is excellent, and plays at the right moment, while silent in others to make the game have some tone while still feeling like the natural world, where it is quiet save for wildlife and environment. Further, the art style brings in retro well, but is still unique. Also much appreciated was the way that the screen did not follow the character. Other Metroidvanias, they tend to follow the thing you control and have limited fields of view because of this. Do not think Rain World would work if one could not have the whole scene because of the way enemies and such are. Having stated this, and hopefully shown that it is a good game still, there are some places where it feels unpolished and negative in its tutorial and guide system. Aside from a brief how-to at the start, the systems are not explained. Should be a way to understand how to combat enemies better, how to befriend neutral things better, and explore. The guide does an okay job showing where to go, but what stops new players from ignoring it is nothing, which can be very discouraging when lost in harder areas. On top of that, while I do not mind this because I like the challenge, there is a lot of dying involved. The timer to get to safety should be a little longer, at least at the start of the game so people can explore to get a feel better, in my view. Simply put, mechanics needed to be better explained and the goals need to be better highlighted. A further grievance, while not with the game but the community, is that this game is often compared to Hollow Knight. My only reason for playing. For those reading this review because they have been recommended it for that reason, these games are not comparable. While they are both listed as Metroidvanias, Hollow Knight had lots more combat, a way to advance through grinding things, and a narrative brought through other characters and lore. This also has as story, and is similarly difficult, but in a way where advancement is based on skill rather than progress by in-game abilities, and narrative is mostly done by way of cut-scenes. If here to replicate Hollow Knight, would not recommend. But, if you are up for a fun challenge, and looking to feel like you are in nature on a food chain, do play. It is an incredible and unique game with great development behind it, but its not for me as much as I may have wanted it to be.

While Rain World has a cool atmosphere, a beautiful art style and believable creatures, it's very hard to recommend this game to anyone for definite. The game encourages you to explore it's intriguing world in order to progress, but at the same time this is very difficult to do due to the predators and the deadly weather system. The confined spaces and the fact you level down when you die (closing off some rooms) certainly does not help this issue. I often found myself stuck in the same area for ages even though I would have liked to explore, which the main appeal of open worlds/metroidvanias.

I can see others really liking this game because it did do some stuff really well, the AI being a prime example. However, I find it pretty hit or miss since it is so difficult and I'm sure there are others that feel the same way.  Maybe it's just me though, Rain World has received much praise and, looking back, perhaps I played a bit too safe.

With that being said, I still do not feel like engaging with this game any more after the 8 hours I have put into it.
its very good, but punishing dificulty

Rain World is unfair. But thats what i like about it. It's unfair to everything in its world, not just the player. You will pretty often be killed by something off-screen, given no time to react. But just like the player, this can happen to any other creature. You could drop down from above and snatch a couple of batflys, giving them no time to react, pounce on a lizard from out of their view and stab them to death. The creatures in this game feel less like obstacles, and more like creatures. They exist to exist. They look for food before the cycle ends and find shelter when it does, just like you do.

While the controls are weird and clunky at first, you could change your controls in the settings to something else that you're more comfortable with. And the clunkiness, thats just what you're gonna have to deal with and get used to because of how the movement is dynamic and physics based. But that clunkiness is definitely worth it. There are just a few controls, which makes them easy to remember but also dozens of movements you can do with just a few inputs, which i find to be amazing.

OK so here's the deal. Rain World is STUNNING if you enjoy environmental story telling, fluid movement, niche discoveries, and unique AI. Nearly everything but the predetermined map is guaranteed to give you a new experience whenever you play a new run. There aren't many single player games that have this power. I cannot sing this game praises enough in those regards, but there are still some flaws to it. For first time players it's hard to know what you are supposed to be doing, and for a game that is oriented around exploration and survival it is difficult to figure out the end goal without finding the iterators. It took me so many hours to even find Looks to the Moon, only to realize I had been going in the wrong direction. 
Once you understand how the game functions and have a basic understanding of the map it is STILL incredibly fun to replay. The modding community is entirely available in steam workshop and the DLC is absolutely worth the purchase. It adds an entirely new aspect to the game with new stories and playstyles! 10/10 Would recommend.

First off, performance. When I heard that this game's AI was procedural generated, I assumed that was going to be unplayable slow on my current hardware, but it's actually one of the smoothest running games I own on my PC!
...
Rainworld is, as advertised, a challenging ecosystem simulator that puts you in the middle to low end of the food chain, (depending on what class you pick,) and it really feels like it; but don't let that scare you off. The game's ambient soundtrack is more than enough to keep you level headed while playing, which you will want to be if you wish to outsmart, and in some cases even befriend or tame the other creatures.
...
My only complaints are control related nit-picks that could be fixed in an update: omnidirectional throwing (unless that limitation is by design), a drop item button, control rebinding, and optional stick-jumping (i.e like Smash Bros has) would be nice.

So this game means a lot to me, It's undoubtedly one of the most captivating and immersive Indie games I've ever played. My first impression of playing this game back a couple years ago has left me with indescribable feelings I've yet to gain from any game. That in and of itself is special. A connection unlike any other, spiritual maybe, as this game does deal with life and death; a creature torn from it's family early on and forced to survive until it finds it's purpose in a long and forgotten world flooded by relentless rain. Without spoiling, a greater goal awaited this creature, a goal that is beyond comprehension that makes everything else seem so pointless.

Rain World is truly a one of a kind game. The artistic style of the game is nothing short of amazing as well as the soundtrack, which both serve to support the intense immersion of the world. Everything that makes this game unique works so well to create a believable ecosystem that surpasses what can be labeled as a just a video game. It's quite uncanny how realistic the ecosystem found in this game can feel, almost like it's an entirely different being disconnected from lines of code pasted onto a screen. From the various creatures to the places you can explore you'll get lost in the world of this game; with it's fully living ecosystem and very intelligent AI it makes for an amazing yet difficult experience. 

There's the main story mode as well as an arena mode where you can play to your liking with friends and experiment with various creatures and weapons. While traversing through the world it can be difficult, unfair, and at times very random, even though it is a very difficult game for newcomers you end up finding other ways to conquer and get past challenges you face. There's multiple different 'slug cats' you can play as, all with different abilities and difficulty levels; so even if you're having a hard time surviving you can turn down the difficulty to your liking. If you're thinking about trying this game out I would definitely recommend it as it brings with it an unforgettable experience that I myself have never and will never forget. Thank you for reading.
Fun, somewhat frustrating, but very very nice. Be a little slug man and swallow rocks just to hack em up later.

Rain World is one of those games that doesn't hold your hand and has you be part of a ecosystem where your place on the foodchain is the near bottom. This game is not for the impatient, nor for those looking for a quick play. It demands your time, quick reactions, as well as your sanity if you go the wrong route.
Rain World is also a very emotion-driven story about an old world slowly collapsing, where people are left to ponder their mistakes all around the idea that re-spawning is an actual story point in this world. If you are willing to go through an uphill battle on your very first playthorugh and make it out the other side, then the story that is given is worth it.

Rainworld is definitely among the best platform games I have seen and played. Although it may take you up to 100 hours to get accustomed to control the body of a slugcat, after you have internalised all the movement and fighting techniques and familiar with all the traits of different species, I believe that you will start to see the amazing part of this game. All these will make you a real slugcat and temporarily forget that you are actually not more than a human player, since the physics are so well simulated and the scenes so well designed. You will feel like a tiny component in an enormous ecosystem, thrilled by the mighty power of the downpour, the intricate interactions between species, and the shocking beauty of the art of environments. You will travel afar and have rich experiences. You will learn a different philosophy of life, time, and history. You will even start to reflect on your identity as a human being.

Play Rainworld, if you are not scared of the difficulty to survive as a weak small creature. By the time I write this review, I have played this game for over 300 hours and have played most of the campaigns twice. You will know why I spent so much time on it ;)

This game is good, but I'm writing this because it's incredibly annoying seeing how misleading so many of the positive reviews of this game are. The game is being recommended to people with mindless meme drivel or implications that its just a simulator of playing as a cute and small creature in a big world. I've been asked by friends if the game even has an ending, because the way people talk about this game completely obscures what it actually is. 

Rain World is a stress-inducing journey through an abandoned civilization brimming with danger. This game combines somewhat precise platforming with unusual controls, aggressive and intelligent enemies with fairly one-dimensional combat abilities, and a massive interconnected world of infrequent checkpoints with a dynamic time limit. The game only tells you how to utilize those sparse checkpoints and offers occasional directional guidance. Otherwise, you are on your own. The odds are greatly stacked against you, and as such you will certainly die, over and over again. 
But as you explore the world further, become comfortable with the unique controls and the combat, get used to the time limit for each of your daily outings, you begin to feel immersed within the dynamic world the game offers. You will find yourself wondering about the history of this wrecked world you've been wandering through, or wondering what the function of each unique area was in the now abandoned civilization-- how the world all comes together in one big picture-- as I did in my first journey through Rain World. 
The feelings of discovery you will experience in Rain World are rarely matched in gaming, and I think that is truly something special. You will suffer as you explore the interconnected world, meeting new dangers around every corner, and that experience of the cruel indifference of nature becomes almost euphoric. It's quite rare to feel truly small and weak in a video game, yet Rain World perfectly captures that experience and something about it was really revelating for me. Despite the capabilities offered by the unique controls, your brain will be your greatest ally as your traverse Rain World. Whether it is outsmarting dangers, finding the best pathing through an area, or discovering a previously unknown mechanic to you, you will certainly experience that great feeling of overcoming the insurmountable.
That, I believe, is the experience Rain World seeks to induce in its players. Overcoming. Learning. Surviving. Against all of the odds stacked against you in a massive, cruel world.

The atmosphere is amazing. Props to whoever did the environment art it's seriously a one-of-a-kind game. I love how it feels like I'm on an alien planet. While some games may attempt this, Rain World does it best. The AI can be a bit wonky at times, especially regarding the creature known for "transportation." There's a lot of ingenuity in the idea but it's poorly executed. Half the time I can't even get on top of its body, let alone its antlers. I can't tell you how many times I've died to worm grass. It's quite embarrassing actually. But despite this, I play on knowing that in the future I can do better. It's one of the only games I have played that makes me want to play more even though I failed. I enjoy that it doesn't feel punishing when I die or mess up. Makes it less disheartening to continue. The map itself is a maze of tunnels leading to other places. And you seriously have to keep track of that timer in the bottom corner. Otherwise, the rain will come without your knowing. It's such a cool concept to have every cycle on a timer. This technique sinks the player into the world itself. We have to abide by its rules otherwise it will swallow us whole. Over all I really like the game and I can't wait to keep playing more!

I don't see much point in the gameplay 'loop' of this videogame, you go eat food and then you hibernate. I had no issue with that at first, except for the fact that when I tried to break the loop by exploring, I would die. Even if it is my own fault that I perished, it still presents a glaring issue with the gameplay loop. Why should I, a slugcat, explore out of the area that I know to be safe, when there is a stable source of food and an easily accessible hibernation spot nearby. I could choose to venture out of my safe area, but I would likely die, and even if I don't die to some archaic predator, I won't even be able to find a hibernation spot by the time the rain comes and kills me. Therefore I stay in the same area, cycle after cycle, eating the same food while hibernating in the same spot. Again and again. Which is when the game starts to become dull. And that is why I don't recommend this game to you.

One of the best and most complex games i have ever played, but certainly not for everyone. 
[b] I recommend this game to people who: [/b]

-Like free exploration and experimentation
-Like challenging survival games or simulators
-Don't want the game to handhold them
-Like games with complex creature ai systems

[b] I wouldn't recommend this game to people who: [/b]

-Want a story-focused game
-Want the game to give them clear goals
-Are very bad at video games or only like easy ones
-Prefer to play online games (you can play online with friends but its a bit buggy)

Listen, before you continue reading my review here is my advice:

No review, no let's play video, nothing can truly prepare you for this game. You either will love it or hate it. Just remember that steam refunds is a thing and that you can try this game on your own and decide if you like this game or not

Now that this off my chest lets talk about rainworld.

+ Slapping soundtrack
+ It's pixel art suits the game
+ True rainworlding experience

/ Can be difficult and frustrating for people

This is Rainworld.

You play as a slugcat. You were torn appart from your family and now you are alone.
This is Rainworld. Such a small creature in such big world... the first on the foodchain. You feel lost. You feel frustrated. You wonder what will you do with your life and if you will even survive.

And the gameplay shows.

There aren't many tutorials, it just goes through the basics. Slugcat feels at the beggining like a bag of potatoes that you are trying to stir like a car on a ice. The are is easier then other areas but still there is danger. You can die and the map feels large and scary. But you are going through.

Because this is Rainworld.

A world where every creature is stuck in a cycle. It's death is not definitive as it comes back again and again. People trying to find out how to get out of this circle creating things and entities that would find the definitive question.

And again.... the gameplay shows that.

The deaths while punishing are quick. There isn't too long sequence when you die, you just are dead, shows your karma going down. You wake up. You go again. You have to expect with this game that you will die and you will die a lot, but for me for example dying wasn't punishing it was fun. I learnt more, or I will choose a different route. Thanksto the fact that this game works like an ecosystem, the danger changes. There might be different lizards or they might me somewhere else making this game less stale.

And at the end you will find the characters, you will find the lore and go through various very interesting locations that will kick your ass but then you will learn how to love them. 

Its a true masterpiece. I love this game and didn't find a game that would get close to the experience I had with Rainworld.

I has three characters that are basically difficulty in the base game.

Monk is considered the easy mode by many, however I believe it is the good character for a tutorial. There is still many dangers ahead but the experience isn't as frustrating. You will learn layouts of the maps with Monk without the frustration of other slugcats. The true banana boy.

Survivor is the basic rainworld experience. The story doesn't change as much but it is good spike of difficulty as you continue through.

Hunter is the challenge mode. You have limited time to do your objective and the world is out to kill you. For me this was frustrating experience but some will like th achallenge.

If you want more. I highly recommend buying the DLC as it adds so much to the game as 5 more slugcat campaigns, expeditions and multiplayer.

Highly recommend.

You are playing a slugcat, very cute little creature living in the world that is rather cruel. The world is immersive from the moment you start the game washed up divided appart from your family unknowing about the area you are in.

The controls might be unituitive at first and you will struggle. Oh you will struggle so much that you will wonder if you ever even have known if you learnt how to jump, grab or use items, but the longer you play the more you master this game. The magic is that you won't lose the challenging part of it.

There are still danger noodles everywhere and even if you learn how to dodge or kill them you never know what they will do thank to the great Ai, dangerous at the best and..... funny at the worst. (Seriously blue spinny lizards are such mood) 

There is still a lot to learn, only the movement guide that you can find on the internet is over 50 pages long, but you don't need to learn all of those to play and finish this game (Even though it could help)

The pixelart has its charm, for some coudl appear ugly at first, but it has such beauty with background and areas that you will stand and try to take the view (if you aren't chased by even more danger noodled and danger noodle deluxe edition with added wings and maybe even the animal equivalent of a shooting gun) You will learn to love the tiny slugcat body and its tiny eyes.

The lore is there for those who want and the base game carries short and interesting story. 

I can't recommend this game enough. If you like to play games not to finish it or for the progress (Because you will die and you will die a lot)  and are playing games for rather challenging experience I would give this game a shot.

Though I already have to recommend buying DLC with it because the DLC is so worth it.

Lacks replayability, but was the best first experience I have had playing a game ever. The ecosystem is incredibly complex and lively, and the backgrounds are absolutely gorgeous. It is a very polarizing game though, since it's incredibly easy to get lost and find yourself victim to really unfair RNG. Rainworld doesn't necessarily reward your progress either, but it works much in favor of the story. You are, to put it simply, just a slugcat. You don't get any special abilities or armour or anything, but instead learn the ins and outs of the world. Alot of times, the game will kill you and it might be unfair, or you might get close enough to a shelter but get killed over and over. Each death can be a lesson, and over time you learn to live as a slugcat. Hard to rate this game, as it's entirely non-linear, but for me its a 9.5/10.

This game is a standout in my library,and contrary to what this game's main selling point is,an exception to most of the games I've played.
You play as a small weak omnivorous animal known as a slugcat, a spry critter that can easily worm it's way through passages and pipes! this is where your main advantages are in this game, most threats you wouldn't wanna face head on but more worm your way around. And your small size and lack of defenses means you do have a lot of threats.
Luckily for you not everyone is against you! You are guided by a mysterious but seemingly benevolent creature known as an Overseer, It's able to somehow manifest holograms which it uses to help you progress! I'd recommend to follow it if you can figure out what it's trying to tell you.
Another potential ally is a scavenger, which is a social species that you can gain the friendship of via gifts!
I don't really have much more i can say on this game, as i haven't managed to uncover any story, but the gameplay and having you fill a much lesser role than what most games would have you fill has lead this to be one of my favorite games I've played so far!

Most players may never get the full picture, but that's thankfully where the fandom has stepped in to help with. A very enjoyable game, with a very active community and many fans, I definitely recommend trying it out if you can.

You take jank inconsistent platforming physics, and combine them with "hardcore" gameplay mechanics that actively encourage you to keep resource advantage and bulldoze your way through levels as quickly as possible instead of slowing down and sneaking around baddies like the game advertises, and what do you get?

You get a game that's kinda wack.

Can't even say the game's that hard; once you get past the first two areas you just run face-first through empty rooms and jank platforming that's more annoying than it is actually difficult.

Rain World is a funny, sometimes range inducing game. It has fun, cute slugcats to play as, and is full of a lot of content. It is a hard game, as many will say, but some reviewers say things about the game that are just not true. I have seen said that dying once resets all your progress or something like that, and that what was referencing the karma flower restored it if you could get it. This is a gross misunderstanding of the karma system and is not true. It is a game where you choose what your goals are, but not anything like a sandbox. You make choices on where to go, and maybe what to accomplish.

I actually have over 700 hours on this game, since I have mostly played on xbox (Review there more silly than serious like this one is).

Lemme tell you, this is the best game I have ever played. It has kept me entertained far longer than anything else besides maybe sonic mania or sonic mega collection +. The amount of replayability this has, especially with downpour (and of course the lovely mods, even if I have not played with them to their fullest extent due to incapability at this point in time), with expeditions being included and emphasized with that, is immense! Its not for everyone, especially with how hard it is to master the controls (I personally got use to them really fast), but it's difficulty is part of its charm.

I have completed the entire expedition challenges page, gotten at least one ending for all of the campaigns, obtained all but two colored pearls, and am only missing one Spearmaster broadcast. I plan on doing it all again several times after I 100% my primary save on xbox, just because I have enjoyed it so much. I have exclaimed that I hate this game many times in the few months I have played it, but it comes from a place of oxymoronic love. This is peak platformer, and I doubt that I will experience one that I enjoy quite like this one.

Also, Spearmaster best scug, cannot change my mind.

Rain World is a beautiful experience. And I don't say experience to sound pretentious; I feel that calling this a game off the bat tends to give people the wrong idea. People often look at Rain World and only see a 2d platformer, and while yes there is platforming, that isn't really what this game is. Rain World is an incredible environment simulator, at its core a survival experience. Critics review it poorly, YouTubers rarely finish it, but ask any fan and we'll tell you how wonderful this game really is. If you enjoy survival games, fictional creatures/speculative biology, or games with loads of interesting lore, Rain World is for you. If you're here for a regular platformer with a clear goal, however, I would suggest you find a different game.
do you like creatures and punishment? buy this game 10/10

So I think this is my first revwiew of a game but its just too much of a masterpiece not to say anything about it.
I don`t even know where to begin...well, at the start of course.
You get dropped into this lovingly made, detail rich world with just enough "personal" story to feel a connection to your character. Why the ".." you may ask and thats bc there are 2 stories here to unravel. First the personal story for every character (DLC Downpour included) that is prette obvious and then there is THE story that ties all storys, all characters together into one big picture, don't believe me? Check on youtube if you want to get spoiled, this game that is at first glance just a really hard and sweet platformer has such a deep story that it`s 1h 30min as a lore video.
And here comes my only critique if you can call it that, you are so busy exploring and surviving this wonderful compley ecosystem that you WILL miss 90% of the story...I hate that reference but think of it as the story in dark souls, there is one, yeah, and its genius and complex yeah, but if you don`t actively search for it you will miss it. But thats not that big of a deal because of the Ecosystem in Rainworld. Everything has its place or rather...it..doesn`t? Yeah so Rainwordls AI and creatures don'r really care if youre there or not, you are not the main character to them, to those creature you are just a meal passing by and Rainworld does such a good job making you feel close to the bottom of the food chain. But even then you are given tools, weapons and such that CAN turn the favours in your way again. You are just one small cog in a much larger machinery, much larger then your charakter and even you can comprehend in the beginning. And don`t get me startet on Scavangers those cheeky bastards. Their AI is so complex they organize like a real tribe and will even try and "communicate" with you when you`re not hostile...but I've bin babbbling on here for far too long alredy, if you`re still here reading this thank thank you for your time and I hope you have a splendid time exploring this rainy world and discovering its secrets :D

It may feel at first like an awful platformer. In reality it is a genius survival game. Reflexes and precision can certainly sometimes help, but you'll get a lot more enjoyment and mileage out of this game by forming strategies and respecting the game on its own terms. Rainworld demands that the player pays attention, remembers things, and notices details, sometimes to an unfair degree. If you stick with it, however, it is one of the most satisfying worlds to learn and master.

PS. The game never tells you this, but you can do the 3D Mario sideflip and an action hero roll.

This game has a lot of charm but death happens far too often because of random predator behaviour (namely them getting stuck which is quite problematic considering how linear the game is) and iffy character controls to be enjoyable. Add to that you also lose progression whenever you die and you can see why only 27% of players got the first achievement (as of the time of writing this review at least).

The illusion of being part of an ecosystem also fell off as I started to notice that, most of the time, predators would be laser-focused on me as soon as I entered the screen.

I could go on - the short of it is: I would only recommend this game to masochists that enjoy an unfair game with a unique charm.

This game is a masterpiece. 
Having completed all of the achievements and ran though the game multiple times, I can say that this game is awesome. While I know it is not everyone's cup of tea, being RNG-Based at times, and the difficulty because of it, it is its own little world- literally. Most everything isn't scripted (with some exceptions) and you can for the most part choose what you want to do. Want to go on a killing spree? Ok! Just be careful of what the consequences may bring. Want to tame the entire lizard population? Go for it! 
And because it isn't scripted, dying to strategically placed pole mimics, being eaten by a lizard for being in the wrong place in the wrong time, etc, you become a part of the world that this game has created. You are among some of the many creatures of this game that are just as wild as the creatures in real life can be.  

The story the game and it's DLC brings is very nice. I will not spoil it, but playing through each of the campaigns was a wild ride- and the story begins to unfold itself as you play, with even more hidden that you may not find at a first glance. 
I encourage those who have taken interest in this game, but have not gotten it, to please enjoy it as much as I do. It is difficult at times, and very frustrating when you keep dying over and over, but do not drop it because of that. You will see that as you get better, you will be able to get past most of the areas that once gave you so much trouble much easier than when you first stumble your way through.

Rain World is one of the best games I've ever played, vastly exceeding my expectations and vastly outperforming other similarly marketed indie Metroidvania-type titles. The AI here is truly amazing for something from a two-man team, with creatures moving about and interacting with the world and with each other in unscripted, procedurally-generated ways. The atmosphere is mesmerizing, and the game is full of mystery from the get-go. The world is surprisingly vast and you can sink a ton of hours into this if you want to. 

At first blush, the play control feels clunky and uncomfortable, but as you get used to it (and adapt to the fact that combat isn't really the focus here)  it feels mostly perfect. I do like using a couple mods, though, like the one where you can dual-wield. 

It is a difficult game (even with mods) with a lot more depth than you probably expect. 

I recommend going into this game as blind as you can, except for maybe looking up a tutorial on the play control mechanics. It's really fun to discover the many secrets of this game for yourself. 

Really an unsung triumph that too few people know/talk about.
