I'd recommend Rainworld to someone who:

- wishes to experience an alien world in all its terror and glory through the eyes of essentially a newborn
- seeks to feel a sense of awe and wonder
- is fascinated by nature and cycles of life, death, and rebirth
- prefers the joy of discovery and mastery to linear objectives and story
- enjoys a game that is indifferent to your desire to be the hero character
- enjoys a limited control scheme that is difficult to master
- enjoys intense platforming experiences
- enjoys intense survival mechanics
- embraces failure
- is okay experiencing misfortune often
- is okay with unanswered questions
- is okay with games that have a timer running at all times
- is okay with looking at the wiki for answers to unanswered questions
- enjoys the payoff of a large time commitment
- does not have difficulty with anger management
- is not afraid or spiders, bugs, creepy crawlies, or the dark
- spends a lot of time with the thoughts in their head
- enjoys philosophy

Rainworld is a game that is difficult to recommend to people. Why? Because the best way to experience the game is also the most frustrating and nonsensical for the average gamer. Almost nothing is told to you about the game mechanincs, controls, or your objectives. Because of this I'm sure 95% of people who try the game quit shortly after starting it. However, for the rare persistent person who values discovery and mastery, the payoff is massive. If those two things are not a primary motivator in your gaming experience I think you will struggle to enjoy what is offered here.

Those who stick around will find a MASSIVE world full of bizarre alien flora, fauna, and vistas looking to be explored. This is the up-front draw of the game but pretty much everything here wants to eat you so surviving is a challenge. Rainworld wants you to experience loss and the inevitability of death. It wants you to realize that what you can do is limited to your place in the foodchain and the cycles of death and reincarnation. Much of the satisfaction of the game comes from overcoming the odds stacked against you as you slowly gain knowledge of your environment use it to live another day. In many ways Rainworld is the antithesis to modern gaming. Instead of drawing you in with shiny loot and power fantasies, it hides most of its best experiences behind hours of mistakes you will make in exploring the world and the gameplay. Later on as you get a grip on surviving you will begin to ask questions and want answers. They are difficult to find. Your final journey to get them is challenging but few game resolutions have had as much of an impact on me as this one.

If somehow I haven't scared you off and you are still wanting to give the game a try I'd recommend you play for an hour or so and get familiar with some of the ideas and concepts. Then go look at a movement and mechanics guide on steam or the wiki to help you understand some of the basics. Oh and also there are some great maps out there! I think this will improve your experience with the game immensely without spoiling any of the later discoveries down the road. I've played over 100 hours and I'm still constantly learning new tricks and tips that would've kept me from dying so many times. There's no shame in making things a bit easier on yourself so you can enjoy the rest of what it has to offer. 

I came into Rainworld originally expecting to play as a cute slugcat and appreciate the art. I didn't expect to find a game that attempted to recreate ecosystems, get me to ask existential questions, or rage quit for months at a time. If you're ready to commit to something like that, I wish you luck and hope you find it as fascinating as I have. 

p.s. - if you love the base game, the DLC  Dounpour is beyond worth it. So much content included and made primarily by fans of the game. It's incredible.

Probably the most frustrating game I have ever played.

The controls are awful. Too many actions are bound to too few buttons. Picking up, eating, swallowing (separate from eating), vomiting up, swapping hands, and dropping are all on one button. When carrying something in each hand, it's hard to tell which one you're going to throw if you hit the throw button. Trying to grab on to the correct pole when jumping between multiple ones is very hard, and some of the poles are hungry creatures in disguise. Sometimes you can't tell if a jump is impossible to make or if you're just doing it wrong.

The map is too big, too visually similar, too painful to navigate. The progression system sucks. The only way to know where you're supposed to go is to stand around until a little yellow bug pops up and highlights the door that will take you in the right direction.

The living ecosystem stuff is impressive, except that all you can really do is just avoid every creature you see. And they spawn in different places each life, so sometimes your path is completely blocked with stuff that's not worth dealing with, while other times it's a walk in the park.

Finally felt like I was making some real progress, but then accidentally wound up hurting an important NPC, and now the guidance bugs don't show up anymore apparently. To twist the knife, it also gives you an achievement. Now I feel bad an never want to touch the game again.

[i]Rain World[/i] has a lot going for it: the game presents its visual in a charming and beautiful way, a similarly beautiful abstract soundtrack, and the general theme about the lack of regard the natural world has for humans and animals alike. These qualities alone were enough to power me through my experience with the game. But when it comes to actually playing the game, the level of jank present in the game slams you in the face. In a game so heavily dependent on movement, you feel so out of control of your character and at times it feels like it's a roll of the dice as to whether you actually get to do what you intend. It's at such a level to where it sometimes feels like it's a ragebait game. I can't recommend [i]Rain World[/i], the jank is too high a barrier for me and not what I'd expect out of a platformer.

Ok, I'm going to update this review later since I only have 3 hours in this game, but I would not recommend Rain World.

I like the art style, but it is virtually impossible to figure out where you're supposed to go, all you get is a symbol projected from a worm somewhere in the screen, which leads to looping around trying to find a shelter or your objective. The gameplay loop is literally just "wake up, eat, avoid enemies, sleep before the rain". That's it. The enemies are overpowered, even on the [b]easiest fucking difficulty[/b].

I am also kind of salty that I was baited into buying this game because "they were gonna delist it due to unity shenanigans so better buy it now". That is a shitty business tactic, especially considering Unity backpedaling their proposed changes.

Honestly, the reviews saying that Rain World is a "streamer bait rage game disguised as an indie metroidvania" are kind of true in my opinion.

All in all, wait for a sale if you want it, preferably at a 60% discount or higher.

Also, one more thing: [b]PLEASE ADD NATIVE FULLSCREEN SUPPORT, I DON'T WANT TO SQUINT LOOKING AT THE GAME WINDOWED[/b]

Rain World is not just any video game, it's unforgiving, it's unfair, it's perfect. The game will frustrate you, it'll make you feel like it's impossible but it's not, the game teaches you to persist and keep trying, the "enemies" are all wild animals, and so are you. It's hard, and it's punishing, and sometimes you'll walk into a room with five cyan lizards as hunter and there's nothing you can do about it. The game has it's fair share of bugs, you, your food, and your children will sometimes get stuck in a wall, But it's nothing that can take away from this game's skillful coding and design. The ambience of the world is amazing, the songs are awesome, the backgrounds are gorgeous, and the game is stunning. The creatures interact when you're not in the room, they fight, they trade, they interact with things. You can befriend things and you can make enemies of things. I would reccomend this game to anyone who wants to try a new thing, it may seem without a story at first but i guarantee you, as someone whos completed every base game campaign and every dlc campaign (except a certain non-canon slug i leave out for discovery's sake ) it has one. The game is a story-survival with a tough of platforming. It feels alive, and it's truly a wonderful experience.

The game is really interesting to say the least: very good prey vs predator gameplay, the AI sells the illusion of being smart well enough, very creative mechanics, ...
However, as a whole, it asks too much of the player's mental strenght to withstand a fractal-shaped stochastic process of random bs that neither you nor the developer himself can possibly predict or even adapt to. And on top of that, you are on a timer.

Some of the frustrations I experienced are (but not limited to):
- NPC dying offscreen to a very specific hostile creature and its corpse - supposedly - phasing through the floor clogging the only practical way to get back to safety;
- falling down into a pit because some NPC popped out of the tunnel you just used, spazzing out the physics and launching you to your doom;
- hostile NPCs getting stuck on each other preventing you to go forward, potentially wasting an entire cycle.

I won't judge this game solely on these admittedly rare yet incredibly frustrating situations, because I don't want to take away from the spotlight the most perplexing aspect that affects the whole game: the camera.
Why does this game have fixed cameras? How am I supposed to be constantly aware of my surroundings?
I lost count how many times I jumped into some lizard's mouth who was just chilling in the transition from one fixed camera to the next or fell down from a platform in the same manner.
It doesn't come to a surprise that the most effective way to deal with mobs is just tunneling back and forth.

Despite all that I pushed through because this does feel like a really ambitious project and I congratulate the dev to manage to pull it off... but it's just not for me and I would recommend this game only to those with a pain threshold high enough to withstand competitive crotch kicking.

P.S. 40 hours and NO practical use whatsoever for bombs.

Rain World is one of the best games of allt time. 

First of all, the artstyle of the game is absolutely gorgeous. All of the areas in the game have their own unique vibe, ranging from murky, abandoned sewages to crumbling radio towers. 

The creatures in the game are fantastic aswell. They all have their own goals and objectives, leading to very interesting encounders, like stumbling into a room where a group of primates are desparatly trying to fend of a giant centipede, or two lizards having a duel over territory. This makes the world truly feel alive on a level that no game has ever managed to achieve.

The story is also great, especially if you have the Downpour expansion, which i strongly urge you to get if you engoyed the game. You play as Slugcat, i little, slimy thing at the bottom of the food chain that wants nothing but to find their parents, though later on, you realise that you can serve a much greater puropse.

Be aware though that the game has a very minimal tutorial, so you have to figure out how to interact with the items and creatures yourself, though this further adds to the feeling of being small and and lonely.

One of the greatest games ever made. A work of art that deserves far more attention and celebration. Sure, it can be pretty opaque and requires much more patience than the average game, but the payoff, the beauty, the story, the gameplay and the world are breathtaking. Do not go all of your life without experiencing this game. Try. The DLC is also mandatory.

(spoilers ahead)
Allow me to preface by saying that this game is INSANELY brutal. If you want to make the game slightly easier, I suggest getting mods like "Struggle" to make it slightly easier for your first time. Even then, the game is NOT for everyone. Death is a constant, and I advise anyone who has a short temper to not play Rain World. 

Rain World is a heavily chance-based game (not RNG). In a region, enemies will wander, going about activities as its species would. Each type of enemy has its own AI, and acts differently. Green Lizards are fairly dense, mindlessly chasing after prey, Pole Plants will lay dormant, awaiting foolish players, [spoiler] and the passive Void Worm will intently observe the Slugcat as it descends into the Void Sea. [/spoiler]


As the name of the game suggests, there is rain, and it is [i] deadly [/i]. each cycle's length is represented by a random number of small dots around your karma level (hold your map button to view). each dot represents 30 seconds, and once all of the dots disappear, the deadly rain comes, crushing you, should you not make it to a shelter. Survive a cycle and you'll be rewarded with a raise in your karma, allowing you to travel to different regions

Master the movements mechanics, learn how your enemies act, and continue to survive, and you will beat the game in no time.

-- May contain spoilers

Perfect summary: "Despite all my rage"

This game gave me Ever hood vibes in terms of how its story works, which I won't explain here, in terms of game play the premise is simple and straightforward after 1-2 runs. You don't need to explore if you know where to go, saving you tons of time.

The game is difficult, primarily due to everything being able to instantly stun / kill you (with the former usually leading to your death anyway) and the fact that you as the player are essentially throwing needles at monsters. It does sell off the point on the positioning of the slug cats in the system though, with wit acting as their main advantage over other creatures. I found myself annoyed at a lot of situations, especially the white lizards. Though, I was more of a person that flees rather than attacked. The game is slightly easier if you face some foes head on rather than run.

I recall seeing a you tuber play this game a year or two ago, Saw the game but didn't put much notice to it, But it's picked up traction ever since its DLC which likely means that it has a very positive reception, DLC reviews would likely be kept on the DLC page though.

Anyway, the gameplay is "unique," It's not something i've played before mechanic wise but it feels familar in a way, the enemies are varied and actually dangerous, forcing the player to employ specific tactics for each species. Some of them being outright unsettling (pole plant, monster weed, all of the spider enemies) and others are... things you wish never existed.

This initially felt like a rage game especially during the farm array and the higher areas of the game. but despite all that I still employed effort throughout the game in favour of curiousity, the main driving force of the game i'd say. If the game play is dis-interesting then curiosity is the only thing that keeps most people playing, which is fine. and it's even done well. the game gives you a silent introduction, and the game remains silent after that. Nobody will talk or say anything of worth excluding 2 NPCs which are far away from one-another and are also optional too. with this, the player is given nothing; with the whole unknown to explore, allowing them to pick up more information depending on how interested they are. 

The only question the game focuses on is "when" since all the characters have their own "set times" in which the world changes depending on who you play as. This makes the world feel alive.

I'd recommend the game to anyone who's looking for a little challenge and prefers a silent game. Similar to elden ring and other rage-esq games that farm off the rage of its players intentionally, the game can be very difficult especially for some rooms and classes, but this is all for the greater message; and its a good challenge that relies on knowledge, wit and sometimes just chance, just how a real life wild encounter would be. The prey must use wit against the brute of their predators. So despite all my rage, I still would consider the experience enjoyable. Rage doesn't always equal an issue with the game. The only real gripe I have is how the lack of proper communication was between the player and rain deer, a complaint that seems to be a common one by looking through feeds of other player experiences


Everhood, I initally disliked how it ended and felt like all my efforts were for nothing, but as I thought about it, it began to shine upon some curiousities that many people have and resolve everything with a simple statement;

"Don't overthink it, You live in a shadow to soon envelop the light, it's your choice in whether you wish to dig deeper or cease."

This game gave me a similar message, though on a more confusing scale.

Also you play as slug cats, who doesn't want that?

Edit: This game also has a workshop featuring more classes, maps (i think) and more stuff. So there is definately replay value added on top of the game's already varied replay value

Welcome to Rain World, a game where you pop your head out of a shelter only to find a colony of scavengers reddy to kill you. Despite the annoyances of glitchy characters (do to how they are made) and RNG killing you just because it felt like it, its a good game. Grate worldbuilding, cryptic lore, and interesting environment. I have always loved ruins and the fact that the ground is man made and everything elts is not man made is cool. It makes the world feel different from the standard man made world on top of a natural one. It takes something you take for granted and almost literally flips it on its head. The creatures you have to fight against and yourself included are all unique. As unique as 2 colonies of yellow lizards (6 in total) geng busting you at a choak point just because they thought you looked delicious despite the fact that theres not enough of you to go around. I would definitely suggest going in blind for the most part. Its hard to describe why I like in to much.

Warning: Farm Arrays is particularly annoying because it is pretty reliant on the AI that just so happen to be a bit buggy at times.

This game is really beautiful. The world it places you in, the animation, the atmosphere, its all very melancholic with tons of charm.

But I really do NOT recommend this game.

It has no respect for your time. Enemy and item placements are randomized on every death, meaning that countless attempts  to save points are spent dying to unfair enemy placements/interactions until luck is suddenly on your side. 

I understand that this game wants you to feel small and powerless in this ecosystem, but unfair, unpredictable, and inconsistent gameplay is not the way to do so. In the end the game just makes you feel frustrated at uncontrollable RNG that, sure, reflects the oppressiveness of the ecosystem, but that could be achieved in much more thoughtful ways.

Rain World is ABRASIVE. It is frustrating and unfair and expects you to deal with it for hours on end. There is a lot to enjoy here, but its honestly not worth the struggle. You're better off watching YouTube videos talking about the lore and ecosystem instead.

I really, really want to like this game. The concept, sound design, and visual design are excellent. The gameplay itself, though, is the embodiment of anti-catharsis. My accomplishments feel like they're accidents from good RNG, the karma system punishes any form of experimentation, and the game leaves you no explanation of what you can or should do. Did you know you can struggle when a lizard bites you, and survive? I didn't because there was never any indication I could. This game feels like it's already expected me to have read the wiki for literally anything more than the button configuration.

A breathtaking dystopia with punishing difficulty and tricky physics-based movement and combat.

Those are great, but what makes this game special for me aren't just those things. For one, the theme of reincarnation is generally under-explored -- not only by games (surprising, considering how almost every game's fail state is death and the very next moment is you being alive again) but also by media in general. Reincarnation is a wonderful theme that lets allows us to think about some of the grand, difficult questions. What do we value once survival is out of the equation? Of course, in the real world, every living creature dies, so survival isn't really out of the equation. Does that change our answer? Regardless, what do we make of the inexorability of real, permanent death? These questions linger in the air -- the weighty backdrop of every screen in Rain World. The game, elegantly, doesn't need to lean on telling you this through text. On your journey, the omnipresent pixel-art decay around you hammers these themes home; there used to be civilization here, and now there is not. At your destination, you've made a choice.

The game's themes of reincarnation, I suppose because their origins in eastern philosophy, come packaged with ecological themes -- this world will happy exist without you. In one the best display of this that I've ever seen in a video game, creatures will treat you (and each other) with varying (and rational) degrees of hostility. Creatures will fight each other. You're not the only creature near the bottom of the food chain in this world and you can occasionally see another creature become prey. The fact that all of this is systems-driven, not scripted, is wonderful.

I'm convinced Rain World is a beautiful thing. I just wish younger me believed in himself enough to git gud instead of watching the endings on YouTube.

Rain World is hard. You need to learn how to move almost from scratch cause the movement here is unique and has a lot of hidden elements that you can not even notice in your first playthough.
Not only a movement is unique, the graphics, the animations, the most complex ecosystem i've ever seen.

At first you'll be most likely feel defenseless, a prey in the world of predators but as you surviving you learn how to protect yourself, learn things about the local ecosystem, differences between species and more so on.
I can talk about Rain World for hours. It already has so much to offer you in the base game but there's the DLC that gives you twice as more, not even speaking of the community mods.
In conclusion if you like it you'll probably spend a significant amount of time in it.

for all the people like me who suck at platforming, there's an "easy mode" that makes it still challenging but much more doable. Yes, I recommend it with some of the remix settings enabled. Does the game contain frustrating and unfair deaths that sometimes make you feel like you are playing a poorly designed game? It does. But somehow I still had an incredible time playing it and couldn't stop thinking about the game no matter what I was doing during my days. Maybe it's that I always felt like I was actually growing as a person while playing it. Just the fact that almost every area is worse than the previous one, or horrible in some new way I didn't know I hated, but that I somehow still always found a way to keep trying and keep going and overcoming all that the game threw at me... That meant something. I feel like I have gotten a new, fundamental understanding for what it means to obsess over how things would be better if something was different: Sometimes they are of course, but there will always be challenges in life, ideally you just choose which ones you like facing best. And that's a good thing; I had fun returning to this torturous game, even when I was scared. It gives you purpose and enables growth. I think the goal is to grow comfortable with your own personal challenge, understand that failure is never the end of things and to become present and at home in your struggles. Embrace them, they are your journey. They are your purpose.

This game is... difficult to unpack without giving away some of the magic but i'll do my best. Simply put there truly is no experience quite like this.

This isn't really a game about you or the character you are playing. You're really just a member of this strange, beautiful, scary, unforgiving, living, breathing world. 

There are mysteries to discover and wondrous places to see, as well as horrors and hardship. Through all of that you learn to understand better with each passing moment. It's often said this game requires you to learn how to walk again with its less than initially intuitive controls and mechanics. If you stick with it however, you'll see a beautiful world and mesmerizing secrets to unravel within. 

Truly a unique experience and cant recommend it enough.

I tried really, really hard to like this game, but just ended up frustrated. I don't like platformers. Shame, because the world looks fascinating and I wanted to experience it organically. Guess I'll just have to watch lore videos or something, and maybe I'll give it another shot some day.

I thought I loved this game then the DLC came out. The DLC takes the already deep lore and story, and cranks it up to 11. There's so much to know, so many secrets, the world feels so real and alive for a reason. The animation in this game is like no other I've ever seen. Creatures AI use the limits of their body to explore the world. While a normal game has a basic "walk forward animation" that plays while something moves in the forward direction, Rain World first has the something reach out with it's leg, and if it can contact a surface, then it's allowed to move. The AI knows this and specifically looks to use the environment just as a player would, just as a real creature would... This is one of those games that is like no other, and no other will be like it. A very difficult game, but a must try regardless.

If you are looking for something relaxing and straightforward this IS NOT the game for you. I saw the cute adventure style and the challenge and the relation to games like: Hollow Knight and though, "that sounds great, I love slugs and cats."

Behold: an incredible game that is really really good; however, like most of the negative reviews, I must concur that this game is both confusing and stressful. If you like exhilarating chase games with a timer and puzzles, go for it. It will give you a great time. If you struggle with understanding archaic progress mechanics, ingame direction hints, and/or enemies that are infinitely more powerful than the Player, do not buy this.

I hope others risk a biscuit on this game, but keep a timer up to know when you hit 3 hours, because that's when you need to decide if playing another 60 hours, or 120, or 500 (for each of the DLC characters combined) is really worth your time and money.

I really wow'd at a lot in just 3 hours, I'm sure it would have continued to amaze me, but I can't continue for the sake of my sanity.

At one point, I was more towards the don't recommend end of the spectrum for this game, but I think I do actually recommend it. It's a very interesting world to explore and it has been fun to pick up now and then to play through some cycles. The music while sparse is very on point and always adds to the atmosphere of the region. The regions themselves are very well thought out, so much visual storytelling going on. And I think the rain mechanic is particularly impressive and conveys so much raw power through such simple visual tricks.

So, exploring is fun. But don't get me wrong. The combat in this game is hot garbage and I'm glad I played on Monk first because I don't think I would've put up with it on Survivor (I did manage to go back and complete Survivor after completing two Monk campaigns). Enemies are fun to watch going about their habitat from a distance, but so much close encounters end up being, "Whelp, I'm dead." And progressing through regions on Survivor mode basically involves a bunch of sheer dumb luck with enemy placements. A well simulated ecosystem where you are one of the weakest organisms does not make a fun game experience. 

Also, I'm not sure how to get into a practical demonstration of how the game falls totally flat on guiding you on what to do next and explaining the lore in ways that visual storytelling could not achieve without spoiling anything. But let's just say, after playing for a few hours I had to consult the wiki to find out what was even going on and I have no doubt you will be consulting it, too. And the ending of the game is such a pretentious slog where the developers find it in themselves to effectively waste around 10-20 minutes of your time for what ends up feeling like, "Errr...okay? That's it? You couldn't have communicated this ending any faster?" 

But combat and certain aspects of storytelling being absolutely terrible, I did play through it three different times and I do find it enjoyable when I'm not dealing with the poor combat aspects so I recommend it as long as you know what you are getting into.

Simply put, Rain World is not just a game, its a masterpiece. 
This game features an extremely dynamic and robust ecosystem of a large variety of creatures, where the player also fits in.
In Rain World, there are no enemies, because what you would normally classify as enemies in other videogames, are actually simply creatures just like you, who simply want to feed themselves.
This game is truly one of a kind and its my favorite game, and I cant wait for future updates!

This game is incredible it strips you down to the basics giving you no real upgrades or special abilities making you have to understand all of the core mechanics, like the insane movement (something I've really not seen done right in any other video game) paired with the amazing art, enemies and world building I would definitely consider this game to be in my top 3. In short, this game is the only game I think does survival right.

[h1]Unique Concept and Design[/h1]

Very interesting game concept! The world around you feels very organic and natural, the visuals are nice, despite not supporting super resolutions (it can get a bit blurry), but it's overall a pleasing experience.

The game can be rather hard at times and a bit confusing to navigate, but it's intuitive on its own, and the possibilities of free choice are wonderful.

Unrelated to the game itself, their Discord server is rather chaotic and badly moderated, so I'd stay away from that one.

This is more than a game, it is a full on experience. I don't think I've ever been so immersed in a videogame before. If you've never played this game, don't look up any guides or get advice. One of the biggest parts of this game is exploration. This game tells you basically nothing except for what the controls do and giving hints to any player that notices. That sense of discovery that you can get around every corner is amazing. This is also one of the most beautiful games I've ever played. It's not just the visuals that make the game so beautiful though. The soundtrack and the AI driven animations really make the entire world feel incredibly organic and realistic. despite having so many games, i rarely ever leave reviews for any of them. in fact this is only the second review i have ever done for a steam game, so you will have to forgive me if the review seems messy, unpolished, or grammatically incorrect.

I rarely ever play hard games because they tend to be hard because of sharp difficulty spikes and my lack of patience. that being said i LOVE this game, despite having difficulty spikes because the difficulty spikes are usually self imposed, and if it's to hard in one area you can pull through and stick to your current route or go another way around. there have been plenty of times in both the base game and the dlc where i got stuck just to realize that, yes you can distract predators and get away with just enough time to spare to reach a save point, or that there was a hidden path right next to me that completely avoids the thing that just killed me 50 times in a row without fail. i will say there is a story to the game and it's actually kind of hidden out of the way with you only getting a very small portion of it if you don't go out of your way to get it, and i should throw in a warning for people with the base game, if you care about lore DON'T loose or trade any colored pearls as they will NOT re-spawn unless you change that in the settings. despite how hard the game is i some how found myself playing hard mode and beating it. the Only other hard game I've loved as much as this in terms of combat and story is hollow knight.

if you want to play, I highly recommend you play it as blindly as possible for all 3 (or 8-9 with dlc) characters for the biggest impact, but if you have been spoiled like i was, don't worry you'll still love it despite the spoilers as there's so much more to the game than whats on the surface.

Rain World is a game of wits. A game of patience. A game of happenstance, where your well-being isn't just as meaningless as everything else's, it's LESS meaningless. Yet, the humble slugcat dares not to give up, as the world without rain is a beautiful one.

It's difficult to be motivated at the start, when there isn't much to lose and the objective is unclear... but after the first area, this game's deceptively simple systems blossom into a rare dance to the gorgeous environment of old.

An incredibly memorable game, one that perhaps doesn't want to be played.

This isn't the first time I've reviewed Rain World, but here I am again. This time, with more experience, I intend to go into greater detail than I have prior.

TLDR AT BOTTOM OF REVIEW, FEEL FREE TO SKIP TO THAT.

Rain world is a visually spectacular game with a deep, rich story and a beautiful world full of colorful and diverse creatures. These creatures are both to its benefit, and its downfall. For a player who has an immense amount of experience, the game quickly becomes "mostly" manageable. (I'll get more into why "mostly" has quotations later.) A new player will find themselves dying over and over and over again with seemingly little to no control over their own fate or outcomes. This is not a good first impression for anyone who seeks to play this game for any extended period, you don't want to give your player a horrible time or they may never come back. With initially awkward controls that are somewhat untraditional for a 2D platformer (not referring to button layout, moreso the controls overall) this will leave many players (myself included) with a sour taste in their mouth. This is the type of game to tell you almost nothing, and expect you to figure things out on your own. For some players, this is great! For players who either lack the time or patience to learn and get over the skill curve, this can quickly lead to refunding the game, or growing so frustrated they never play it again. I initially played when I was much younger, only returning due to my friend asking me to play it again. I had the typical beginner experience, many many deaths and wandering about aimlessly having no idea where I'm supposed to go.

And that's another problem- your only guide, the yellow overseer, can die. If it either dies or you don't realize its signals, you will wander aimlessly having no idea where your intended route is. Furthering this, even once you reach your destination, that's the end of your guidance. You're set loose with no help from the overseer, and magically expected to find your next destination on your own. It's not realistic to expect the player to find 5P without guidance, let alone wander aimlessly for hours. You essentially are required to use a guide and/or map if you are a brand new player, not only because of your extremely unclear objective, but because there is SO MUCH the game doesn't tell you.

A few examples of such mechanics the game says nothing about: slide spearing, rocks cause lizards to flip, vulture masks scare lizards, backflips, slides, slide pounces, rolling, roll chains, deer covet spore puffs, scavengers have a reputation system, lizards have a reputation system and can be tamed, the list goes on and on and on. Some of these you could naturally encounter just via playing the game normally, but some are extremely unrealistic to ever determine on your own. That's why it's so crucial to play with a guide, but that shouldn't ever be necessary.

Onto randomness. The AI in this game does exactly what it intends to do- simulate an ecosystem where every creature has its own thought processes and functions independently of one another, autonomous in behavior and seems almost "realistic." While this is extremely successful in its intent, this leaves a somewhat sour player experience given that the player exists at the bottom of said ecosystem, hunted by almost every creature in the game. This is why the new player experience is so punishing- literally everything is out to kill you. Even an experienced player can't win every situation, sometimes you are just guaranteed to die. Yet, despite this, nothing is consistent. Creatures can take any path they want on any given cycle, enemy spawns aren't even the same every cycle, nor are spear/rock spawns, etc. Everything is random and you could literally take the same path twice and encounter no enemies, then almost every single enemy in the region (and predictably, end up dying or being forced to retreat and finding an alternate route.) There are so many deaths that are entirely unpreventable. Scavenger spearing you from 3 screens away, KV coming out of nowhere and spearing you in about ~10 frames, a leviathan deciding to spawn when you thought you were safe, dropwigs camping the beginning of a screen, ANYTHING camping the beginning of a screen, etc etc etc. It's these kinds of deaths that even today, still plague me despite being a significantly more experienced player now. Given that these deaths are almost impossible to prevent, now apply that to a new player and imagine how frequently a new player will die given the simple unfairness of the game. This is by design, of course, you are the bottom of the food chain. I just don't agree that a player should be so helpless without dozens of hours in the game or watching countless guides just to become competent.

I've talked a lot of trash about the game, and I could go on, but I'll refrain for now. I want to address the positives.

I don't even know where to start, really. I love this game as much as I hate it. The story is so compelling and interesting, there's so much to dig into. This game is an absolute masterpiece in environmental storytelling, you can see the world decay around you between every campaign. Every individual character has their own unique endings and story, the creatures have so many unique and intriguing abilities that are fun to interact with if you're good enough to know how to play against them, there's just so much to love. Every room looks stunning and fulfills a purpose in its environment, the music is beautiful and atmospheric, slugcats are just so adorable, there's so much dialogue to uncover between 5P and Moon, I could gush about this game for hours and hours. With how vague the story is, there's much room for headcanons and personal beliefs, making every player's experience special. Personality modifiers ensure no two creatures are ever the same, and function similarly yet have individual preferences. Slugpups are both extremely burdensome, yet so cute that you want to take care of them anyway. Artificer is my favorite, her story is profound and her abilities are likely the most enjoyable thing in the entire game. That said, I'll leave my review here and create a TLDR:

Summary: Play Rain World if you have the time to invest to become a good player and research the game. It is generally unwise to attempt to play this game totally blind, you are better off reading guides or watching videos on where to go in the effort of saving time and not wandering about aimlessly, dying repeatedly to achieve nothing. This game will try your patience, you will hit your desk, you will probably yell at your screen. The game isn't fair, it doesn't want to be, but if you have the patience to take back control (as best you can) and put it in its place, then you can (mostly) do that. I truly love this game, but I cannot recommend it to someone unless they have both an unwavering sense of patience (due to the unfairness, and randomness of the game) and a great deal of time to invest to both uncover the story and become a better player.

there are many things in rain world you have to find out yourself. one of those things, which you can only find on the internet, is that there is, in fact, a 'wrong way' to go...and it's very, very easy to go that way, and the game will let you keep going that way for as long as you like. 60 hours (and 283 successful cycles) later, i finished, disappointed.

with this hands-off approach, rain world allows a rewarding process of discovery...at first. Early in the game, I enjoyed learning the mechanics and unpacking the intricacies of the environment. Twenty hours in, however, the joy of discovery was long faded, replaced by boredom, frustration, and growing apathy. I kept feeling that I wasn't doing what the game wanted me to do - and I kept being right. when the advice for someone in the same situation to me is 'restart the game', there is a problem.

learning I had wasted several hours barking up the wrong tree entirely ruined my desire to experiment. on top of this, i managed to approach every in-game moment from the wrong direction, despite my best intentions, meaning when I eventually found the 'right' direction, all impact and tension was lost. getting things right might be rewarding for those for whom 'getting good' is its own reward, but getting things wrong is so punishing in terms of time and wasted effort, that I lost interest. I stopped having any sense of 'succeeding' - only 'failing to fail'. I googled for help, and got on the right track - but the damage was already done, and the game wasn't out of 'wrong directions' to blunder my way into. as my playtime passed thirty hours, then forty, then fifty, I became exhausted, and impatient for the game to end, and I wasn't able to enjoy the exploration I found.

as a result, my overall experience of rain world was miserable. rain world has a 'right direction' and a 'wrong direction' - which is a fatal flaw in a game about unguided exploration. rain world is a game best played with a veteran friend on-call or an internet tab open, to guide you away from the wrong direction. save yourself. look up a guide.

Rain world was an incredibly fun experience (mostly)! The exploration, the (limited) combat, the discovery, and the platforming were all incredibly satisfying! It felt amazing killing a blue lizard, outmaneurvering a white lizard with its own tongue, flying over orange lizards with a squidcada, and meeting a certain calculator! However, some sections were super annoying (LOOKING AT YOU MEMORY CRYPTS AND THE LEG AND THE RAINDEER) and were kind of frustrating. Epic game, will play more! 8.5/10

DO NOT ANGER THE SCAVENGERS DO NOT ANGER THE SCAVENGERS DO NOT ANGER THE WHITE LIZARDS DO NOT ANGER THE WHITE LIZARDS, but yeah jokes aside this is an amazing game. got the game 3 days ago, haven't played it today (when im writing this review) and I've sunk 10 hours into it already. I've played many games before that i mastered, but this game? im 10 hours in and still in the second area, and im loving and hating it and thats why this game is great. 

Controls: very standard controls, easy to remember but hard to actually use to their full potential, and by that i mean its hard to know every single sort of moment tech with just those few controls, it takes a while to figure them out and use them properly.

Difficulty: its rain world what do you expect? game is almost impossible to new players, and the reason critics don't like the game and say its bad is because they haven't beaten it lol

Map: i dont know theres a lot of areas, one areas called sky islands i believe and i explored all of it in like 3 hours, and it isnt very large so..... yeah.... big map!

Fun: the game really helps you see what its like to play a game like a Slugcat (scug) or basically any animal in a world it doesn't understand, you have no knowledge of it till you explore. there's almost no hints besides the little yellow robot (forgot his name) that helps you and the occasional tip screen, it throws you into a bleak dystopian of a world, really helping you know what its like for the slugcat. the trial and error part is great because once you get past the trial after 500 errors it feels amazing. oh, and watch out for the fake poles, they're not funny.

Story: The story is actually surprisingly good and quite easy to understand through just pictures, and explaining your backstory, but your main goal is to "Ascend" and get to beat the game by doing this. you'll know you're there when the screen starts being very very very very (you get the idea) very very wavy, or y'know you can just watch the world record speedrun on YouTube....

Overall: this game is amazing and stupendous, as well as heavily underrated. i recommend getting this game heavily as it takes a lot of time and if you need a new game to master, this is it. definitely not for the people prone to raging as uh.... the green lizards when you find them will kill you many... many... many times over. oh and we cant forget the worm grass! im not gonna try to spoil all the animals and storyline, instead of gonna be like Rain World and just give an overview and not explain things very well, so your intrigued to buy the game and figure it out.

This game is just incredible. It's definitely not for everyone though.
If you're willing to fail a lot... I said A LOT, and you have the time to do so, then continue reading.

This game is a simulated ecosystem, where you play as a rodent (commonly referred to by the community as a slugcat (or scug)) in the lower portion of the food web. You are not very important, and have limited abilities when it comes to fighting and movement. The beauty of this game comes in the form of its creature AI, which captures the primal stupidity of real biological creatures such as humans pretty well. The different creatures of this world are (almost) all very deep, and lucky for you, the game doesn't tell you any of it! You're left to figure everything out, which is one of the best and worst things about this game (but, not one of the worst in a bad way. I can't bother to explain too much because I wanna play it!). There's no issue about lengthy dialogue, cutscenes, and the like (not saying there's none of any of these, but none of it is a negative experience while playing the game. You'll have to figure out which of these is in the game).

The game has its issues, but I don't think they take away from the experience if you end up sticking with the game (which is one of the issues: you need to play the game and get decent at the unique bass mechanics before you start getting obsessive joy from it).
That's all. I could go on about the great things stored within, but not only would that spoil you, but it'd keep me from playing the game for more time than I have been resisting already by writing this review.

So, I will try and keep this as spoiler free as possible, but read at your own discretion. 
Rain World is frustrating, agonizing, and sometimes, completely full of BS. You will often be left screaming at your screen, wondering how you were killed by something that wasn't even the frame yet. You will panic and cry out in pain, frustrated that you were just one second away from finding and entering a checkpoint. I know this is the case, because this was me. For my first few playthroughs, I contemplated giving up. The utter frustration at knowing that you on the near bottom of the food chain was almost too much. Despite this, I continued, because despite being angry and upset, I couldn't put the game down. Rain World feels like a game that can only really be enjoyed a second time through, completing the game. I am now a lot more confident in my gaming abilities because I now know what I am doing. Despite this, I do have some criticisms (SPOILERS)
Raindeer: The Raindeer is a deer which is required to beat the game. However, you have little to no way to control it, despite getting a spore-puff thing to control it. Honestly, it's the only part of the game that I actively dislike. 
Softlocking: Rain World measures progression through Karma Gates. Essentially, you have to survive each cycle to boost and maintain your Karma. This is then used to enter sealed gates. Here's the problem. There are certain areas where you will continuously die, and you will try to leave to go back and replenish your Karma, only to realize that you are locked in this difficult area with no way to leave. Sure, you can continue onward and brave the onslaught of tough creatures, but often times, you end up in a cycle. Another instance of soft-locking comes in the far east end of drainage. It's a one way jump, and jumping back will place you in one of the most difficult swimming areas in the entire game. Combine that will a-hole leeches, and it quickly wears you down. Even more experienced players I've seen online get frustrated with the leeches. 
Rain World is not easy, and you will be frustrated. I am glad I stuck with it, however, I can completely understand why others would not.

I fell in love with game during my first play through! I played monk for my first run through the hostile world this game revolves around, and despite the lower aggression of enemies, longer cycles, and easier region requirements, every shelter I reached felt like a massive milestone. In the beginning, the base controls are clunky and unpleasant to use, making exploration a slog, and every action something you have to think about for a solid second or two, which in most cases, will mean you've died before you can effectively react. ITS NOT A BUG, ITS A FEATURE!!!!!!! You're SUPPOSED to struggle. You're supposed to get frustrated and unreasonably angry! This game isn't fair but neither is nature. You learn to move and effectively defend yourself, along side your little character! The world is a simulation of nature, life around you goes on, it doesn't care about you or your story, the creatures are all just trying to survive like you are. After all my stumbling, falling, being eaten, drowned, electrocuted, and carried off, I found myself passing by shelters I'd normal dive into, finding more than enough to make friends with creatures that previously pestered me to no ends, and even traversing along side the beasts that would have gladly eaten me for dinner. This is a game of exploration, frustration, accomplishment, sadness, wonder, survival, and determination. I vividly remember how much I struggled, and I'm proud of how far Iv'e come. I seriously recommend giving RainWorld a shot, its unlike anything you've ever played before!

Many people might think this game is unfair, that lots of deaths are unavoidable. But most of the time that's not the case, and there was some decision that would have allowed you to survive. A lot of skill in rain world is about smart preemptive decision making, and if you analyze your deaths for what you can improve on, you can learn the game.

Something I love about this game is that lots of interactions and the lore are more realistic than you would expect of a game. It really feels like this is a real world.

For most people, I would recommend playing with the rain world remix sort of built in mod, and the tips system enabled. It teaches you a lot of the fundamentals one at a time as you play, but even with that you still need to be compassionate and observant in order to have a smooth experience, and that's part of the appeal of the game.

Basically, this game isn't for everyone, but if you're looking for a game that challenges you to master its tricks rather than just stumbling through, I highly recommend it.

This is an edit of a previously very simple review. I want to preface this by saying that I rarely put the effort or braincells into writing a gramatically and structurally cohesive review like this. This game, however, has had so much heart and soul poured into it that I would feel terrible knowing that I did not fully articulate my thoughts about it. 

Rain World is everything I've ever wanted in a video game's graphics. Wonderful pixel-art, interesting creature designs that produce visually distinct and unique animals, even in the same species. Breathtaking vistas and graphical fidelity in even the smallest of details. Everything in Rain World's visuals comes toghether to create a cohesive and immersive whole. There is nothing that I would criticize in this aspect.

The AI of the creatures that inhabit Rain World's many regions is complex, but logical. While it has its quirks, you can expect the animals to act just like an animal would. Predators will hunt prey and prey will run from them. Neutral creatures will wander around, and more complex beings will react to how you treat them. When approached as a video game enemy or an obstacle, these creatures become utterly unpredictable and impossible to defeat or sneak by. When approached as wild animals, their behavior is absolutely logical and the player can distract or defeat them in a myriad of ways. 

The controls are obtuse, unintuitive and take a long time to learn. Would I criticize this, then? Absolutely not. The immense satisfaction you get from chaining toghether advanced movement is fully worth the time invested into learning the ins and outs of this game's control system. They open up a lot of different and innovative ways to traverse the environment and evade predators.

Items are similiar to the movement system: completely unexplained by the game. You are shown food, and told to eat it. That is one item. There are many more, and upon encountering them you are simply told to "experiment". And that is exactly what I did. The process of discovery is satisfying and fun. Items rarely have immediately apparent uses. Again, there is nothing I would criticize.

Rain World has no conventional systems for progress. Death is not an obstacle, but a certainty that will occur sooner or later. Death however, has little bearing on the actual gameplay. The player character has no levels, no skills to learn, no upgrades. While I often see this game described as a metroidvania, it is anything but. The progression through the game's regions is completely nonlinear and the player can choose to wander into any of them in any order and at any time they please. Their progress is limited only by their skill and knowledge of each area. Rain World does not punish the player for dying, as each time a death occurs the player is simply sent back a "karma level". These are needed to open gates to regions, but karma can be gained as quickly as it is lost. The rain itself is an ever-looming threat, but with planning and thought out routes, a player can complete the entire game without seeing the rain once. As the player learns and improves at the game, so does the main protagonist. The slugcat is not so much a player-controlled creature as it is an extension of the player, bearing all of their imperfections, but also all of their skills.

Now, for the story. I have never, in my many years of playing video games, found a piece of art that spoke to me on the same level as Rain World's story did. The little dialogue you are given is very well written, and conveys an incredibly powerful message. I cannot state the importance this message has had on me as a person, it is beautiful, thought-provoking, and effective. The narrative is tied directly into the world itself, and even the game's title is part of it. Everything, again, forms a cohesive whole, and again, I have no criticism towards any part of it.

Rain World is not a game, but rather an experience. I know this very statement gets thrown around a lot in the industry, but I fully mean it. Nothing I experienced while playing a video game has come close. Not to say the artistry in the works that are often brought up in the "games as an artform" argument is invalid or ineffective, Rain World simply offers a fusion of both art and interactive media, delivers on what it sets out to do, and what is most important in a video game: it's just fun to mess around in.

Is it for everyone? No. Will every player get the same level of enjoyment I get out of playing Rain World? Also no. But if you are a person willing to spend time and effort learning something new, using the knowledge you learned and then willing to wait for your reward, then I wholeheartedly recommend Rain World.

I usually hate survival games, but Rain World manages to stand out from the rest and be an incredible experience. This is definitely one of my favorite games of all time, and I'm doubtful anything similar will ever top it. If you're thinking about getting this game, note that the Downpour DLC is a must-have; the base game is great, but the DLC has more content than the game itself and is what makes it so phenomenal.

PROS:

Simplicity - Unlike most survival games, there's no inventory or crafting system. What you're carrying in your two hands is what you get. The only thing you have to manage is eating enough food between rain cycles so that you can hibernate. There's a lot of versatility and subtlety in using the items you collect, which you gradually pick up on as you play.

Enemy Design - The best thing about the game is the complex ecosystem, where enemies interact with the player and with each-other in simple yet complicated and unpredictable ways. Even the basic lizard enemy that you first encounter has a lot of depth to it's behavior; it will chase you, sure, but will often get distracted fighting with other lizards, giving you a much easier time sneaking by. There's too much to talk about here, but enemy AI has never been better in any other game.

Music - The music of Rain World is fantastic.

Story-Telling - Rain World has a unique and compelling plot, and does a better job with atmospheric story-telling than any other game I've played. This is increased a hundredfold by the Downpour DLC. 

Exploration - The Rain World map is absolutely gigantic; even after 80 hours of playing, there's still an entire area I've left practically unexplored.

CONS:

Difficulty - Rain World leaves the player to stumble around in the dark. Learning how to deal with all the hostile creatures takes a lot of patience, and dying can be extremely punishing. This isn't a bad thing for me personally, but I don't think this game is for everyone.

No Direction - Rain World gives the player very little instruction on where to go or how to progress, and you can spend hours exploring areas without feeling like you've gotten any farther in the game. This caused me to quit the game early on, eventually coming back to it and restarting. This isn't really a bad thing either, because it makes certain moments of the game much more powerful when you finally get to them, but if you're looking for a game to give you instruction on what to do, you won't find it playing Rain World.

Some places can only be accessed with one or more spears embedded into the wall at certain parts of the route for Slugcat to climb on top. You might get gated into a bad spot, in order to avoid that, do not sleep at a shelter you don't know the area around relatively well, it's better to die and return to the previous shelter you know well enough than to hope for the best at an unknown area. There's local multiplayer campaign on DLC, different save slots, reputation system with factions, culture, crafting, I like this game a lot.

This game is one of the few that have made sick in my stomach in a good way. The sound, art style, characters, storyline, and enemies all are perfect to me. Sure there's still the occasional getting angry from having to redo a cycle again, but you learn to look out for that pole plant or dropwig that ended your run.

Rain World does an excellent job of making you feel like a part of a living, breathing ecosystem. You aren't necessarily at the top of the food chain in this world, and you certainly begin to feel that after the first twenty or so times you get eaten by something much larger than you.

This game has an rather large world to explore and a story to learn about if you look for it. Each playable character (save for Monk and Survivor mostly) are unique in their abilities and campaigns, allowing for unique experiences depending on the character you select.
There are also a handful of collectables placed around the world, giving an incentive to venture out into the far reaches of each region you come across. Finding these collectables allows you to access more items in the sandbox and arena modes the game features, where you can spawn in the various creatures and items in the game to play around with at your own pace. 
In the Downpour DLC, there are also custom-built challenges created for each playable character, along with an "Expedition" gamemode, which has you embark on short journeys in the game world while completing randomly generated challenges for points. 
All these sandbox gamemodes and the story mode itself give the game a great deal of replay value.

Something to keep in mind: Rain World is a challenging game. You will likely spend a lot of time getting lost and dying in the first few hours of gameplay as you learn of the game's systems and controls. 

If you can get past the harsh learning experience that is the first few hours, you are in for a truly special experience with a unique art style, an immersive interconnected open world, and a great soundtrack to boot. Rain World is definitely one of my favorite games of all time, and I would highly recommend giving it a try if the game seems even remotely interesting to you.

Simply put Rain World is amazing.  Rain World is not for everyone due to its difficulty and aimless first few hours, but those who persevere are well rewarded through the depth of its world building and play control to survive and thrive in an alien world long abandoned by a powerful ancient race.  In Rain World, the story is not about you, its about the remnants of life in a world long abandoned and left behind to decay, of life flourishing in every nook and cranny, in whatever strange forms they take.
Don't give up on Rain World, push past its difficulty and seemingly hostile nature, and you will find comfort in rummaging through the affairs of Passing Gods.
Survival is difficult.  You are a small fragile creature alone in their exploration of a crumbling world.  This world can be conquered, its secrets found, and its stories brought to a close.  A way out exists, it only needs to be found.
A game for gamers

I love this game. Definitely not for everyone, but if you enjoy exploring and figuring things out for yourself this is an amazing experience. The more you play the better you'll get! You will die a lot though. Some of those deaths will seem completely unfair and might make you want to punch your computer. Death is inevitable and everywhere, the fun part is figuring out how to avoid it!

I would recommend going in blind if your trying to get the full experience. Fair warning, it can take a lot of trial and error before you figure out key components of the game. This one is pretty interesting: it has a unique mechanic that allows creatures to roam around and move like they're actually realistic! never saw this feature on any game. Also it gives some creepy vibe that youre just a small animal trying to survive in a weird and hostile enviroment where anything and literally everything wants to kill you, similar to hollow knight but in hollow knight you can swing your weapon to hit anyone with bad intentions, this one NOT, you have only spears and rocks to throw against pretadors (cherrybombs too but thats endgame) basicly you are totally vulnerable without these, relying only at your skill at the game.
At first sight i felt like exploring some vast and misterious ambient just like hollow knight, but this one was different, i got lost often and just decided to wander around and ended restarting the game because i got to a point where i thought i couldn't return (that totally ruined my experience) but eventually i did finished it. My thoughts at the ending was a mix of amazement,happiness and total confusion (im talking about void sea trippy effect). After some time playing the game i really wanted to criticize it heavily because of the difficulty but its art and kinda charismatic protagonist(even tho i rage at him alot because of his lack of coordination) makes me reconsider it, BUT you will agree with me that seeing something precious that could easily be your pet getting bitten by a dropping from the sky cyan lizard or being shot by a king vulture in 2 seconds after it appears actually is enough to damage your sanity and well being.
The music is pretty much a alarming sense that tells you if you are in danger or not, even tho some sounds are awesome like floes and bio engineering for example.
The artwork is like hollow knight style but some backgrounds are even delightful to see, and it looks almost real.
Lore is scattered in pearls so you have to find them and bring to a robot at the edge of the world, pretty much okey but hollow knight lore is way better.
Gameplay is dark souls like but eventually you get over it.
Heres the only thing i didnt like in this game, Hunter mode.
I understand you want to challenge players but this is total insanity, You have around 20 cycles to do 2 quests that take you very far(not required to win) and remember that everything wants to kill survivor? this time nature itself found a way of producing mass weapons of destruction to go after you while you struggle to catch 30 seconds of peace. I really like Rain World. The game is difficult and unforgiving, but I quickly got used to it and enjoyed it.Would recommend it. 


Either way there are still some situations where deaths can be really unfair. As an example, some rooms are divided into multiple screens because of their size, and to switch screens you have to go close to the edge of one screen. The predator AI is constantly working, even off-screen, and sometimes it can happen that enemies attack you from another screen when near the edge of a screen, which will most likely result in your death. Adding camera scrolling would fix that issue.


But if you have trouble, you can also play as the Monk (basically easy mode). But dying is part of the game, and I completed my first run as the Survivor. 


The predator AI is really well made. They can make mistakes just like the player and predict where the player could go once they move out of their sight.
And scavengers have by far the best AI in the game, they can communicate with gestures and show emotions like fear. They have their own reputation system with the player. They even have different personalities. 


The art style of the game looks beautiful. The lore is interesting and creative. I really liked it. I also really liked the soundtrack. Every area (except subareas) gets its own Threat Song, which makes each area even more unique. And they even have multiple layers that increase when the threat increases. But the atmospheric songs are amazing as well.


If you don't like difficult games, you shouldn't play Rain World because you will die a lot.


10/10

Also, try the amazing co-op mode!

Behold the game which will abuse you over and over again like a toxic partner, will make you repeatedly question your own existence, and yet still remain one of the greatest masterpieces you will ever have played.

Feels like you are actually a ferret, and I love that so much! The way you move is so realistic, despite being a fictional slugcat. The ecosystem is so natural and intriguing, with surprises everywhere. The creatures move according to the rules of nature, and rarely, but still, even so, you can actually escape from them. Even if caught, if you struggle correctly, you can escape, and I love that realism as a prey animal in this game. You can even get predators to chase after you, goading them by getting up in their space or positioning yourself in an easy to escape position (more or less... I've failed on more than one occasion). Why would you want predators to chase you if they are already after you? Well sometimes, like many predators, they don't actually want to eat you just yet, but well, there is a big ambush predator in your way, and you don't want to be the one eaten. So lure that predator in, and have them fight. Let's you and him fight. There are multiple ways to achieve objectives, and you can even set up long-term plans. And don't even get me started on the absolutely wonderful mechanic of the rainstorms. 
I genuinely, completely seriously, wholly and fully say this game gives me a reason to live life.

I understand this game isn't for everyone. However, this game is extremely fun if you just spend some time on it. I've seen negative reviews on this game saying that the enemies aren't staying on path and they are always somewhere different or maybe the controls are bad and who could possibly forget THIS GAME TELLS YOU NOTHING. All of this is true but, I think if you checked what you were getting into and you knew the goal of the game then it wouldn't be so bad. If you don't know this game is a game that simulates a living ecosystem in a dying world. You are not important because you are only a part of this ecosystem. This is why the creatures of Rain World can move even off screen and do (almost) whatever they want. This game also gives them the ability to control their own movements with procedural animation. Basically it makes them control their limbs and make the limbs move however they want so, that it pushes itself from point A to point B. This makes it even harder to predict your enemy. I'm no expert on this topic so if you want to actually know how this works watch a video about it. Your character is procedurally animated too so expect lots of cool movements based on how you move your arrow keys. The controls are difficult to get the hang of. This is because the creature you play as is learning how to live without family guidance. you will most likely get used to it and if you look back actually good at it. Once I got eaten by a blue lizard the actual easiest predator in the game. Now I killed a red lizard one of the most difficult lizard in the game. 






Finally lets talk about difficulty...



 Imagine the hardest game you have ever played
times it by 10 and then add a hint of impossible to escape moments.
Yes there is parts of the game that are not fair and unexpected, But is life fair?






In short this game is like "Hey did you think that you are not a top predator? Here lets show you what being at the bottom of the food chain really looks like and lets see if you can climb to the top just like you distant ancestors."

Great game.

Its difficulty leads you to frequently and subconsciously take moments to appreciate not being dead. During these moments, your focus broadens, and you see the world around you. Details in the cobbled stone you walk realize themselves, and the lives of all those who have ever trodden it and ever will manifest in your attention. You've worked so hard to get here-- was it worth it? Does that question even mean anything, considering here isn't anywhere special at all and an experience being worth anything is a ridiculous concept anyways?

The experience of Rain World is deeply allegorical. 

Sometimes a blow is too much, a failure too humiliating, that you make that judgement call. Its not worth it anymore. You try in vain for any glimpse of the goal that you assume is out there, but all you see is overcast skies and empty black tunnels. There is no guide, there are no rails, so for all you know the path you're treading leads nowhere at all.

Succeeding in Rain World requires you to realize a new perspective on the worth of experience.

In these moments, these moments of reflection, of peace, where the music swells for nothing, nowhere, nobody at all, you realize just how worth it it was.

I gave this game a fair shot, alternating between Monk and Survivor.  I'm done with it - here's why:

- Poor platforming: crouch jumps will only work about half of the time, with no rhyme or reason.  Jumping between adjacent walls to go up - also only randomly effective.  And when trying to climb a ladder? This is the only game I've seen where the character gets hung up on the sides of the ladder!  Awful stuff.
- No scrolling: An unforgivable design choice in an unforgiving game.  This could prevent so many accidental deaths of walking into an enemy simply because it is one screen over.  
- Inconsistency: You won't die if you and an enemy are going through the same 'dashed line' pipe.  You will die if you are going through the same 'sideless' pipe.  Why? I don't know.

I know many of you out there love this game. I don't.

*Neutral review for hubristic pricing*

I bought it for $25 at 40% off, but even at this discounted price it does not feel like a premium game - feels more like an early access indie game. The opening of the game doesn't have music, and while the art is good and animation acceptable quality, $25 doesn't feel like the right price - especially on steam - for a minimal 2D game with no music to even set the mood, no matter how alive the world might be. 

May try again if it goes on 75% discount.

Absolutely fantastic game.

TLDR: game is very good but very hard (particularly to begin with)

Rain world has one of the most incredible and dynamic ecosystems in any game, the AI is simple code wise and yet unmatched (even with a couple of less favourable examples) in its overall interconnecting realism and complexity. the game really is an ecosystem on its own that you are just living in.

The combat is brilliantly handled, with the player being one effectively one shot to anything yet able to dish out some violence in return. This is an ecosystem and you are at the bottom of the food chain.

The DLC is massive and like a whole game with the amount of content it adds, definitely get that with the base game if you like rain world sounds.

The lore is fascinating and intricate although you will likely only see the surface in the average run.

The difficulty is a turn off for many people and if you struggle with hard games you may not like it. Although the feeling of reward when you do eventually learn the game  is amazing. People complain about the RNG which is somewhat fair but since its basically an ecosystem simulator on top of a game it should be expected, you cant anticipate what another animal should do so the game doesn't let you.

The art style if beautiful, sound/music is great and used sparingly keeping it fresh and maintaining the perfect atmosphere and level design is phenomenal (although not quite perfect) the stages are designed around parkour combat and exploration with easier but longer roots for less daring players and run around to avoid the ecosystem doing its thing and blocking your path from one way. 

Personally ive never had an issue with reindeer yet but from what ive heard and seen they are quite buggy but not as big a deal as people make them out to be.

Overall this game is a rewarding, skilful and unique; definitely give it a try. not necessary the right game for the plebs who struggle to play hard games.

Rainworld drops you into a stunningly beautiful world and gives you an amazing skill based movement system to explore it. The ecosystem is powered by amazing AI that makes the world feel truly alive. Rainworld is difficult, you will die. A lot. However each and every death is a learning experience that will make you better at surviving. You save with each successful cycle and each cycle is only a few minuets long so even if you die right before the next save-point you are only losing a few minuets of progress which makes it very easy to jump back in and try again. You must continue exploring in order to uncover Rainworld's rich story and deep lore so please do not become discouraged if you feel like nothing is happening or that you have no clear goal. The goal is to keep exploring, explore enough and I promise the game will make your overarching purpose clear to you. Overall this is one of the best games I have ever played and I cannot recommend it enough.
