[h3]Rain World: a Game that creates its own Experience[/h3]
     There are plenty of games out there that are fun. There are plenty that are visually breathtaking or challenge players skills. But it is only the very best ones that create their own entire experience. Rain World, is an excellent example of this. Despite receiving mixed reviews from critics, it achieves this unique experience with a vast, interesting world, lots of mechanical depth, and an incredibly immersive atmosphere.

     In Rain World, the player plays as a "slugcat," an aptly named creature that seems to resemble both a slug and a cat. The player jumps, crawls, hides, gathers food, and hunts in a vast, two dimensional world, exploring every unique corner of a diverse ecosystem on an alien planet, all while avoiding a frequent, deadly downpour. This world contains all sorts of odd, sometimes seemingly impossible creatures, which interact not only with the player but with each other inside of an elaborate, simulated ecosystem, in which the player is but a small part of. However, slugcats sit rather low on the food chain in this ecosystem, and often find themselves being hunted by terrifying, ravenous predators. The player must quickly learn to survive in this world by gathering enough food, avoiding predators, and most importantly, not getting caught in the rain.

	One of the things that makes Rain World unique is the natural way that it lets players learn. Instead of shoving wordy tutorial messages in the players face or starting out with lengthy and obnoxiously easy challenges, Rain World throws the player straight into the deep end of the pool, and leaves them to learn how to swim on their own. At the beginning of the game, it shows the player the basic controls and other fundamental mechanics of the game, but then immediately sets the player free to explore. The player will probably die countless times throughout their journey, but every time they do they can use that experience to survive the next time they are in a similar situation. While playing this game, the player really feels like they are learning to survive on their own in an unfamiliar world using tricks, exploits, and strategies that they come up with completely on their own. For example, after getting eaten by a ferocious lizard the first couple of times, the player might eventually notice that the lizards are not capable of climbing poles. They can then use this knowledge to easily stay well away from the jaws of the beast, and live for another day. This kind of process happens frequently across all kinds of different situations throughout the entire game.

	Another reason Rain World is so interesting is because of the incredibly in-depth ecosystem that it simulates. Every single creature the player encounters in this game has its own survival in mind, its own encounters with other creatures, and sometimes even a unique personality. Unlike other games where everything revolves around the player, the player is only a small part of this vast ecosystem. To demonstrate that the player is really not the main character of this universe, a lizard which has caught the player might get distracted by another lizard, which it decides to fight over territory with, losing interest in the player. Additionally, the game keeps track of and simulates all of the creatures in a wide area, allowing all kinds of interactions amongst the wildlife to happen constantly regardless of whether or not they are being observed by the player. This results in the player often walking into situations happening between other creatures that they arent even involved in, which helps make the world seem so much more lively. 

	The AIs of the creatures in this game are also quite realistic. Lizards hunting for food will wander around, investigating small noises they hear, and give chase only when they spot something with their limited vision. Giant Vultures will swoop down upon unsuspecting prey, only to fly off frustrated when their prey hides out of reach. The most notable example of this games intricate AI systems are the Scavengers, which are monkey-like creatures that live in tribes across the map. Individual Scavengers have unique personalities, remember the players actions with a reputation system, demonstrate emotion, and even communicate with the player using body language.  These kinds of deep systems and mechanics not only breathe more life into the game, but also keep the game feeling fresh later on, since it gives the player more advanced systems to learn about and use to their advantage.

	One of the greatest things about Rain World is the incredible sense of atmosphere it creates. From the soft sound of dripping water after a fresh rain cycle to the faint chirping of small insects in the background to the distant whirring of ancient machines, there are so many small details in the worlds ambient sound design that makes players feel like they are really in the world themselves. There are also many visual elements, such as colorful rainbows, foggy landscapes in the background, or cascading shadows cast from clouds rolling by, that further contribute to allowing the player to become immersed in the world. 

	Adding to the atmosphere is the games music, or lack thereof. The player will spend much of their time accompanied by no music at all, creating a lonely and sometimes unsettling feeling. But, during key moments of the game, various types of songs do play, like the hollow, lonely song that plays when you first open the game, the percussive and suspenseful music that plays when in danger, or the ominous, ancient hymns that play at mysterious locations. Perhaps the most important aspect of the atmosphere, however, is the games story and the players journey itself. The games story is a tragic tale about the protagonist slugcat being separated from their family at a young age, losing all hope of returning, and searching for a new purpose. This story is reflected quite well in the games depressing, lonely, and desperate atmosphere.

	However, Rain World is certainly not flawless. One common criticism of the game is that controlling the slugcat feels rather sluggish and imprecise. While this may feel like the case at first, it really just takes some practice. After spending enough time learning and mastering the controls, it starts to make sense, and players are able to move more deliberately, with precision, and much more swiftly. Some people also dont like the lack of guidance and the openness of the game, which admittedly does sometimes lead to new players winding up stuck in extremely difficult sections of the game they werent intended to be in yet. This is certainly an issue, but the game does use multiple methods that attempt to subtly steer the player back on track, so these cases are somewhat rare. Finally, the main issue that many people have with this game is with the sheer difficulty, and how cruel and punishing this game can sometimes be. When playing through the game for the first time, many players will find the game overly difficult and frustrating, not enjoying this type of extreme challenge at all. But this is simply just how the game is. While some are willing to push through the steep learning curve to experience the joy of mastering this game, most are, understandably, not.

	Despite its flaws, Rain Worlds unique, immersive style of gameplay and story create not just a game, but an incredible, unique experience for some people, a journey which will be looked back upon fondly. However, its harsh and cruel nature will make it less than enjoyable for everyone else. So, while Rain World is certainly not a game for everyone, it is an incredible experience that is worth every minute of its time for those it does resonate with.

You are a slugcat.
Slugcat is not a hero.
Slugcat is a animal, prey and predator.
No enemies, only animals, and you are not the only prey. They learn and grow. Be nice to them and you might even tame or befriend even the fiercest beasts.
No magic powerups, way to become stronger is learning the surprisingly complex movement techs and the weakness of each animal.
There is a story, follow the where the little yellow camera points. You might need to sleep to get more "karma" so doors open. Greet the remains of a ancient civilization. Don't eat the glowies on the beach. Check what the yellow friend shows you in pictures. You can help. Or leave.
DLC has more content than base game. Better endings for the base 2 slugcats. Many more slugcats with special behaviours set on different ages of the strange world. 
Become a slugcat. NOW.

Don't play blind. I straight up don't recommend this game to you if you aren't planning to look things up or discuss the game with friends who know about it. The game has a tiny tutorial and complicated movement mechanics so feel free to look things up and DO NOT feel bad about it. The Rainworld Wiki is great for at least getting a basic idea of what locations to go next and what items do (and what controls to use them). 

If you play blind, you'll may get frustrated by how unfair the game is (it is unfair, the developers were more focused on simulating an ecosystem than making a balanced game) and you won't know where to go to progress, let alone how to use items like spore puffs or grappling worms.

Another thing: you can get mods and still get achievements, so you can play the game with all the QOL you want and not get punished (like SBCameraScroll if you want the camera to follow you). Alternatively, you can download Rotund World and become morbidly a beast.

This game has a lot of reviews from users with hundreds of hours that say you should go in blind. It'll be frustrating and you'll ragequit, but as long as you keep coming back, eventually the game will click. Maybe it'll happen after fifty hours, maybe after a hundred, maybe two hundred, but eventually it'll click. The game also has story-based achievements, and only 13% of users have the achievement you get for reaching the half-way point. That's because most people never reach that second stage. I went in blind as the reviews said, got frustrated and ragequit as they predicted, but frankly I don't have the time to spend dozens if not hundreds of hours just to figure out the basic mechanics through trial and error, so I went ahead and read some of the articles on the wiki. I'm glad I did. I went back to the game after reading the wiki, had a great time and beat it, and I want to do a second playthrough later.

The frustration that comes with playing Rain World is twofold. The first reason for it is mechanical. It's a tough platformer. You die constantly, and a lot of the deaths are to RNG. However the second and more important reason is that the game is deliberately obscure. It tells you (almost) nothing. It doesn't even tell you you have a [spoiler]health bar[/spoiler]. When you start a new game, it doesn't tell you that "monk" is [spoiler]easy mode[/spoiler] and "surivor" is [spoiler]normal[/spoiler]. It doesn't tell you what moves you can do or how many items are edible. I'm sure it's mind-blowing playing this game for dozens of hours and then realizing you have a [spoiler]slide move[/spoiler], but I'd rather be told this information up front. The game is hard enough without requiring you to guess basic mechanics.

Once you have the basic gameplay information, Rain World turns into something more like a conventional metroidvania. You can go anywhere and gain access to new areas by picking up helpful items. You can lose those items again, but you need to bring a light if you're going into a dark area, things like that, so some routes through the game world are impractical. It's not a typical metroidvania for sure, but once you actually understand the mechanics, the game turns out to be much less strange than it seems at first. You jump on platforms, you fend off enemies, pick up health. You go from point A to point B to C, then the credits roll. The game world simulates an ecology, which is neat, but from the player's perspective it's only the deliberate obscuring of the mechanics that prevents you from playing it like (mostly) any other tough platformer with realistic-ish physics.

If you already know you're one of those <13% of players who don't mind ragequitting, coming back, ragequitting, coming back, etc., for dozens or hundreds of hours before you get it, by all means try it blind. If you're more like me, I'd really recommend reading the wiki before you ragequit and uninstall. You don't have to read any story spoilers, they all have big warning labels on them. Just read the page on the controls and some basic stuff like how hibernation and feeding work. My own frustration (mostly) went away at that point. I still died all the time, but now I didn't mind so much because I understood why.

The game looks great. I kept thinking of the game Another World in terms of the esthetics. It sounds great too, all moody background noise and drones with some minimalist music here and there. The atmosphere in general is spot-on. The enemy designs are cool and otherworldly. The world-building is consistent and well-done. The game even makes you feel for the couple of NPCs you come across. I played with a PS4 controller, which worked fine most of the time, but I found it very difficult to get the timing down on extended sections of wall-jumping, so I had to switch over to keyboard for these parts. On keyboard it was no problem. You can switch back and forth seamlessly between controller and keyboard, so you don't have to commit when you start. I played on Proton, and it seemed to run really well.

This. F**king. Game.

I can comfortably say that beating Rain World is one of my most prized accomplishments when it comes to gaming. Not only because it's very difficult in a refreshingly unique way - more on that later - but also because the [i]spiritual significance[/i] of the game, the ending in particular, left an ever-aching scar on my heart that refuses to heal even years later.

There's this general belief that game journalists suck at games; I don't want to get into that right now, but I honestly believe that Rain World simply blindsided a lot of its more mainstream reviewers with its unconventional control scheme and strange, dynamic difficulty. This isn't a 2D platformer. The slugcat cannot really jump like we're used to; instead, it has a handy set of other movement abilities, and learning them in spite of your instincts is required to get anywhere.

And this is on top of the other unusual design choices. The world is incredibly interconnected and if you're persistent enough, there's nothing really preventing you from doing stuff out of order and even skipping a lot of the game. No worries though - the chances of you doing that on accident are very low.

What really makes Rain World shine, however, is the way its difficulty works. Almost all hard games can be learned, and that's what you're expected to do. Learn the steps and execute the dance. But Rain World shuffles things up every time you die. Enemies appear in different locations. A route you took last time might be inaccessible this time around due to a bunch of lizards fighting for turf. Sure, you could try sneaking past. Or even fighting them. But as a general rule you're not a fighter; you have to use a mixture of trickery, stealth, being quick on your feet and occasional violence to get by.

In other words, you're squarely in the lower half of the food chain. Yes, there are creatures that are below you that you can hunt and consume, but most things want to make a snack of you instead. And they will. Oh yes, they will.

The most memorable and glorious moments of the game will be where you will have barely escaped with your life over and over again in a single cycle and miraculously managed to find shelter just before the rain came. And as you start to really understand the workings of the world and the abilities of your slugcat, moments such as those will come more and more often. That's its true power.

On top of all that, Rain World has a spiritual component - one that is not immediately clear, but as you keep playing, you'll begin the true significance of a lot of stuff. I don't think it's practical to completely unravel the plot by yourself due to the insane things you need to do to get some pieces of info, though; I had to consult the wiki to really understand. But it's fine - you'll still get a very satisfying and emotional experience if you go only with what you can find by yourself.

And above all else - it's a very, very unique game, even by indie standards. Difficult, yes. But possible to learn and to master. Complex. Obtuse, perhaps; but so incredibly satisfying. Not for everyone, for sure - and yet, I implore you to check it out. I'm incredibly grateful to the Universe that I did and refused to give up.

Rain World is one of those rare games that feel tailor made to be as unsatisfying to play as possible. However, unlike most titles which fall within this category, that is its intended appeal.
 
When playing Rain World, you are but a delicious, savory slug cat in an ecosystem where nearly everything is either predator or prey. Your rank in the food chain is laughably low, and the game makes sure you understand this very early on. The reason why most players drop Rain World after only a few hours is because the gameplay feels unrewarding, directionless and unreasonably punishing. Just like real life.
 
Being driven away by these factors early on is entirely understandable, as even those who are dead set on seeing the game through to the end will be forced to take things slow. Only through careful observation, methodical exploration and an ungodly amount of patience will you persevere in Rain World's oppressive ecosystem. There are no upgrades or special moves to unlock. Your only ally is the intricate knowledge of the game's systems that you will gain gradually, after many hours of trial and error. The Downpour DLC sort of flips this dynamic on its head in favor of a more conventionally fun gameplay loop fueled by the new characters' wacky abilities. But that doesn't mean the game becomes a cakewalk. In fact, with the downpour slug cats, so many new sources of danger come into play that they often outweigh the benefits of having character-specific attributes, making the experience somehow even more excruciatingly stressful. I love it.

So then, what does one get out of playing Rain World besides unspeakable levels of humbleness and a head full of gray hairs? The ultimate kind of immersion. Rain World is as close as one can get to truly FEELING like a helpless creature in the treacherous wilderness. This feeling is elevated even further by the game's absolutely gorgeous environments and soundtrack. All of these elements combined secure Rain World's place as one of, if not THE most jaw-droppingly atmospheric game ever created. And then there's the story.   

Each character has their own unique little plot line designed to get the player to care about them. Besides having their personal quest, every slug cat plays a role in the game's overarching story about a world left behind by an advanced civilization and its progressive decay. Environmental storytelling is a core aspect of Rain World and there are times when a mere glimpse of the scenery is enough to let the player know that things have taken a turn for the worse in-between different slug cats' playthroughs. Many such deeply affecting moments are present throughout all campaigns and, together with the pieces of lore scattered throughout the world in the form of data pearls, they make for an exceedingly compelling narrative.

The best way to experience Rain World is by going in as clueless as possible, although I don't blame anyone who turns to the wiki for help along their journey as I'm guilty of doing it myself. It's fine if you desperately need guidance and are unwilling to spend the next 3 hours trying to figure out where you're supposed to go, just note that the experience will have a much greater impact on you if you slowly figure stuff out for yourself.

In a nutshell, playing Rain World is like watching your favorite show while getting kicked in the nuts. The kicks just keep coming. One day you will have taken so many kicks to the nuts that you'll stop feeling your nuts. But you'll still be getting kicked in the nuts. And then eventually you'll come to realize that the kicks to the nuts serve to enhance the viewing experience. Every kick to the nuts will make you notice new subtleties and nuances of your favorite show that you had previously been unaware of even after hundreds of rewatches. You will never be able to watch it again without having 10 kicks administered to your nuts every second. It would all feel so bland in their absence.

I can't fully describe how great of a game this is. It is an experience that I am glad I decided to take part it. The beautifully crafted landscapes, the surprisingly in depth movement system, the music that I can't ever seem to get enough off and the unforgiving yet satisfying reward of dominating the food chain. It's great.

This game is by no means easy, it shows you the bare minimum at the start and pretty much expects you to learn everything about the ecosystem that you are now suddenly part of and you will undoubtedly become a lizards lunch a good amount of times. You will likely end up feeling very lost at the start too, you aren't given a clear objective of where to go apart from a Yellow Overseer following you around pointing out various things about the environment you are in which at times can seemingly make you go back from where you just came. Because of this you can quite easily end up in a very difficult area which is honestly something that could be improved slightly to dissuade inexperienced players or at least give an idea of what to expect before essentially soft locking themselves. If I was to give any advice to new players for a slightly more enjoyable experience, head up and right at the start of the game.

The creatures of Rain World are often brought up in discussion as the way everything interacts creates a world that feels very real. One experience with a certain creature may differ greatly from each individual making you uncertain if you can repeat the same strategy on it for an easy victory. For example the Green Lizards, you may find one that is very lazy almost making no attempt at catching you, simply biting the air in your general direction when you are close. On the flip side you may get one that doesn't seem to give up chase and lunges at you much more motivated to get it's next meal. You can never quite be sure. (Can't say the same for Reds, They want you dead.)

I would talk about the scavs but honestly they have such a complex system that I don't think I can even begin to explain how real they feel at times. (minus the questionable reaction times that will never feel fair.) All I will say about them is try not to give them a reason to kill you.

I could honestly go on about how much I love about this game for ages. It's one of the games that I plan to eventually 100% (not doing that achievement it's too mean) but if you read this along side the thousands of over reviews that have likely talked about what I have not and are still interested in getting this game, you absolutely should! 

Thank you Videocult for making such a wonderful game.

Rain World is my favorite game. 
    It has 3 campaigns (9 with the Downpour DLC) that are chock full of 12+ colorful regions with stunning scenery and incredibly relaxing (at least, to me) music, along with wonderful (and sometimes scary!) creatures, ranging from the small, scared lantern mice, to the giant towering iterator superstructures that the game takes place in and around (yes, they're alive!). There is so much lore to discover along with a wonderfully advanced and diverse ecosystem!! 
    I could go on for HOURS about this game (and have), but i think it'd be best to discover all of the different mechanics and each of the creatures and their strange habits on your own!! 

(Also, this game is EXTREMELY mod friendly if that's the kind of thing that you are interested in!!! my personal favorite mods are mostly small quality of life tweaks and cosmetics, like sticky HUD or the very popular Dress my Slugcat! if you do plan to play, i suggest you browse a few of the mods in the workshop!!)

My favorite game of all time. I'm going to do an English essay on it as a piece of art. I could post the whole essay here, but I guarantee you should just experience it firsthand.

I've played this game since before 1.5 and Downpour, and still keep coming back to it as my friends discover it for the first time for an experience they'll never forget.

You control the unenviable after they are separated from their family and habitat by a rain storm, washing them through a labyrinth of still-functioning infrastructure that fights against the reclamation of nature.   
You don't know where you are, you don't know how to get back, and the strange yellow creature that greets you after you gain control gives you scarce, fleeting advice before you're eaten by a hissing green monster. 
... then you try again.  

The gameplay loop has you learning a deceptively simple three-button control scheme as you struggle to feed yourself, hibernate, and progress a mysterious counter that seems to gate your progress through the game; You'll quickly begin to appreciate that while survival for the regrettable slugcat is harsh, the world isn't about you- The meticulously detailed and foreign environments you traverse feature functional ecosystems that you are merely a conveniently sized snack for, not an explicit target. 

This is where the game can be polarizing. It's very old-school in it's design and is, as the kids say, "Nintendo Hard". It's design philosophy of tossing you into an alien world and leaving you to learn it's rules extends from the more advanced movement techniques to unclear UI elements. You do get a guide that will attempt to point you in the right direction, but they are driven by procedural behaviors and can be inconsistent at best. 
I do respect that some folks won't enjoy this game, but for anyone that is shying away at my previous description: Just wait a moment-

The difficulty is important. 

I won't tell you that you MUST play this game regardless of your personal tastes, but if you can pay out the patience the game demands, it will absolutely pay you back. 
Rain World is a game with a very carefully crafted narrative and intent to its environmental story-telling, with moments and revelations that still to this day give me chills and make me tear up a bit; And that's not including the Downpour DLC.  

If you still want the story without the difficulty, the game has always had mods and now includes official quality of life features to adjust it as you need.

If you want a classic styled cinematic platformer with a rich cast of creatures that simulate a fascinating ecosystem, absolutely, cannot recommend enough. 
If you want a deeply introspective and surprisingly philosophical story that thrives on your actual struggles as a player, this game will live in your head for decades to come. 

Oh and there's official co-op support. Just be sure to go through the effort of setting up Parsec (and maybe reWASD for sharing keyboard inputs) as my experience with Steam Remote Play is... inconsistent. 

For any of my friends I forced to play this game: I'm not sorry :)

Just beat the game for my first time after 9.5 hours, and I still feel like I've barely experienced all that the game has to offer especially with the DLC.  There is so much content in this game that you never stop being surprised and entertained.  One thing I never hear anyone say about this game is just how absolutely terrifying it is.  Maybe it's just me being afraid of bugs, but every single thing in this game had me on the pause screen considering just alt+f4ing out of fear (especially the stupid spiders ahhhyerfgeayfeas8rg).  However, all that did was make the reward of making it through an area 100 times more rewarding.  I really feel like I got to truly face and overcome my fears.  If you are arachnophobic you might just never beat this game if you can't muster up the courage to unpause the game and fight those spiders.  If you like a challenge then buy this game for sure, it has hard to master platforming and hard to master combat, and once you get good at them you really start to feel like a badass.  The feeling of outmaneuvering multiple apex predators using nothing but a rock and a couple backflips is a rush.  The main gripe I had with the game was just how little direction it gives.  I understand that it is a part of the experience to figure things out, but there are so many times in the game that if I hadn't looked something up I would have never found out that it exists.  I'm sure that you can beat the game without looking anything up, especially if you aren't afraid of fully exploring the more scary areas of the game.  But if you played Hollow Knight and thought that it didn't have enough direction, just know that this game has even less.  But I still recommend it, amazing soundtrack and visuals, difficult and fun to learn gameplay, and a story that keeps me up at night just thinking about it.

Edit: At 110 hours I can now confidently say there is rain in this world.

A good game ruined by terrible controls.

In detail, the movement is quite good and the combat feels nice. Therefore, I am more referring to the player input as Rain World really struggles with that. I am coming from a keyboard which might mean this isn't a problem on gamepads but, whenever you need to interact with some kind of vertical platforming everything falls apart. 
I wanna start with the good things because it's important to understand why this major flaw nullifies every system and makes it impossible to enjoy the game. 

The environment, music and creatures are really well done. You wanna get lost in this world and explore it. I felt the strong urge to sink many hours into this game and all of its components work beautifully together to invoke that feeling. The little encouncters, how enemies and other bugs interact with each other and the soundscape are magnificent to create this dystopian place you survive in. Art design in particular is some of Rain World's strongest bits. Hence why it's so frustrating that it's impossible to stay immersed.

The problem really lies within how either the maps are designed or how controls are handeld. One of these systems kind of create this tragedy.

You see, a perfect example is when the environment slowly starts to shake, the rain is coming and the suspense start rising. You are jumping from platform to platform and the whole progress you made that day is almost finished. All you need to do is make your way back which you've prepared in advance by remembering the route and therefore you're certain that it's easy. But then you encounter a horizontal pipe leading to a smaller horizontal pipe above you inbetween two stones. One of those stones has a vertical pipe. You need to press spacebar to jump and then w to grab the pipe above you. Sadly when you do that your slugcat instantly gravitates towards the vertical pipe next to it and then grabs it. You then need to press space again to let go of it and reset the position a couple of times but by then the rain killed you already because it kept teleporting you again and again for like 10 times. Looking at you pipeyard.

Another instance is when you slept in a dead-end like the garbage wastes and need to do a climbing action on a rather tall wall. Spacebar is also the same input for crawling that last bit of a wall and the walljump which frustrates when you are trying to get over it and you don't have the space to do a backflip or throw-jump so your slugcat is just constantly walljumping until it works after the 5th or 6th try. 

Especially climbing pipes after a walljump is something that just works on a coinflip. Regardless of pressing w your slugcat refuses to grab it and falls into its death. 

Which leads me to the conclusion that the map design is either bad and shouldn't have these types of platforming sections or the controls on keyboard need a giant improvement. Because of this all of your immersion just goes down the drain, your day progress gets resetted and it stops sucking you into its world. 
I played for around 12 hours and tried again and again to love this game. And I actually like everything about it but this flaw makes it impossible to play the campaign when you regularly get stuck in situations mentioned above for minutes at a time until some creature just kills you or you fall into your death without even doing the input. 

The remix improvement were turned on and I have no problem with platforming in general. I suspect I need to say this because it's easy to blame the player but honestly I've tried many times. Celeste 100% wasn't a problem for me. Katana Zero's highest difficulty wasn't either a problem. And the simulation focus on Rain World is even something I enjoyed, the general platforming is good. Pouncing over cliffs and out-maneuvering enemies is fun especially with the combat. It isn't the game feel that I have a problem with which just makes it so frustrating because I like the game.

Hoping for a patch or a mod to appear because I still wanna finish it and give it more tries.

There is a big difference between hiding aspects of the game to impose the sense of secrecy, mystery, and give you a reason to want to explore the world, and just being too lazy to add a proper tutorial. Every second I spent playing this game I felt so lost, wandering around wondering what the developers even wanted me to do. I find food, and I hibernate. THATS ALL YOU GET. Find food, and hibernate. Everything else comes at you so fragmented and hard to understand, I had to look online just to understand the basic mechanics to the game that the devs never bothered to mention how, or what they do. This game fundamentally looks amazing on paper, but at the end of the day its another failed attempt at making a "challenging " game by adding a bunch of mechanics and not telling you ANYTHING.

Positives:
- the game looks and sounds good
- actually a good simulator
- the animation system is funny
- poles/beams
- hiding from and avoiding predators is fun
- the lore is pretty nice and has great spiritual resonance
- nice community
- sizeable DLC waiting if you like the base game

Negatives:
- doesn't feel much like a designed game, extremely rough around the edges in general
- the skill curve is a messy rollercoaster
- the controls are not fun to use and take a long time to get used to
- ledges
- maneuvers that make traversal fun instead of painful are extremely obscure (it would be fine if it was fun already at the skill floor, but it's not)
- too much randomness in guidance makes it confusing instead of useful
- too much randomness in food and threats makes you artificially lose time or fail attempts to progress altogether
- while not too punishing in itself, way too much to allow for the necessary experimentation, and it's tiring to get back to the same point again
- possibility to get softlocked if you didn't figure out an optional mechanic by yourself earlier on
- requires a certain player action which makes little to no sense, as it amounts to giving up on trying to find the solution, to progress at some point
- in no way similar to other games which's communities usually recommend it

This game is a masterpiece in almost every way. Definitely not for everyone as you do need to power through the first few hours until you gain a basic understanding of the mechanics, but once it "clicks" it should slowly evolve into an absolute joy to play.

The world and vast array of different regions to explore within it are all very distinct, and each of them is extremely fun to uncover and explore fully given how beautiful they look. It's totally worth it to slow down and just look around instead of speeding through every new location you find.
For me, the feelings that the graphics and style of Rain World induce in me are unlike any other game I've played in the past years. The game just has a certain type of beauty to it that I cant find in anything else.

The 2 soundtracks of Rain World combined easily add up to one of my favourite original video-game scores ever. In tandem with the aforementioned visuals, the game becomes a master of escapism. Nearly every track engorges and absorbs you in the world that you must forge your own path through, and immerses you in the animalistic nature of the various combat encounters.

As i opened with, the difficulty and non-traditional ways that the game functions may pose a challenge to anyone giving the game a try. Playing Rain World, you have to be prepared to be beat down and stomped on by the many difficulty spikes throughout a play-through. Combined with the somewhat harsh punishment for failure, it can seem extremely daunting for any new players- however, as long as you fail, there will always be some sort of lesson to be gained. Learning of a shortcut to sneak around a particularly hard obstacle, Understanding the tactics that your foes could employ to win a fight, becoming more comfortable with the movement of your player-character, everything helps. The game has no abilities, no extra lives, no way to just cheese your way out of anything. Knowledge is power; Experiment with your options.
(Side note, while seemingly simple at first, there is a surprisingly in-depth and complicated movement system to learn. Extremely rewarding if you put in a little bit of time to master it.)

As for the lore/story, there is only a handful of times that you have parts of the plot actually shown to you directly, as a lot of the lore is uncovered through collectable trinkets and such. This isn't to say the story of the game is bad however, there's an insane amount of information to find and learn about. Piecing everything together was extremely enjoyable for me, and if you like ruined, uncaring and mysterious worlds in any sort of media, i'm sure you'll enjoy it too.

For a conclusion, play this game if you want a refreshing, tough-as-nails world to explore while discovering what caused this planet to fall to ruin, all while being complemented by not only one of the best soundtracks a game has to offer, but also some of the most artistic, expressive and unique graphics you'll find in amongst a sea of low effort triple-A garbage and mediocrity.

10/10

The game has great graphics, atmosphere, sound design, and gameplay. However, the RNG aspects of the game really bums me out. Combat can be weird at times, especially when going up against scavengers.

Don't play this game if you are too used to handholdy games that don't require any thought to learn.
I've played a fair few games, but this is my favourite ever.
This game is unfair, yes, we know that already. That should be made clear to you upon your first ten deaths to the same thing, because you don't get taught anything about how to move on. Such is the life of a slugcat, and you need to accept that if you want to make any progress.
You are alone.
There is nobody to help you.
There is nothing that will help you.
From start to finish, you play as a pitifully weak creature called Slugcat, and there are no upgrades, nothing to show for your progression... Except for your own skill. Like the slugcat, every cycle and every death comes with the knowledge to improve yourself. There are no powerups, no level ups, no stats. Just your sense, your understanding of the world, and your skill. 
In my opinion, there is no game out there more immersive and more intense than Rain World.

Im very split about how I feel about this game.
Ill start with the good stuff:

The visuals and overall atmosphere are really solid.
The few times the soundtrack gets to play always makes me stop whatever I was doing and listen.
Being dropped coldly into this ecosystem and finding your place in it is a completely unique concept that I have never seen being explored by other games. I also generally enjoyed its survival aspects.

However the game is often repetetive and frustrating.
I dont really get where the fun in the gameplay is supposed to be coming from:
The platforming is rather slow, unresponsive and clunky not to mention the claustrophobic leveldesign that at times completely removes that aspect from the game.

"Maybe its about exploration" I thought. But the games systems dont reward or encourage exloration either: If you explore you die. Either becuase of unfamiliar terrain, enemies or because of the rains. Speeking of... do you remember the rain in BotW? How it would hinder you from climbing that mountain? Now imagine that but ten times worse. Why would there be a time limit for exploration? The rains either lead to you retreating back to your previous hibernation spot or to a miserable death somewhere on the way to the next one. I basically always chose the latter which ment I would explore the rain world bit by bit each time getting a little further. This wouldnt be to bad if it wasnt for the karma system, you see each time you die your karma level drops. And like I said you die a lot. But when your karma level is too low you cant get past the gates to the next area anymore which basically makes all your progress pointless and leads to you grinding your karma level back up again.

Ive played up to the Shaded Citadel the games third area and its giving me Tomb of the Giant vibes. To give an example as to why I think its poorly designed; the area is completely dark. The only way to see anything is by grabbing some glowing animal. However because of its weight, carrying it reduces your jump hight, causing some jumps to be unreasonably frustrating or straight up impossible. I saw that the monk class can see in the dark but I dont want to start from the beginning all over again. 
I dont know wether Im gonna push through and finish the game or if im gonna move on to something else. I can definetly imagine me competely changing my mind about this game if I get to see the end and ending up loving it but as of now this is my recomendation:

Is rain world a bad game? No. Is it a masterpiece? Hell no. Is it worth your time and money? Possibly, if youre really curious for it. Just dont set your hopes too high.

I tried really hard to like this game. I love its atmosphere of discovery, and I'm not opposed to the high challenge level of the gameplay. But it's willfully unclear about what you should do and not do; anything simple with immediate consequences you can learn by trial and error, but bigger things like "is this the right direction, or will saving here lock me inside a high-difficulty challenge area irrelevant to my goals?" or "I found this character, but what can I do with them?" you're left to fumble through on your own.

This game, oddly, feels like Titanfall 2 in it's movement & difficulty. Sure, it's easy to move around, but if you want to learn to move like a real SlugCat (like a real Pilot), there is a long & tall skill curve to climb.

   Also like TF2 multiplayer, every other creature in Rain World starts out being absurdly more powerful, capable, & harder to kill than you. Unless you can stack the odds in your favor, or learn to move like a ninja slug, you're going to die a lot before you "git gud."

   Personally, I recommend looking up the lore & some tutorials to help you understand what the hell is going on, & learn the basics of movement. As you master basics, learn the more advanced techniques. Personally, I've enjoyed the challenge of learning the movement, as I did in TF2 (RIP).

   Really fun, once you embrace the randomness, difficulty, & exploration. In this game more than many, "Journey before Destination" applies tremendously.

   If you don't like exploring, overcoming adversity, & developing your in-game movement (IRL Keyboard commando) skills, then this game might not be for you. 

   Or at least, those were the reasons I've thoroughly enjoyed it, especially after watching a nearly 2hr vid explaining the exceedingly cryptic lore of this game.

This game is beautiful. This game has a beautiful ecosystem it forces you to get used to, and it perfectly utilizes fear and stress. This game may seem like a cute and stereotypical game, but I do have to give the warning that it's niche - after a few hours, you will be hooked or completely turned off, so I'd recommend playing 1-2 hours and then refunding if you don't like it. Give this game a try, if you do enjoy it, this is guaranteed to be a top favorite, with the beautiful ecosystem story telling, and the beautiful indie art style. The OST is brilliant, and the vibes of each region is mesmerizing. If this game is good, the DLC is a must play, revealing more answers of this game's one-of-a-kind story, with each campaign being almost as long as this, and just as action packed.

This game is absolutely stunning, brutal, and, in my opinion, the best simulation of an ecosystem I have ever seen. The controls (again, for me) feel smooth once you get the hang of them, and jumping around from pole to pole to move faster feels very rewarding. 

[ GOOD THINGS ]

- The predators and prey feel very expertly coded. I cant predict what they are gonna do next, and in most cases, I have to wildly flee myself before I get mauled.

- This game is not easy. I will mention this in the bad section aswell, but not giving the player the power of god, or a double jump, feels smart. If an overseer recommends I go somewhere that i cant reach, i will keep trying to get there, in various ways, if needed, because i know it is possible for me to get there. 

- The soundtrack, character design, and rain system feel flawless aswell. The game gives me a capacity to roam and be awake, but if you stay out too long, then you need to get moving to a shelter and NOW.

[ BAD THINGS ]

- This game is hard. You will not be fed the next area on a silver spoon, and grabbing fruit or grabbing batflies can be challenging. The rain can catch you. The lizards can. Any number of predatory animals or plants can reset you a cycle. But it isnt listlissly impossible hard, as most guides make it seem. Go at your own pace, run away from lizards instead of fighting them, if you want. This worlds only limit is time and skill.

Overall, I love this game, but you dont have to play if you dont want to. Just go at your own pace :]

Fucking nerve wracking at times and I LOVE IT. I was racing against the time, mere moments from death when I made it to a save point, and I haven't felt that level of stress and adrenaline from a game in a long time. 

The AI is also amazing, I often just messed around with some of the enemies to watch how they would react, very interesting and I'm considering getting the DLC for safari mode, so I can play around with the ai without risking my life.

In general, I highly recommend this game if you like platforming, as there is plenty of things the movement allows you to do and it makes combat feel very rewarding when you survive. The survival aspects mix well and I would not be surprised if this becomes one of my new favorite games.

Ori and the Blind forest's hillbilly inbred cousin wanna be. Sometimes my cat can survive in water for super long, other times my guy is in water for 3 seconds and dies. No air meter, I don't know how long till I drown. Exploration is failure. The game often give you 2 branching paths as if it wants you to explore, problem is that one path can lead you to a shelter and the other way will,  waste your time and then it rains, you die in the rain, rinse repeat. More than a few times I enter a room but one of the enemies that can kill you in one hit will just site at a door/pipe, glitching out, rolling over it self or stuck in a pipe I need to go through, wasting time until it rains. Nothing is communicated through you. It's 100% trial and error. I was in the draining area and died to a school of fish. At no point in the game until then did it even hint that fish can kill me. It was only after I randomly wandered into a different area that I seen the fish glow red, which usually means they are dangerous. Problem is that not all enemies glow, some blend in with the background. Some only glow at certain times. The fish only glow near the surface, so when I encountered them for the first time in a mostly underwater area, I die. The game forces you to walk on egg shells and take your time observing and exploring to then kill you with rain. The game punishes you for activity exploring quickly by having enemies blend into to the background or spawn directly in front of the pipes you need to go in to progress and you just have to wait until they move. The game teaches that you can throw things at enemies but it serves nearly no purpose...... until it does. Trial and error isn't difficulty, trial and error isn't a game-play mechanic, it's lazy. Im not going to ram my head into a wall 50 times until I guess the correct answer. The games just give throws occasional new hazards and enemy at you and you either guess how to deal with it correctly the first time or die trying to figure out, or better yet, just trying random things out or go a different direction until it rains and kills you anyway. The whole hibernation thing only serves to extend the game, making it seem like a longer experience. Hibernation doesn't even do anything but gates some areas. Early in the game I ran between 3 or 4 rooms, eating, hibernating assume it would do something positive but it's just there to gate off some areas. Removal of the hibernation thing in favor of a regular checkpoint system (instead of shelter) would improve the game in my opinion.

[h1]Much more than just a cute 2D platformer[/h1]

At first glance, Rain World seemed to me like just another cute little indie platformer. When I downloaded it, I did so along with Ori and Planet of Lana in an effort to stock up on 2D games I could play on a laptop. I was in for a rude awakening when I realized that this was a survival game in a harsh and brutal environment with complex and nuanced enemy design and an overwhelmingly large, scary, yet beautiful world.

The following is a detailed review of everything I thought the game did well and did poorly from the perspective of a completionist with all achievements and over 240 hours of gameplay. Since I absolutely adore this game, lets get the negative points out of the way first.

[h3]What the game does wrong[/h3]

[b]The control scheme is god awful[/b]
The entire game is controlled with 2 buttons. Every action in the game is basically the jump button or the pick-up button or one of those combined with a directional input or with each other. This can lead to extremely frustrating situations where youll be fumbling around trying to pick up or drop or eat certain items but wont be able to because all 3 of those actions are the same button. This is probably done to simplify the controls since the game is already very harsh in other regards and can be easily remedied with fan-made steam workshop mods.

[b]The randomness of the world can be frustrating at times[/b]
Rain World is a massive complex ecosystem where enemy encounters and behavior can depend on a multitude of factors. Spawns are fixed but how the games creatures decide what to do and where to go is very dynamic in nature. Although this is one of the most beautiful aspects of the game, it can also be the most frustrating. Its fairly common to encounter situations where the events of a cycle will play out in the most unfortunate possible way. Predators can block exits and just sit there or block an access pipe, aerial threats will attack at the worst time imaginable, or a friendly creature that is absolutely necessary to progress will just refuse to cooperate, etc. This is, in my opinion, a small price to pay in exchange for the sheer excitement of the games dynamism but can still be infuriating sometimes.

[h3]What the game does right[/h3]

[b]Gorgeous visuals with a unique art style[/b]
This will ultimately come down to whether or not youre a fan of pixel art, but if you are, then this game is nothing short of beautiful. Every area is visually appealing in its own way, with its own color pallete and theme. From industrial gutters, to abandoned underground train tracks, to a night-time metropolis, to a bridged complex overlooking a rainbow filled skyline. All dark and unsettling yet uniquely gorgeous.

[b]A massive and intricate world[/b]
Rain Worlds map is overwhelmingly large. It is comprised of over a dozen regions, each with their own aesthetic and their own fauna and flora. Each region has tons of things to explore, enemies to encounter, and different paths to take. As you pour more and more hours into the game, youll get a feel for how all the areas connect to each other and how best to path your way through the world on the way to different goals or objectives. There are always multiple ways from A to B at any given moment and what path you take, or what regions you choose to trek through or avoid is entirely up to you.

[b]A dark and gritty atmosphere[/b]
The game has a unique way of inspiring a sense of dread which is represented in all manner of forms. Youre travelling through a long abandoned/forgotten industrial area, in a race against the rainfall with the constant threat of predators around every corner. The world youre in is harsh and unforgiving and simply surviving while finding enough food to hibernate at the next shelter is a real challenge. Its a unique thrill with the stress of avoiding hazards and evading predators juxtaposed with the sheer euphoria of finding food or a shelter in an unexplored area. Combine this weird dichotomy of emotions with a dark and dreadful world and then throw in a beautifully melancholic soundtrack and you get a unique atmosphere unlike any game Ive played.

[b]A profoundly beautiful story under the surface[/b]
I wont get into any story spoilers here but the games story is very deep and meaningful. The story isnt presented to you up-front, but is always lying in the background waiting to be pieced together by dilligent players. The story also takes place over a timeline with each of the main and DLC characters contributing a small part to the greater picture.

[b]A living breathing ecosystem[/b]
The creatures in Rain World are vastly different from one another in their appearance and behavior. This can range from friendly to fearful to neutral to hyper-aggressive. Each creature has an optimal way to be dealt with, along with its place in the food chain and will behave according to a complex set of built-in relationships between them. A predator that wants to eat you may be scared off or killed by an even larger threat. A fight between two predators can provide an opportunity to slip past, which can sometimes even save you after being caught in the jaws of a predator. Some creatures have a reputation system with the player and will react to the player differently according to what their current standing with the player is. Certain predators can be fed to tame them, at which point they will follow you around and defend you (as long as you continue to feed them). Creatures will hunt, kill, and flee from each other and all these interactions are unfolding in the world constantly, even without the players presence. This furthers the sensation that this dauntingly massive and unforgiving world exists with or without you and you are only a small part of it.

[b]The best DLC I have ever seen offered for a game[/b]
Downpour more than doubles the amount of content the game offers for a fraction of the price. Downpour adds a whopping 5 playable characters that each have their own campaigns, unique mechanics, and new stories that take place at different points in the timeline which serve to fill in the gaps and paint a more complete picture of the events that take place. Each campaign also includes character exclusive regions and slightly altered areas based on the campaigns placement in the timeline. One of the campaigns even features[spoiler]a complete ice age reskin of the entire world map + the collapse of one zone onto another.[/spoiler] Each of these characters and their campaigns could easily be their own DLC and I would happily buy them, but Downpour adds FIVE of them which is a gargantuan amount of extra content to an already content-rich game.

[u]TL;DR[/u]
I started Rain World expecting to play a cute little platformer and what I got instead was a brutally harsh yet thoroughly enjoyable survival game. It was a journey through a beautifully crafted world with a complex ecosystem and a profoundly deep story under the games surface. It offers an overwhelming amount of content to enjoy and only gets more gratifying the more hours you put into it.

Game literally changed my life. Rain World made me understand people who fixate on the same game for a very long time even after they've already done everything in it. There is no experience like Rain World and I'm almost a little sad to think there will never be anything new like it in my life again. Go in as blind as you possibly can and do not look up guides unless you are well and truly stuck, and even then, I suggest checking the wiki for the region you're in and simply guiding yourself to one you HAVEN'T been in instead of looking for the actual goal of the game- Trust me, as aimless as it can feel at first, the joy of discovery in Rain World is THE appeal. It will either be extremely right for you or you will not be into it at all. Learning the controls is the biggest hurdle, but I found it very fun after getting over the frustration.
If you're patient, and (not to sound pretentious, but it's how I feel) you drop your preconceptions about how and what games "should" be, you will find this game insanely rewarding. I never in a million years would have considered myself the type of person to enjoy this game before I played it, but I am sincere when I say I am a different person having played it. Please give it a try.

This game is a real gem. I never really enjoyed the 2D scrollers, however this game is quite different. When asked about it I like to tell people its alot like Elden Ring meets 2D scroller as for difficulty. Spearmaster is rather challenging, Sky Islands sucks as a whole and the game is rather fun but also very very challenging and infuriating sometimes.

Pros:
- Incredibly unique gaming experience
- Phenomenal background storytelling
- Progression based solely on one's knowledge and skill
- Responsive and in-depth movement system
- Fantastic ecosystem; game does a great job at making you feel helpless
Cons:
- Screen cutoffs in big, open areas that can often get you killed
- Really useful and life-saving movement tech left completely hidden from the player (without DLC)
- Can easily make new players feel stuck/lost (God forbid you go to Farm Arrays and not Drainage/Industrial in your first playthrough)
- Jungle Leeches (I will find the sick individual/s who designed these things)

This game will unapologetically beat the living hell out of every new player and piss on their unconscious bodies as they're down. But if you're persistent (and quite honestly insane enough) to keep trying and learn, you'll experience one of the most breathtaking and unique 2D exploration gaming experiences to date. Is the game perfect? Hell no. Far from it. Is it worth sinking many hours into and even more with the DLC? Absolutely.

When I opened this game, I thought this was going to be a relaxing experience... [i]I'm so sorry, little one, but I was sorely mistaken.[/i]


[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I'll start off with what I would classify this game as, because it's a pretty unique experience. In short, it's an environmental survival and resource-management platformer sprinkled with a bit of rogue-lite in there. To be honestly with you, the closest game that I've played that I could compare it to is Noita for it's brutality and platforming, but that's about where the similarities end.

Would I recommend this game? Yes, but it has an acquired taste. There will be b*llshit deaths that you can't control. There will be no-win situations. The phrase "What the F*CK IS THAT??!?" will be said countless times during your time in the brutal setting of Rain World. However, what this game excels at is creating a beautiful ecosystem to observe and realize that you are only a very small part of. Let's get into that more, shall we?

[h2]The Strengths[/h2]
The environment of this game is extremely well done, down to the smallest detail, and much of this is due to how enemies work. Not only are the level layout and aesthetics gorgeous and gritty, but the enemies feel at home there. Different factions of creatures are in specific places of the map, but can venture out, fighting other factions or even amongst themselves. Furthermore, the "day" cycle of the game (going to keep this spoiler free) determines what enemies are out, and let me tell you, when the day is ending, even your WORST enemies simply want to survive like you do. All of these tiny interactions of the AI are what make experiencing this game truly special, because no run through the same area will be same. Getting ambushed by a massive enemy swooping out of nowhere at the beginning of an area? Well, even though your expecting it on the next run it never comes. The enemies are not simply roadblocks for the player, they are a part of the world, just like the player.

Also, this game can be horribly terrifying, especially when you stumble across new enemies (which happens often). I cannot tell you how many times I have entered a new room, seen what sort of abomination lies with in only to turn tail and run immediately. If this game has one thing to saw, it is that you are not the main character, you are only a small yet integral part of the world you find yourself in...

Overall, this game is great, but only if you're OK with a few b*llshit moments here and there. Otherwise, learning the game and how it works is a joy, and I'm still finding interactions that I've never seen previously. Would recommend, and good luck, fellow slugcat!

Great game hard but fun and it has great AI and story building would recommend this game and try it out.

Playing this is more harrowing than playing a Fromsoft game.

If you play this, I strongly suggest that you try to play it as blind as possible because discovering this gorgeous and enormous world is the best part about this game.
However the map is kind of non-linear to a fault because at some point, after discovering most of the game, I got stuck because I took the wrong entrance to one of the last area. So you know, do everything you can, don't hesitate to backtrack because I guarantee there are passages you missed the first time around but do spoil yourself eventually if you feel like you need to to go forward. I also wish the guide helped a little bit more. Like it will help you fuck around a LONG time before it reminds you that you're not at all going "forward" to an objective.

This is all I'm gonna say. The journey ahead will be hard but it will be so rewarding.

(And pay attention to the loading screen messages. This is the closest thing you got to a tutorial beyond the basic controls.)

I had a blast exploring the environment of Rainworld. The first 10 hours are tough as you attempt to adapt to the movement mechanics, but once you get comfortable exploration comes naturally. Buy the game if you have an undying curiosity and love to adventure.

An endlessly endearing experience, with a lot of heart and soul behind it. I really enjoy the controls and once you're used to how finicky they can be, they become extremely fun to play with and the creature physics just end up making sense intuitively. I'm not good at all the flipping and sliding and especially not throwing my spear mid-backflip, but I end up feeling like a damn badass when I jump away from danger at the last second, or stun a lizard to jump over him and then spear him in his squishy body.

This game is definitely worth the price and will keep you entertained for many, many hours.

"Rain world is a melancholic game with a heavy, murky and deep lore about existentialism."

This is one of the best games I have ever played.
With a story and lore so intrinsically built into the world that the experience integrates the player into the world's ecosystem through sheer immersion.

Oh, and I guess it's pretty challenging as well.

I played the game for the longest while the same way I imagined a Slugcat would try and survive. I moved when food got low and avoided confrontation to the best of my ability since there was nearly no benefit to willingly engage something bigger than me in combat.

Yet despite all the difficulty at the beginning I could hunt titans by the end of my journey.
Keep in mind that your skill is the only thing that improves from the beginning of a capaign until its end.. in most campaigns at least.

Rainworld is an amazing game, packed full of lore and interesting game mechanics to try out. It also has extreme replay-ability due to the different campaigns, passages and even endings- and all of the different mods available add 100 00 00+ things to do!

Although one of it's major drawbacks is how hard it is to new players. It doesn't give you much info, just a simple tutorial and boom- out into the world you go, with random creatures constantly trying to kill you, or simply inconvenience you in one way or another. I don't exactly have much advice to give, due to me having abit of a headstart when I first played since most of it had been straight up spoiled for me, but one thing I can recommend is exploring, as it'll help you adapt and learn how to deal with all different types of enemies.

Rain World is a game I would never recommend to anyone. To try and describe the feelings I have about this game is an essay within itself. Rain World is one of the most impactful, beautiful, frustrating, and down-right cruel games I have ever played in my life. 

This game has fundamentally changed the way I view the world, and not in a generic Ahaha! I learned about Buddhism! kind of way. It defies all nature, there is no world where Rain World is not frustrating, there will always be pain attached to this game. 

However despite that you always come back to Rain World, because it is unlike any other game. No Game displays such skill in enemy AI, movement, combat, art and more. It gives me this feeling of Super Smash Bros Melee, a game that beyond all reason should not be successful. A game that almost feels broken, unfinished, or fundamentally flawed, yet a game that surpasses and will continue to surpass all others like it. 

For most, flaws are not what they look for, they want perfection, but for people like you and I, Rain Worlds flaws are what makes Rain World Rain World.

One of those games that you'll never really forget.

Very unique, challenging, punishing, rewarding, so much fun. Buy the DLC if you enjoyed playing the base game, it has more content than the base game and is really enjoyable and well made. Definitely worth the price unlike many AAA games.

The AI is top tier and really lively, the pixel art and environments are amazing. This game has a lot to say if you're into lore and philosophy, but if you're not you can just play it for fun and enjoy the ride. 

This game does not hold your hand at all and lets you make all the decisions. 

Some advice for beginners: This game is really hard at times, so if you're really struggling don't feel ashamed to play the "easy" mode and choose monk. In this game the easy mode is still pretty hard if you're new to the game and is really more comparable to the "normal" mode in any other game. I played monk for my first ever run and still found it difficult. If you find yourself getting lost and not knowing what to do, don't be afraid to look at the wiki or a guide.

I want to play the Rain World that I hear people talk about.

For as many unique things this game does, I can't recommend it to the average person. There are so many points of frustration that need some quality of life attention, especially rerolling the mob spawns and grinding food for gates. I also think the second area (Drainage System) leaves an especially bad impression compared to the amount of freedom in the first area. Hitting credits ended up being more force than fun. If you are a fan of punishing platformers like Super Meat Boy or even Jump King and want a less breakneck pace, give this one a try. If you come in expecting an open-world exploration game where you survive by hunting your own food... you are like me, misled by some VERY loose definitions of those words. Good luck!

heh slimy cat rain lizors,,,









but seriously. this game is freaking life changing. like basically if you like platformer games, story games, and games that make you want to rip your hair out at all, buy it. buy the main game and if you like it, the DLC makes it even better. it's like a whole new better game added onto the already unbeatable base game. the story is so intricate but at the same time simple to understand at least the basics. it's the kind that will make you think about it for years and in the most random situations. the characters lore, if you dig a bit deeper than surface level, is so incredibly detailed and the personalities, especially of some later game creatures, are so well put together it's honestly amazing. it immerses you almost instantly in a world where you aren't all powerful. you arent a god. it feels like life kinda. you are just a creature in an ecosystem. you can eat the other things, but they can eat you too. its a learning experience to survive. you will die. you will die so many times. dont give up i promise its worth it. (also no. dont go running with your one spear towards that lizard. if it doesnt care about you, just go around it. flight is better than fight in most situations with this game.) all the people who said it's too hard - honestly - just didnt try hard enough. im sorry but it's probably true. its very much a try, try again, and again and again and again. and again. and maybe one more time. like i have over 200 hours on this game at the time of writing this and i still havent been able to finish all the campaigns without cheats. its a horribly hard game but everything else it has from the story to the animation to the art makes up for it. and on the topic of animation, the animation feels REAL. like its an actual animal. even though its pixelated and 2D it still is one of the most immersive games that money can buy. and the art in game and in the community is amazing. like truly some of the best art you'll ever see. especially from the rain world community which is one of the most accepting, inclusive, talented, and loving communities you will ever see on the internet. i need to go to bed now so i need to wrap this up but. buy rain world. thank you for listening to my ted talk. i will expand it tomorrow.

It is an aesthetically pleasing game with a good soundtrack, but it lacks a strong sense of direction. I found it hard to know what was happening, what the goal was, how things interacted or worked, and all around how to play. I can tell there is a skill curve, where it becomes much more playable once you learn the mechanics, but without direction or even a goal bar, it feels unmotivating to continue.

This is one of the best games I've ever played.
Probably my favorite game of all time.
It has amazing environments, sound design, and beautiful art and music. 
The main campaigns have tear-jerking stories, and I love how the player is meant to infer and piece together the lore from the environment and what little information you are given. I also adore how the game doesn't hold your hand and emphasizes exploration and figuring things out yourself, i rarely had to pull up a wiki to figure stuff out, if at all.
Some things I personally would like to see improvement on:
Certain areas of the map being improved to remove invisible walls, I think it breaks the immersion. Maybe replacing them with some physical barrier that fits in with the environment.
Small fixes to creature spawns and AI softlocking you (notable example is the caramel lizard in farm arrays by the gate to outskirts, which could also be fixed by just making the shelter a little bit bigger.)
I also really appreciate the dev team's efforts to fix modding on Linux.
i really don't have much to complain about, most of the game is really well made and the current bugs and goofs are so minor.
I do realize the gameplay isn't for everyone, but if you love exploration and discovering things for yourself you will love this game, it also provides a great challenge.

Rain World is a BEAUTIFULLY illustrated game.

Many people end up quitting because of the fact that the game won't hold your hand, the game will be very harsh on you. At first you'll be frustrated with this, but it's very much necessary. You're playing as a small creature low on the food chain and the game treats you as such. It perfectly sets up the environment around you, which has you learn your way around it yourself. It immerses you in such a way that you are able to put yourself in the slugcat's place. You yourself have to discover the story, and once you put together the pieces it lets you enjoy it to its fullest.

I STRONGLY urge you try the game, it is absolutely my favorite game and I expect it to be for a long time. <3

For me this game first and foremost is a feeling of silent dread of the world that is abandoned, which inspires the feeling of fleetingness of life. Through all the characters and epochs we witness the world decaying, as nothing actually mattered and is ready to meet the Void. At the same time we are reminded that the cycle is unending and will start anew.

This game is my favorite among indie titles and not without a reason. Many talk about its unprecedented natural habitat simulation and dynamic animations, fluidness of movement, steep learning curve, art style, story and lore. For me its all of these things combined into something almost flawless as an experience. It might be not the best gaming you will ever get, even though its really solid and fun soon as you dive head first and submerge yourself properly. But it is The Experience.

It only got better with Downpour. I cannot sing enough praises to the developers that worked of DLC that worked so much time on it by their lonesome. Videocult is also to be commended as they worked towards bringing DLC developers on board. Downpour introduced so much into story and contextualized many elements from the original game, at the same time largely expanding The Experience. 

In conclusion, I would like to say that the game might not be everyone's cup of tea, This review is purely subjective and comes from heart. But if you find other reviews to your liking and looking for something hard, stylish, alive and thoughtful - you just might be in luck.

This game is legitimately one of my favorite games in the world. While you start the game not knowing much else other than the fact that you are a little creature and must find a way to survive, once you get further into the game you realize just how rich the world is! Everything feels alive in this game and no two runs are the same. Hell, even each cycle is completely different, even if you're in the same area! 

The replayability for this game is insane! Even more so if you have the DLC which I 100% do recommend if you enjoy the base game. While the game is already one that you can replay over and over, if you do find things getting a bit stale then look at the workshop! The modding community for this game is astounding and it seems that every day there is new mods to add and try out! From cosmetics to game aids to new fan made areas, enemies, or even completely new slug cats to play as with their own mechanics! You can also play with friends through remote play so only one of you need to own the game. 

I will warn you that the game can get incredibly frustrating at times- especially when you're newer to the game as there is a complete lack of hand holding. You will die *a lot*, but its just part of the game. If that doesn't stop you from turning away completely I really do suggest you try it out! 

This game is so incredibly beautiful. The music, art, story- everything is amazing! As far as I've seen there really is no game like this one. If you want a game that will challenge you or you love a game that has amazing lore or of course if you like just being a little creature then this is the game for you!!
This game hurt me on a emotional and physical level and I can't stop playing it. 10/10 would recommend

Just go into this game prepared to be an animal near the bottom of the food chain just trying to survive. You'll be scavenging for food and evading creatures that want to have you for their own meal, or sometimes that are hostile to you for the sake of it. Some may even be curious before making a decision of how to deal with you. You're just a part of this world. Survive, and you will find out what it has in store for you.

I just... cannot handle the frustration this game forces down upon me. white lizards deciding to fall asleep in a tight corridor and not letting me pass to the area I am trying to go to. a horde of adult centipedes swarming me while I am in complete darkness with overseer giving barely enough light. I do not know what I am supposed to be doing or where I am supposed to be going. I shouldn't have to look up guides online to figure out where to go or what to do. Even after looking up a guide for how to fight these lizards, I still struggle. Either there are no visible weapons nearby, or I am in a tight corridor that does not allow movement. Not to mention, I don't even know how to throw in any direction other than left or right. Is that just me or is that an actual in game mechanic that forbids being able to throw in all directions? Again, I shouldn't be forced to look up a guide for every single thing in this game. I'm sure it's a good game if you can become good at it. (But why play a game that isn't fun for you until later on anyway?)

EDIT: Just wanted to say thank you to the random people and people in my friends list that gave me some tips for the game after they saw this review. That was very cool of you guys and probably the first time I've seen positive feedback from any community.

This game is an incredible experience.

Mechanically, it's pretty amazing, I know for a fact I only know a tiny, tiny bit of the abilities of the slugcats, and intend on doing more runs to discover the secrets Rain World has to offer, both in terms of story, and mechanics.

An incredible experience I recommend, especially if you have a friend to do the adventure with. This game is hard. Very hard, and it's very punishing, however, the reward of survival through the challenges of the environments and fauna trying to devour you is great- though don't expect the game to actually reward you. It tricks you into feeling rewarded, which is arguably even better. 

This visually stunning, pixel-art style game makes you feel like you're part of its environment, not in control of it, and that's very rare."
