[h1] Score: 8/10 [/h1]
I beat the Survivor Campaing, it took me around 27 hours, pretty fun experience overall and definitely worth experiencing. It is, along Zelda Botw, one of the best games about exploration out there.
[h2] Pros [/h2]
[b]Pretty fair unfair game for the most part[/b], the game doesnt expect you to have a high karma level after some difficulty mid game sections, which is nice, it also raise your karma level in a part where you need to be at maximum karma. It's a game where you will eventually beat it if you keep trying.
[b]Exploring is fun[/b], it's just plain fun, that's the main reason to play the game, the game never get repetitive because each region introduce enough things to keep the game fun.
[b]Gorgeous visuals.[/b] Everything from the locations to the enemies to the slugcats is so charming and memorable.
[b]Pretty memorable soundtrack.[/b] Thou, it's kinda hard to search for specific themes.
[h2] Cons [/h2]
[b]Extremely unreliable Overseer[/b], it was gone for most part of my mid/late game playthrough, I did Unfortunate Development twice because I missed the path to [Redacted]
[b]It doesn't bother to introduce more advanced techniques that make the game more fun.[/b] Just read the wiki of the game.
[b]Pretty simple story.[/b] It'll be hours and hours of basically no story at all, you can get extra lore using pearls, but that requieres a lot of effort and backtracking.
[b]I personally didn't like the last section of the game.[/b] It was hard to see where I could move and I was swimming in the void for 25 minutes. It was not hard or something, just disappointing.
[b]You can't bang Moon.[/b] Originally the score was 8.5/10, but I had to lower it after writting this part of the review.

10/10 but man where do i even start with this game
well i bought the DLC with the game when i first got it knowing it was likely something i would like after i played a little bit of the game on a friend's console and i am glad i did
when i played this game for the first time it was like i when i played Mario for the first time when i was younger
in other worlds its nice to have a game that kicked my ass for a while before i learned how to play it and the ins and outs of its game mechanics and was still fun
to say its unlike anything else i have played is a bit of an understatement so here are my thoughts on it in detail

(Lore/Story) the story is pretty good i like the world building and the vibes this game gives me when playing though its areas 

(Controls) the movement is clunky but not in a bad way you kinda have to drag yourself though the world like the rodent you play as and there is a lot of neat tech and funky stuff you can do because of this it just takes a bit of getting used to it tho i have always used a controller when playing this game so idk what playing keyboard is like

(Gameplay) getting used to the movement and avoiding being eaten is very important if you cant do that you wont get anywhere in this game. other than that you eat food, wander, avoid the rain, find shelter and die a lot to name few of the things you will be doing while playing and the creature AI is really something else helps make this game feel alive and hungry for Slugcat meat 

(Graphics) i know quite a few people that don't understand the appeal of pixelated graphics if you are like these people and cant understand why this game is stunning and gives of the vibes it does then i feel bad for you 

(Music) the soundtrack is fantastic and really adds to the vibes love the threat music that plays when enemies are near you

(Issues) the only real issue i have with the game that i can think of off the top of my head is the way screen doesn't scroll in larger rooms rather once you get to the end of the screen and can move past it will transition to the next screen even with the threat music that can help you know where danger is the lack of screen scroll can still lead to a lot of deaths to off screen enemies that fall in to the screen from above or are waiting for you when the screen transitions while you move across the room

(recommending) even tho i had a great time with this game and still do i really don't know how to recommend the game to people because of how different it is maybe give it a try if it looks fun

(Community) while i haven't talked much with other players as of now the modded content that is being made is fantastic keep up the good work guys

10/10

Before you play!

Understand that this game is hard, and that it is MEANT to be hard. You will die. A lot. There is no avoiding it (unless you use cheats for godmode, in which case what's the point?)

This game's skill ceiling is off of the charts. Different levels of play look drastically different. The movement system is one of the most dynamic in any game ever, and it's ecosystem is well done. You aren't anyone special in this game. You aren't some chosen figure destined for greatness. You are most often just a member of the ecosystem, or OCCASIONALLY a messenger.

If you are a rage gamer, don't play the game. You will dislike it. This game requires MULTIPLE tries to understand how good it is, and if you aren't willing to put in that time or effort, don't play it, it's not for you. The only way you get "stronger" is EXCLUSIVELY by getting better at the game. Literal experience is your XP bar.

Not a metroidvania btw. It has a lot of elements of one, like the different region names and... well that's about it. This is not a metroidvania, as much as Mr Scug looks like Mr Hollow Knight.

Regardless, this is one of my favorite games of all time, up there with the titles of Terraria, Celeste, and Hollow Knight, You just have to get by the difficulty barrier first. It's a high bar.

Rain World has the best AI I've seen so far in a video game and has an immersive and expansive world for you to explore. 

[b] Animations [/b]
Rain World has a unique 2D animation system. The game doesn't use sprites or pre-rendered animations - the animations are run in real-time by code and react dynamically to the environment and world around you.

[b] Survival [/b]
You play as a slugcat, a small creature low on the food chain, and are thrown into this dangerous world to survive. You must learn to use the environment to survive; by finding food and shelter, using the local fauna to help traverse the world, or learning how to out-manoeuvre the local predators.

[b] Movement [/b]
There is a lot of advanced movement tech in this game. Heck, there's an 87 page long google doc detailing how to perform most of this tech. Strangely, you don't need to learn any of it. It's all just there to enhance replay value and speedrunning.

[b] Adventure [/b]
The game is best experienced blind, there are a lot of wonderful things to find in Rain World; but if you are struggling to progress or understand what to do it may be worth looking up advice.

[b] Co-op [/b]
With the Downpour DLC, you have access to local co-op (which can be accessed through remote play), and 5 new DLC campaigns all of which have unique characters and changes across the world. Some criticise the DLC for being more game-like and less immersive, but I never ran into this as a problem.

[b] Achievements [/b]
Getting 100% achievements was ... in some parts a frustrating experience. Some of the challenges in the arena were a bit annoying (although some of them were great!). Challenge 70, while cool, was very annoying forcing you to replay the slow and boring phases 1-3 to access the much more difficult phases 4-6.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
Overall, I had a fantastic experience with this game. Highly recommended if you love exploring expansive immersive 2D worlds with a great artstyle and design.

Playing this game is a strange feeling, one moment you hate it and wanna punch a wall (i indeed punched my wall). But once you get to beat the game out of determination, you realise it was one of the best games you've played. To anyone that decides to give rain world a try, its a lot like real life; don't be off-put by the difficulty, just try your best and success will follow.

A overtly grandiose world would possibly be considered a "con" in certain cases, however the grandeur of this particular world is at a level such it is appropriately marveled at by those who lose 'the bag' to join in on this experience. The heart-wrenching story, in which a unidentifiable creature (what fate a slugcat) loses their family in what can only be described as a truly disturbing deluge. One will traverse a world of abject horrors, avoiding danger and crafting weapons (gun) that aid them in the most significant ways they can. 

Hunter Mode will kick your ass.

The story exists, though it may be hard to believe considering that one will likely not see nor understand the unfolding events. This can be helped through the fortunate created mods and cheats that can give for a significantly more forgiving environment, though one should try their skill in the milquetoast flavor to start. (Perhaps you are "built different.") The DLC aptly dubbed "Downpour" adds a multitude of new business ventures for your more communist government to explore and experience. 5 of them, to be exact. 

As for those campaigns, the premise of each is simple. Respectable chef. Vaporeon. I Have No Mouth, But I Must Scream, An ecological and literal terrorist, and Spiritualistic Apocalypto Fuzzy turned Dr Manhattan.

Woe be unto thee who forgo the loss of funds this masterpiece will jerk from your damp, sweaty grasp. They do it from love. Though the loss of funds is quite significant, it is often lessened during select "sales" that allow the commonfolk to indulge in it's beauty, and thus so I cannot help but recommend her majesty "Rain World" to any who find her 'personality' the slightest bit interesting.

This game, a masterpiece.

"Do you see the same as me?
Beauty continuing to bloom even in a place long forgotten.

I did not have the will to depart, nor the desire.

Why did they always search for an escape, as if we were imprisoned?

What offering from the void could usurp the gift of life already given?

This moment, right here! It is where we are meant to be."

 - Rhinestones Beneath Shattered Glass

I loved this game! It is hard, and even unfair, but so is life: if you want to survive as a slugcat, you must turn the odds in your favor or recognize when to run and hide. This game is incredibly organic: predators and preys roam around at their own will, hunting each other or together, obeying intricate mechanics (vision/hearing, movement, reputation, etc.) that take time to identify and exploit. Learning how to move swiftly was also satisfying. The user interface is minimal, meaning that the player must pay attention to the characters expressions (looks/breath, posture) to understand the situation, and greatly helping immersion. Even the lore went beyond my expectations.

If it weren't for the karma system and one minor design choice that exclusively punishes new players, I would recommend this game to everyone. There's nothing worse than finally making it to the next shelter then realizing you have to do it 4 more times in a row with a depleted food supply.

If that wouldn't bother you (or you're fine with disabling it the system in settings/using an exploit like I did), go for it. The game is enraging at times and unfair by design, but even as someone who absolutely sucks at games and gives up easily, it's one of the best experiences I've had. The way the AI works means you'll always have different obstacles to avoid, the environments are massive, the story/lore is very interesting, and the music amplifies it all immensely.

This game is amazing, if you're someone who likes to explore and piece things together on your own, like enemy behaviour, the world around and its story, or even such things like movement. Rain World is not one bit easy and pretty much everything about this game's design is hostile, but that's what makes it such a persuasive nut to try to crack. If you don't give up, this game will reward you and surprise you about a million times over, and there is no way it's story won't absorb all your thoughts.

very special game. can be pretty challenging and takes some time to understand how to enjoy. There's very little hand holding. But I'm glad I didn't give up because eventually I L2P and had unforgettable moments with the other creatures in the primal simulated ecosystem of rainworld.

Tips:
- Play blind. Don't look up anything! The game will surprise you endlessly.
- Enable the built-in REMIX mod with the absolutely necessary QOL changes.
- Use the map. The area's you've explored will stay visible after you die. There are dead ends. 
- Experiment with everything you find. Don't be scared to die, because dying isn't that bad (especially close to your last shelter).
- Pay attention to the tips in the loading screens. e.g. The physics based movement system is actually really awesome once you finally get used to it.
- Don't forget to finish the game all the way to the credits eventually

1. Captivating Art and Atmosphere: Rain World's hand-drawn pixel art creates a visually stunning and atmospheric world. The contrast between its beautiful environments and the harsh, unforgiving ecosystem adds depth to the player's experience.

2. Mysterious and Immersive Narrative: The game's minimalistic storytelling approach encourages players to uncover the narrative through exploration and observation. The world of Rain World is filled with secrets and lore, waiting to be discovered.

3. Unique Ecosystem: Rain World presents an ecosystem teeming with bizarre and interconnected creatures, each with its own behavior and role in the food chain. This ecosystem evolves and adapts as players progress, creating a dynamic and unpredictable world.

4. Challenging Survival Gameplay: Survival is at the core of Rain World's gameplay. Players must navigate treacherous environments, find shelter from the constant rain, hunt for food, and evade or confront hostile creatures. The difficulty adds tension and satisfaction to each successful survival.

5. Gorgeous Sound Design: The game's audio design, including its ambient sounds and haunting musical score, complements the visual beauty and adds to the overall immersion.

6. Nonlinear Exploration: Rain World encourages exploration and experimentation, offering multiple paths and routes to progress. Players are given the freedom to choose their own way through the world, making each playthrough unique.

7. Responsive Controls: The game's controls are precise and responsive, which is crucial for navigating the challenging landscapes and facing off against formidable foes.

8. Deep Lore and Mystery: Rain World's enigmatic world is ripe with lore and unanswered questions, inviting players to theorize and speculate about the story's hidden depths.

9. Unique Multiplayer Experience: The game's multiplayer mode allows players to explore and survive in the world together or compete in a race to reach specific objectives. This cooperative and competitive element adds variety to the gameplay.

In conclusion, Rain World is a mesmerizing and immersive indie title that shines with its captivating art, atmospheric world, and challenging survival gameplay. It offers a unique and unforgettable journey through a harsh and beautiful landscape, where players must adapt and overcome to survive. The game's minimalistic storytelling and open-ended exploration make it a perfect choice for those who appreciate depth and mystery in their gaming experiences. Rain World is not just a game; it's an artistic and atmospheric adventure that leaves a lasting impression on players who dare to explore its captivating world.

Amazing game so far! I will do a full review once I've finished it, and a final one once I've 100%'d it (all achievements) because it's really cute and I want to finish it before Downpour.

Okay, here's my updated review.
I absolutely love and adore this game; however, I don't want people to be misinformed about what this game offers.

PROS:
--- Story ---
The story that takes place during the events of this game is very interesting, and I would highly recommend it for anyone looking for a new and abstract world. The story is separated into different campaigns, each taking place during a different time. The combined story can be woven together through the details experienced in each campaign.
Simply put, I would recommend this game for its interesting story alone. It also does an amazing job at environmental storytelling.
--- Characters ---
Without spoiling too much, every major character in this game is amazing, they all have their nuances and find their own niche within the community that adores this game. I cannot dive too much farther without spoiling the story.
MIXED:
--- Movement System ---
Surprisingly, the movement system is very fluid yet very punishing. Initially, the movement system was very frustrating to me, and I believe most people quit their first time as a result of their problems with the movement system (too finicky or responsive). The movement system can throw people off and often leads to many deaths when first starting out. However, with how the movement system works, it can be manipulated with a very high skill ceiling to make for some extremely fun gameplay.
CONS:
--- Combat ---
The combat could be considered 1-Dimensional, as it mostly consists of stabbing monsters with spears. However, the movement system can be used to make combat more interesting. In most scenarios though, combat remains consistently the same.
--- Some Gameplay Elements ---
Some campaigns (in Downpour) involve a quest-like delivery system, where the main goal of the campaign is to just deliver an item and then go to "x" location. This is mitigated by the amazing environments that you pass through; however, if you aren't interested in the "environments/world," you might become bored by this gameplay loop.
Additionally, some things in this game are just too punishing and rage-inducing, such as a later-game area. This area is amazing to look at, yet has very odd game-design which can make you want to pull your own hair out. There's a few instances of odd game-design in other campaigns as well.
CONCLUSION:
For people looking for an interesting story and those who find themselves to be more artistic, I would definitely recommend this game. However, with some elements of the game, it can prove to be very frustrating and seemingly unfair. The game doesn't hold back, and veterans of this game will find that it is much fairer than it seems. It has a steep learning curve, but I find that pushing through and learning the game as Survivor or Monk (the first campaigns) will make the game much more enjoyable.

Rain World is a beautiful game, with a gorgeous landscape, engaging gameplay, and a overall decent soundtrack. The lore is rich, and, albeit confusing, extremely fun to toy with and think about. However, despite all these pros, I would like to preface this;

[b] Rain World IS NOT for everybody. [/b]

This game is as wonderful as it is difficult. I personally wouldn't have it any other way, however it still has its downsides and flaws associated with this extreme difficulty.

Rain World is:
 An extremely engaging platformer, that, when you master certain controls, is quite fun.
 A lore packed world, that can either leave you extremely confused, or allow for rather rich storytelling.
 An extremely difficult and RNG dependent game. One spout of bad luck and completely halt progress, and generally feel unfair. This is (supposedly) by design, which allows for a difficult challenge.
 A game that has decided to make me petrified of sounds scissors make, and rain.

Rain World is not:
 A metroidvania. You gain no significant boosts throughout the game, however it does reward exploration and curiousity. I feel the only exception to this would be two of the slugcats in Downpour.
 Perfectly designed. This game is covered with flaws, head to toe. While I love it dearly, I'd like to acknowledge some here.

Some Flaws with Rain World.
- The static screen-based camera can lead to some extremely unfair or downright impossible to avoid deaths. Yes, there is a mod to fix this issue, but I would like to bring it up here.
- Janky Controls, especially for a newer player. While they are purposely weird to simulate what it is like to be an animal lost in an unfamiliar world, they aren't exactly friendly to new players in some instances.
- Confusing and rather hard to navigate regions. While I love getting lost in some of Rain world's regions, this game has a severe lack of showing the player how to progress or where to go. For those who'd like a completely unguided playthrough, it can be rather difficult to even escape Outskirts.
- Some of the RNG related instances. Mostly in the form of where creatures will decide to perch whole cycle. This can be extremely frustrating and downright unfair in some instances.

Despite my negatively, I do hold this game extremely dearly, and would recommend it to anybody who'd like to give it a shot. However, just know this game may not be for everybody, and may not be for you. I do hope that if you do give this game a shot, try to enjoy it to the best of your abilities, for some of the experiences in this game will be some of the best.

I love this game so much. It is probably the most frustrating experience I have gone through, but I still keep coming back. 
   Deaths seem unfair and unexpected because of all the randomness in how creatures spawn and behave, but that also means that the same section of map can play completely differently each time. The controls seem extremely slow and clunky at first, but as you learn the different moves you can perform, it becomes fluid and cohesive. There is a lot of difficulty in the game that many people might not enjoy, but if you can get past all that, the game is really fun.
   Now, I'm gonna be honest and say I did use the Rain World wiki. quite a bit. 
   For the first 5 hours or so I did play without any help, but I got stuck and had no idea what to do. While I do recommend figuring stuff out first, don't be afraid to use the wiki. There's no use ruining your enjoyment of the game just to have a "pure" run of the game.
   Overall, it's really fun even though sometimes it makes you want to chuck your controller at the screen and never play it again.

I have majorly updated this review to be even better:
This is a 8.5/10, and my third favorite game of all time, BUT: [h1]I'm going to actually tell you if you'll like this game or not, BECAUSE IT IS NOT FOR EVERYONE[/h1] (no seriously), these are VERY important, and though the trailers and description make it somewhat clear I want to expand on it:

To enjoy this game you must be fine with these things:

- Dying A LOT, this is the major one. This game will kill you after 20 minutes of progression out of nowhere right next to a checkpoint and send you all the way back before you did it. This game is a type of difficulty you don't see a lot. I always play games on the hardest difficulties, and (at least in my opinion) very good at games, especially ones like Rain World at first glance. Rain World throws all the classic difficulty systems out the window though. Rain World's difficulty comes from addapting to new enviroments, learning enemy patterns, randomness, it's unforgiving nature, and survival (I.E. Finding food and not failing a janky parkour section).

- RNG, lots of RNG, ties in with last point.

- Getting lost and a ton of exploration, which is just as much of a con as much as it's a pro, it's just a preference. If you don't particularly like getting lost and exploring and all that jazz, go into the game for a bit, get past the first few areas, and if you dont like that aspect, use the Wiki maps, and you'll have a great time still.

(Added) - Purposefully jank mechanics. Rain World has one of the most jank and weird movement systems on purpose, and that can justifiably be frustrating to people. Even the combat is weird. You're mostly one shot to almost everything, and the combat involves finding spears, finding rocks, and throwing things at your enemies' weakpoints until they die. You don't get your spears back, you have to either find a new one or pull it back out of enemies, this is a type of combat I hadn't really seen before.

You have to be VERY patient and be willing to die A LOT if you want to beat this game, here are my recommendations:

(Scratch everything I put here previously): Play Survivor. The story makes more sense, and even though it may be frustrating at times, it's worth it. It's the type of game that makes the journey so hard that when you finally finish it, it's extremely liberating.

Don't play Hunter (hard mode) until you beat the game, it is not what you'd expect.

Other than that, this is my third or fourth favorite game of all time still deciding if it's better than Hollow Knight in my eyes (Update: It is after Downpour, though I have faith that Silksong will be better than Rain World), it's absolutely beautiful, the AI is jawdropping, the environments are fantastic, and even though I had no idea what was happening, the ending almost brought me to tears (mainly because of how god damn difficult it was getting there, and because the art was so damn good).



Absolutely fantastic game.

I love it! While it can sometimes be difficult, it is very unique in a way that other games that seem at first similar can never come close. You could just play it as a normal platformer game, but you would miss out on the entire idea of the game, and it would eventually become impossible to move forward. You have to learn the traits of each type of creature. In fact, each individual creature has it's own personality. You can befriend a predatory lizards by bringing them food, but be careful. If you manage to take the mask off a vulture, the lizards other mid-range predators will fear you, but the maskless vulture will chase you down. If you see the scavengers raising their spears, you know they don't trust you, and if you are too aggressive to them, them might send some members out to kill you. If you grab a flying squidcada, you can jump higher. If you can't reach an area, throw a spear into the wall and climb on it. Don't let the garbage worm take your spear, though. Good luck!

Wrote this coming off of my first play-though,

Rain world puts you in a situation where you are a lost little dude with no idea what/where the hell they are, hungry stomach, a world that you don't understand, and all you have to survive is a pile of debris and your wits.

This game is hands down the most refreshing game I've played in a long time. I don't think there is or will be another experience that is as lively, brutal, adventurous, mysterious, and amazing as this game. Went into this game mostly blind and, though it took quite a bit of time to get through this way, it was worth the journey. The replayability of this game is also amazing since there's many things to uncover you might have missed, plenty of slug cats to play as, and a fairly lively workshop and content community. 

I'd highly recommend everyone give this a shot, and even if it's not for you, it's a beautiful game that is unlike anything I've ever played. If you're like me and you've been thinking about it for a while but never really made up your mind on whether or not it'd be worth the time money and effort, go for it. It was absolutely worth every last minute and will be time and time again.

I really try to enjoy this game, and im still gonna continue playing it, but at certain point it just feels like a chore

imagine if super meat boy had a maximum timer after wich you die no matter what, and every time you die you lose 20 minutes of progress, at many points in time that's how rainworld feels

the game is just counter intuitive, even when you're supposed to learn how to play with just watching, it's like they set rules and then made them not work 50% of the time

-this game requires patience to do most things, yet you can't take your time because you would either be being chased by a creature half of the time, or about to get killed by the ingame timer (wich is randomized each day, so you may just have to suck it up and waste another day idling before you have enough time to go trough) and if you instead try to rush, there will always be an enemy camping to the other side of the zone, wich you have to either waste time that you don't have to go trough, or risk it and do a 50/50 of dying and starting again or finally crossing

-this game wants you to learn, yet everything (item spawns, enemy spawns, enemy movement, and enemy AI) is randomized every day, you may get lucky and go trough a zone completelly unharmed, or have to deal with bad spawns, and waste another hour or so dying and respawning over and over, the game also punishes experimenting, since dying lowers you karma level, something crucial to go between each zone of the game

-the tools you have are there, but way too limited, you have 3 slots to hold stuff, in most zones one will be occupied to hold an item you need to traverse the zone, and if you are trying to discover the lore of the game so will be the 3rd one (wich mind you, discovering the lore involves an awfull ammount of backtracking) you may say this is expectable since one is doing a hard challenge put on themselves, but when i have to go trough three times the ammount of torture just to understand what's happening ingame i'd just skip the lore part and try to reach the ''ending'' of the game instead

besides that, you have the most useless map you could ever imagine, why would you divide it in three different parts? why would you make the player's experience harder in anything that isn't the main aspect of the game itself instead of what counts as one of their only tools? eventually i got so tired of dealing with it that i had to sink into the wiki (getting spoiled major things too, because lord forbbid you get to discover something yourself in the game about exploration without walking 10 hours) just to know where should i even go to begin with, the lack of context and the  minimal help of the overseer didn't get me too far last time (he's literally gone for half of the zones you traverse, cmon)

the game is just a slug (no pun intended, i love slugcats) and at more than one point it just feels sisyphean to jump from one savespot to another, i know that more than one will say this game IS meant to be hard and that im tilting madly, i know the game is fun but if there's no progress after four hours maybe others can enjoy it but i cannot

TLDR: sometimes, this feels like the complete opposite of a game with how it expects you to handle it

i have bought the base game and the downpour expansion, and i will probably keep playing it further until i get to finish it if possible, until then, my looks on the game are not good

and to whoever says skill issue, go back to your cbt session or whatever game you need to defend next

I will preface the entire review that I did not get as far into the game as I would've liked, but I wanted to return it.
Rain World is absolutely gorgeous and mechanically amazing but with how punishing and grindy at times (if you're bad, which you will be if you just installed the game) I could not absolutely bear to play it more than 2 cycles at a time and did not enjoy more than a handful of minutes of my total playtime.
If you like incredibly punishing games with simple but very deep mechanics that are satisfying to learn and master, with stunningly good NPC AI and complex, interesting lore, you'll love it, but if you're not a part of the small ammount of people that would realistically enjoy the game you will absolutely loathe your time with it.
I don't recommend it to the majority of people, but I can see and understand where its fans are coming from.

Deceptively cute game with surprising atmosphere of a sense of fear.

I really thought I would enjoy this game, but it just wasn't doing anything for me. The map is confusing, many mechanics aren't explained (intentionally so, I'm sure, but still frustrating), hibernation locations (save spots) are seemingly arbitrarily laid out, enemies will one-shot you -- the final nail in the coffin for me was that even after almost two hours of gameplay and reaching an entirely different area (Industrial Complex) I still felt like I hadn't actually found anything interesting that was worth the exploration. I promise I'm not one of those people that NEEDS constant stimulation or something exploding spectacularly on-screen every couple minutes, but the lack of any kind of positive feedback for exploring just wasn't much fun -- it felt like all I would ever find were more enemies. Navigating through the rusty buildings is a good initial hook and quite beautiful, but the first couple hours of Rain World did nothing for me in terms of expanding on that hook or promising that there was something more beyond angry lizards in dilapidated areas. In fairness, it may get better later, but I'd rather refund it now before the 2hr mark and not take that chance.

A [b]chair[/b] is a piece of furniture with a raised surface used to sit on, commonly for use by one person. Chairs are most often supported by four legs and have a back; however, a chair can have three legs or could have a different shape. A chair without a back or arm rests is a [b]stool[/b], or when raised up, a bar stool. A chair with arms is an [b]armchair[/b] and with folding action and inclining footrest, a recliner. A permanently fixed chair in a train or theater is a [b]seat[/b] or, in an airplane, airline seat; when riding, it is a saddle and bicycle saddle, and for an automobile, a car seat or infant car seat. With wheels it is a wheelchair[14] and when hung from above, a swing. A chair for more than one person is a couch, sofa, settee, or "loveseat"; or a bench. A separate footrest for a chair is known as an ottoman, hassock or pouffe.

The chair is known for its antiquity and simplicity, although for many centuries it was an article of state and dignity rather than an article of ordinary use. "The chair" is still extensively used as the emblem of authority in the House of Commons in the United Kingdom and Canada, and in many other settings.

rain
I started out hating this piece of garbage. Then I started hating this game. And finally I began hating this masterpiece.

In short: Artful and unique, Rain World combines procedural animation and compelling storytelling to give one of best platformers I've played. If you were drawn into the worlds of Ori and the Blind Forest, or Hollow Knight, you will definitely enjoy this one as well. To describe it in few words, it is dynamic and powerful in presentation. Very highly recommend.


At Length: This game hits a lot of marks, and while it does have some shortcomings, they're overshadowed by the things it does right.

What does it do right?

- Procedural animation. A technique full of technical challenges to implement, but done so fantastically in Rain World. Every creature in the game moves according to how it's able to, rather than a pre-set animation. Creatures can lunge, flap, lose their grip on surfaces, ect. This will also have an effect on your Slugcat's own movement.

- Environmental storytelling. Adventurous types will find plenty of ways to get lost, and along the way, see interesting sights and learn a little bit more about the world they inhabit. There are mysteries to uncover, but I won't spoil them here. 

- Music. James Primate and the rest of their team have created a soundtrack that not only supplements the environmental storytelling, but engages the player with the events on screen. The choice to make the music dynamic itself lends greatly to that effect. I often listen to the tracks while not playing. 

- Content rich DLC. Buy downpour with this game. It vastly expands the content of the original game in all aspects. More music, more areas to explore, more Slugcats, more lore. Do it. 

- Art and design. Rain World is a work of art in and of itself. There are places I needed to stop passing through and just soak in. There are moments when I felt overwhelmed. At some point I cried. In addition to evoking emotions though, I was also impressed by the range of designs of creatures and elements of the environment. Enjoy such classics like: bees that tie you down, and an insect half the size of a Toyota Corolla. 

- Skill and exploration are rewarded. The game is a journey, and not one just based on travel. You'll figure out what things means and how to use them, and it's a good feeling when you do. Knowledge and a practiced hand are king when it comes to survival. There's also cool little things to find throughout the world. Challenges and expedition mode add more levels of knowledge and skill testing.

- Local co-op. Not a feature I make use of personally, but I see the value it in for others. Support games that bring people together. Jolly cooperation makes cold nights in the shelters better for everyone. Online co-op is not an official feature, but one that's possible through Steam Remote Play. Since that's a direct connect feature, you might experience some lag when the person you're connecting to is far away. 

- Community. The Rain World community kicks ass. So many talented folks, kind folks, supportive folks. Some of those folks went on to put their love and hard work into the DLC. The community is active and positive. Join the Rain World discord, there you can talk about your journey through the game, see the art that's posted every day, discuss lore, why Saint is the best Slugcat, or talk about mods.

- Mods. In addition to an active community overall, there's also an active modding community. Turn a terrifying foe into a clown, add whole regions to your game, or find entirely new Slugcats with new looks and mechanics. Be sure to thank or support those good nerds that make the content. 

What does it not do right?

- The game is unfair. That's not me complaining, there are points where circumstances align to destroy your Slugcat in sudden and sometimes funny ways. But sometimes it's just out of your control. It's the nature of the game, being as dynamic as it is. This might be cause for frustration among some people, and unfortunately, it's not helped by what I'll mention in the next section. However, it's an important part of overall feel of the game. I'll let you discover why.

- Controls can be somewhat vague, and the immobile camera can cause lack of awareness beyond the edge of the screen. The controls for the game are simple, but there's a lot of different movements you can do. A series of buttons you press can mean something if you're standing on the ground, and something else when you are climbing a pipe. This usually isn't an issue until you're hanging over a pit. It's remedied with practice, calm input, or changing your settings. There are also audio cues that help with the camera issue. Additionally, quality of life mods exist for both of these issues.

To conclude: I cannot recommend this game enough. It's beautiful, there's cool game design elements to it, the story is evocative, the music invigorating. Creatures and places that firmly belong in our memory. A vast, mysterious, terrifying world to explore... and through it all, you. The humble Slugcat. Going WAWA and inconveniencing calculators. Only those folks who don't like platformers at all, or get incredibly frustrated easily, would I say your experience with the game could be hit or miss. But otherwise, buy it. Play it. Support it. Become Slugcat. Can you feel it? The spear in your little hands? Your body squirmshing through the pipe? The wag of your tail? The- no, get back... leave me... it's too late, I'm... the rains are coming... I must...  I... WAAAAAAAAAAA!

Oh, and you can hit Pebbles with a rock, 10/10.

I may not be good at it, but I would buy it again in a heartbeat. Definitely recommended for anyone that likes difficult and atmospheric games :P
I want to eradicate Vultures with all my might.

-Fascinating & unique creatures with advanced AI, that make up an entire living breathing ecosystem. You are not the center of the world but rather just another creature living in it. Creatures interact with each other and the environment regardless of whether you are there to see it. You can enter an area to find a fight already taking place, or a predator can grab you and be dragging you back to its den only for an apex predator to grab them and fly off with them. Everything is unscripted and happens organically, resulting in a world that feels unpredictable and truly alive.

-A very large and detailed world to explore, with tons of variation between areas and challenges that will test your abilities. The environment is absolutely gorgeous to look at feels overwhelmingly atmospheric at times. All of the areas have something to offer and are a joy to explore.

-A hauntingly beautiful narrative and rich lore in a fascinating world. This game has one of the most unique and interesting worlds I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. It feels truly alien and unknowable.

-Replayability in the form of multiple campaigns (even more with the DLC) that take you through an altered version of the world as a different character at a different point in the timeline, with their own goals.

-Amazing soundtrack

Be warned: this game is difficult. You are not at the top of the food chain. The world is cruel and unforgiving. But if you can get past that, or if you like a challenge, this game will deliver and incredible and unforgettable experience.

This game is addicting. I lost my wife and kids to this. I lost my soul, I sold my house, I lost sweat and tears. I lost my friends because all I talk about is Rain World. My kids have stopped talking to me because I link everything they say to rain world. My child told me they have cancer and I said "rain world reference" and he immediately died. I got a severe drought warning on my phone and my children cried as I said "rain world reference." There will soon be a flood one day, and I know then, I just know, that my time will shine.

I tried to explain the lore to my children and one had an aneurysm, along with my fifth wife. The others have no recollection of that day, rain world reference included. 

I try to rid myself of this affliction, but the very act of ridding myself of the game draws me that much more into it, much like the ancients in their unending cycle of life and death. What a terrible fate I have found myself in, forever trapped in the cyclical nature of my own making, and forever alone in facing it. A drug that cannot be flushed out of the system. A system that acts like a drug. The game reflects on the unending of all things, and the madness that comes with the imprisonment of eternity. And I sit here, writing this, trapped in a hell of my own design, driven mad by the unending nature of my prison. I write, well aware that I will use these fingers to pluck upon the keys of my laptop once more, and perpetuate the cycle that brings me both ecstasy and madness in equal length. 

I miss my family. I miss my life. I bid my old ways adieu, and launch the game once more.

Honestly one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had, Rain World is a very harsh game in which you'll have to learn and adapt to the ecosystem in order to survive, it may be a little bit hard in the start, to the point where you might even quit, but if you manage to overcome all the threats and difficulties this world has to offer, you'll experience one of the best story and gameplay I've ever seen in a videogame. Despite all this, Rain World is still not a perfect game, some of your deaths might feel cheap and it's heavy reliance on rng may feel a bit bullshit at times, but as time goes on and you gain more experience, this will stop being an issue. So yeah, what an incredible game.

This game is a Masterpiece it is near perfect, it is so unique and really makes you feel like you're the prey rather then the predator unlike most games. Every single button you press is a decision Do i kill that salamander? do I run away? do I distract it by throwing a rock? do I throw food at it to distract? do I jump over it? This game is so punishing it is the most punishing, and one of the most difficult games i have ever played. But that difficulty is necessary if it was easy it wouldn't feel like you are the prey, if it was easy it wouldn't feel realistic. This game feels like a genuine world it has an environment so complex no other game is anywhere near the level of complexity. The atmosphere in this game is so good, You go from ancient civilizations, to abandoned cities, to beaches all of which are amazing. There is even an area where if you have not done something yet, you have to wander through nothing but darkness, where the only noise, and light is the enemies, making you use the enemies to navigate around. On top of all of this this there is an absurd amount of content for just one game each slugcat is it's own unique experience.  I cannot give this game enough praise just know that if you buy this game you are in for a tough ride.

Rain World is the uncanny but perfect mix of your most intense fever dream and yout most delightful primal comfort fantasy, all wraped in tons of playable content. It's minimalistic yet complex; Brutal and cute; It's nostalgic, smooth and shiny, but still distopian and dirty; Welcoming and enchanting, but unbeliavably punishing to new players.

Basically, it evokes morbid games like Limbo and INSIDE, but gives you the chance to fight back and thrive; But make no mistake: The instant deaths and opressing atmosphere are still there.

The sooner you know your starting place, the quicker you can challenge the ones above you in the food chain.

And, of course, it is properly accompanied by a Dark Ambiance OST, complete with synth stuff and all.

Go play this game NOW.
Truly one of the games of all times

first off, Do Not Buy without a controller. The controls on keyboard are unresponsive at best, and flabbergasting at worst.
Usually in order for a 2d platformer to be fair, controls should be tight and it should be clear how you interact with objects. 
stuff such as the pipes that you have to crawl into, the items you throw, the branches you grapple, they're all a hat toss if what you want will even work. thrown objects can't be aimed and it's hard to tell if it's being thrown -x or +x. coming out of a pipe onto a grappled edge will sometimes just cause you to fall, needing to repeat an entire portion of the map. Multiple times. Pressing down in order to start a long jump will sometimes cause you to just walk off an edge instead. All this on top of having maybe 5 minutes between rain storms, having to collect 7 pieces of food with the horrible aiming (god forbid you think that the tiny dragonflies that light up and act like prey are prey), and being far away from a shelter trying to make the same jump 60 times because this time its chosing to grapple and climb onto the pipe you're trying to go into without your imput quickly made me decide to opt for a refund. 
I'm sure all this is smooth as butter with a controller, but I'd rather fight against monsters rather than whether I will be allowed to jump or it will just decide that I'm too close to a wall so I have to sit there grappled to it

Rain World is an opportunistic predator that lives on the internet.
It hides out of view, usually underground, but will wave the cute protagonists, OST and artwork as bait for its prey - ADHD neurodivergents currently lacking a hyperfixation. Once they approach, the game may take its time to react, but upon contact, prey are dragged into the ground, only re-emerging after days or even weeks. All individuals who re-emerge will attempt to coerce others into "playing Rain World," implying the animal itself may be parasitic and using its influence to gather more hosts.

An accurate simulation of the average new york subway rat's journey to die in the sewers.

Rain World is a game about trying to maneuver your rodent through the long-dead remains of civilization while avoiding starvation, predators, and the inevitable rain that'll smash you into a fine paste.

Now, a lot of people love this game, me included. However, it definitely isn't for everyone.
Still it's worth a shot, and if you don't enjoy the feeling of this masochism simulator you can refund it and move on. 

If you do want to get into the game, I have a bit of advice: You will die, and you will die A LOT. Try to learn from your deaths and think about what you could have done differently.

Every time I feel a raindrop I get a panic attack. Every time I go into a building I check the ceiling. I carry a rock with me at all times. I constantly watch the shadows while in open areas, least I be taken by a creature from the skies. I avoid all lager bodies of water lest I be ambushed by a creature from the depths. I always have a pearl in my stomach. I fear anything that is red. While underground I listen for the snapping sounds of metal, lest I be dragged away by a horrific beast. I watch the walls, lest I get jumped by a camouflaged monster. I praise the corn, for it sustains me. I fear the grass for it devours me. I hate deer for they betray me. I got fired last week, my boss said "YOU ARE ACTING LIKE A COMPLETE LUNATIC YOU NEED PROFESSIONAL HELP" he was immediately squired by a king vulture because he didn't listen to my warnings. Oh well, he was at minimum karma anyways, I say to myself as I do a backflip spear throw to reach the roof of the building and escape through a pipe. My extreme paranoia and cowardice has let me survive but no one will listen to me, fine let the lizards devour them, more time for me to escape. My life is in shambles.

This is a game you need to want to play to actually play it, it is a GREAT game and i personally love it however u will most likely wont enjoy it or play it for long if u personally genuinely are not interested in playing the game.
I do recommend the game if u WANT to play it, it is fab and the DLC is also super fun. The base game consists of three cats, one being easy mode (Monk), the base one (Survivor)  which i recommend playing unless u really have skill issue and then (i think) if u beat the game as either one u unlock one which is more speed run and survival based (Hunter). It took me personally 20h to beat Survivors campaign and it was really fun, i did resort to using a tutorial at some parts cause i felt mega stuck and i recommend u do the same if stuck but other than that just play the game, OR DONT PLAY IT AS U WANT! 
From there i tried the DLC adding 5 new slug cats with their own "Powers" quirks is if u will,
Gourmand, fat, can craft, can body slam enemies. Artificer, keeps getting hunted can EXPLODE!. Rivulet, super fast cat neat mobility but the RAIN comes sooner. Spearmaster, infinite spears, no mouth, eats with spears and Saint, Pacifist, long tongue and then God hood eventually.
I didnt beat all the campaigns yet but the one i did play are super fun loved them, i did however try all the slug cats and each one is unique (except Monk he is just easy mode) and great fun. The world is huge and the art style is stunning, really pretty and fun game.
Some downsides i do have to say is that the game can get u omega stuck and not soft lock but ur just lost u got no clue what u are doing, and thats normal i fixed that with a tutorial to get me back on track, and also the game is simply unfair sometimes lol and thats part of the charm but sometimes is SUCH bs.

Simply, only get the game if u are intrested and are willing to push through and play it otherwise dont bother cause u will not enjoy it. I do recommend the DLC but get it only after you have completed Survivors or Monks campaign. Very nice game.

Joke review: Never finished the game, got fucking folded by everything including angry water, and despite having both Scolopendrphobia and Myriapodophobia only one enemy is the game triggers it and its fucking a collection of dust spiders hiding in the dark.

Real review: Borderline unfair with a lot of the deaths its a game that does apologise, doesn't explain itself, and leaves you feeling lost and confused. Perfectly simulates what its like to be a much smaller animal in a large ecosystem, especially near the bottom of the food chain. Gamers love it, game journalists hate it.

i love this game, however it is an abusive relationship.
the music and the art and the atmosphere are beautiful and the vibes are immaculate.
the ecosystem is complex and interesting and immersive and really feels alive.
the community is awesome and the dlc and mods add so much to the experience.
the story and worldbuilding is very interesting and it raises lots of questions, and the game will not give you the answers easily. you will not understand much at all on your first playthrough. it will take hundreds of hours of exploring every corner of this enormous world over many campaigns, and lots of curiosity and determination to piece together the story. (or look on the wiki if you just value your time)
the movement system is very complex but you must learn all of it on your own (or look up the nearly 100 page long document that documents it)

this game is an experience, but it is certainly not for everyone.
it is hard and extremely punishing. 
the tutorial teaches you only the bare minimum you need to survive and you have to work everything else out for yourself.
this game does not care for you. it does not value your time or your sanity. it will not forgive you for your mistakes. as one user has said, it does not hold your hand; it stomps on your fingers and watches them bleed. it is unfair. you will die. a lot. you will only progress through determination and strategy.
other than yellow, there is not much direction and you will often be lost.
as you progress through the game enemies will get stronger and more numerous and you will stay as weak as you started, so you must use the skills and experience you gained on your journey.
and all the challenge is worth it. the first time i reached the top of 'the wall' was the first time i have ever felt awe and when i finished the final campaign was the first time a game made me cry.
it was worth every moment.
this game is an amazing journey that you will never forget.

The game's gameplay definitely isn't for everyone, it takes some time to get used to. The lack of real instruction on what to do other than surviving can cause it to be difficult to keep motivation to play. It's "relatively" easy to survive in the starting region, and since you don't know any other goals it can stop being interesting. There are some spoiler-free ways to figure out which direction you should go if you want, such as gameplay videos or some short reddit post. Also, the community art and videos are fantastic, even if you don't end up playing the game the pmv's and animations are worth checking out.

In all seriousness, Rain World may be my favorite game. It is brutally difficult, and that almost scared me away from playing it. But once I got into it, I was immersed into a world that is somehow so alien to us humans, but somehow so familiar and relatable. The lore of this game, without spoiling anything, drives home how small and insignificant your player character is. Realizing the scope of the world you play and and beyond is akin to imagining infinity. The Story of the game is intellectually engaging and interesting. The artwork is smooth and coherent. The gameplay is brutal, but rewarding.

Play Rain World if you desire to be lost in a world that will amaze all brave enough to explore it.

This is a difficult review to write. Hundreds of hours in this game and yet I still feel hardly qualified to recommend it to another person. Dont get me wrong, its an incredible game. More people should play it. Should you?

Perhaps.

Ill start with the details. The pixel art looks incredible. The sound design is great. Its rare to see the full potential of procedural animation realized, but Rain World does it. Every part of this world looks and feels alive. The excellent AI of the games various inhabitants contributes to that as well.

The gameplay is a more complicated topic. Thats not a cop-out way of saying the game isnt fun to play  it is. But its also infuriating. Death comes for you easily and often unfairly. Its not a roguelike, but if you cant stand roguelikes I would hesitate to recommend this game to you.

The controls are in a similar situation. Theyre not bad, and theres an incredible depth of skill that can be achieved with them  once youre done exploring this game on your own, check out the wikis movement guides. Ive come to enjoy the controls, but only after a great deal of frustration.

This frustration is a core part of Rain World. You could not tell the story that the developer is trying to tell, could not provide the profound experience that Rain World does, without this frustration.

All the same, Id recommend to everyone that they enable the Remix plugin on the Classic preset immediately. The quality-of-life changes this gives are invaluable, and dont diminish the experience in any way. The other options can be tried on a case-by-case basis.

The Downpour DLC is absolutely worth it, and enabling the More Slugcats plugin that it grants you access to right out of the gate will provide worthwhile additional content in all your playthroughs. You should start with Survivor, the white slugcat, regardless.

If you can stick with it through to the end, Rain World will absolutely be worth the time you put into it. 9/10.

I really wish I could love this game, we have had lot of wonderful memories together. The art, the music, the memories~ 

But them I remember that every day it beats the piss out of me with its bare knuckles. 

Review at 22 hours in, still on my first run though this is normal from what I see. 

This isn't a hard because its challenging, though it has it's moments. what it is truly; is a creators vision not aligning with game design foundations. It's a GREAT vision, and although I've cut my life expectancy in half from the blood pressure, I love the good that's in this game. The issue stands that there are some serious game design faux pas embedded in the bones of this. Extreme punishment for failure, poor signposting (not talking about yellow), crucial mechanics are not explained. Crucify me if you like for this, but it's also a wiki game; just because something *can* be discovered in the game, doesn't mean it *will* be.

If the goal was to create an immersive experience around being a powerless part of nature; frustration is the enemy of immersion. There are ways to punish and reward the player for engaging with your creation that don't cause them to be frustrated and "switch-off". Instead, it chooses to "reward" you with an opportunity to experience the game for longer than 15 minutes without giving your head another contusion.

I will finish this game, and I plan to finish all the other stories as well; but it is a violently abusive relationship, and i can't in good conscience recommend anyone attempt to *play* this.

Watch an experienced play through, preferably without commentary. Or turn on all the remix mods to say "fuck you" to the devs for designing the default experience around the highest levels of play. 

I love this game for what it does right, great experience, great art, design, soundtrack. Terrible game play.

****
EDIT
****
I just completed the survivors story and, now I can only push my last point harder. This game would have been far more enjoyable had I not gone in blind. 

There were no answers in the core gameplay, you won't get your questions resolved. You have to extend your gameplay out across multiple characters or ludicrous fetch-quests, at which point the "Big moments" turn from being amazing spectacles and strong resolutions of a characters plot to:

"...OH thaaaats what was happening, huh I guess that's neat"

Would have been nice to know the significance while it was happening, but eh.

([i]This is awfully formatted and poorly explained. Read at your own discretion.[/i])

[h1]This is a warning to those who plan to buy the game[/h1]


This game will absolutely[b] not hold your hand [/b]or[b] be kind to you [/b]

This game will [b]eat you alive[/b] and enjoy doing so.

It will feel [b]unfair and RNG based[/b], but that's how it is. It's supposed to feel RNG based, it's simulating an [b]environment[/b], not a planned layout.

Your movement will feel slippery and sluggish but you must remember; you're a [b]creature with faults[/b], not the [b]perfect war soldier[/b] or a [b]brave italian plumber[/b].

If you refuse to adapt or change your ways; [b]you will be punished accordingly by the environment[/b].

If you need to do research on the game before you buy and play, go ahead. Many argue you shouldn't, many argue you should; just pick your poison.


[b]I have too many friends (on my Steam List and IRL friends) who bought Rain World and:[/b]


[b]A) Stopped playing after the first hour or so[/b]


[b]B) Who asked me to play with/help them and learned nothing about how the game functions.[/b]
(Don't let this stop you from playing with friends though; if you like the feeling of having company, go ahead. What am I going to do, shut off your computer? Keep in mind though, the original experience was supposed to be played [b]Solo[/b])


If you truly are still planning to buy this game, watch gameplay of the first hour so you can determine if you should buy this game. Hell, if you have a friend(s) who likes the game (and has the DLC, since Co-Op is only featured [b]in the DLC[/b],) ask to remote play with them!

[b]A few key notes to keep in mind;[/b]

Demotivation is common and may occur often if you are not strong-willed and/or curious (those these traits may not be the sole reason why people are motivated to play the game.)

Keep your ears and eyes peeled. Listen for a change in the music.

If you do die, think of a way around your problems and don't suddenly blame the game for your fault; mistakes usually happen due to the player's lack of knowledge of game mechanics.

Rain World is one of those games where you need to find your own reason to enjoy it. It's an unforgiving survival game where you will die, die, die, die again, die some more, and die even after you've put in 100+ hours. This isn't a possibility. It's a promise. You may wonder what the point of all this dying and struggle is. Why you're here, why you're trying so hard for seemingly no purpose. But the reason is this: whatever you want it to be.

Yes, there's a story. But the game isn't going to go out of its way to give it to you. You'll have much more fun if you go in with the attitude of a sandbox game, finding your own niche and enjoyment in the mechanics and game world. Whether it be killing wildlife, taming wildlife, exploring the many beautiful environments, scavenging for any scraps of lore you can find, learning all the movement tech... 
It's a beautiful and charming game. But it's not going to be for you if you can't find a reason to hit "continue" even after your tenth death in a row to same exact dumbass lizard.

If you're still reading and considering this game, here's a few spoiler-free tips to finding the story. :]
- Go as far RIGHT and UP as you possibly can. You can choose to go right first, or up first, but both paths will be unforgiving. The only difference is how many chances the game gets to punish you. 
- You'll probably find something important in you go straight right. It won't be helpful until you go as far up and right first. 
- Colored pearls have lore in them. 
- The little yellow eye-guy is only helpful for general directions, 'cause it sucks at giving you specific ones. Ignore it if you're lost.

I think it's time to finally recommend this, after beating almost all campaigns of both the base game and DLC.

Rain World is tough, it's not for everyone nor does it hold your hand. This is by design and if you stick with it, you WILL be rewarded with a rich and emotional story.

It's a game about learning and surviving. You'll be dying a LOT, but especially in the first campaigns, The Survivor and The Monk, there is little consequences for it aside being stooped down a few levels of Karma.

But each new cycle you show up, you will have learned more and you will get better.

Don't forget, you are just a lost, young Slugcat after all. Survival has to be learned. If you give yourself the time and patience, you'll have an unforgettable adventure ahead.

The game also has an absolutely fantastic modding community. Thanks to mods like "Dress my Slugcat" I was able to play as my own characters, which was honestly a big bonus.
There is also "Cutscene Slugcats" that are vanilla cats reimagined to be closer to how their artwork looks and it's amazing.
A lot of talented people are also working on custom regions, which I love.

Overall, big thumbs up. Love this game to bits.

I can't say for sure whether you'll like this one. Some might come away with the impression it was a platformer, an ecosystem simulator, even a rage game. For me, this is an immersive, spiritual experience. Never has a game so perfectly put me in the mind of its protagonist, an animal trying to survive in a world of animals doing the same, not one of us significantly more important than any other. Pair that with some of the best environmental storytelling I've ever seen (in ANY medium) and you're left with a true piece of art. Give it a shot: either you'll find the same transformative experience I had or you won't.

This is, perhaps, the most phenomenal concept for a game I've ever seen.

It has lots of unusual decisions which may seem awful at the first glance, but the deeper you get into the game, the more you realize how absolutely brilliant is each of these moments at making it feel like a brutal and unforgiving ecosystem, which is exactly what devs aimed to do. The slugcat doesn't get any new abilities throughout the game, rather it is the player who learns to survive in this world by all means necessary, up to the point where it eventually becomes its new home. And that once again precisely represents the plot, where the player is just a little slugcat that is completely unaware of all the dangers in this new, cruel world, not understanding a single thing at first, and then learning more and more over the time, until it eventually doesn't even need to go back to its previous home anymore.

The artstyle in this game is beautiful, and despite the relatively simple graphics, it still looks amazing. [spoiler]I know the most popular example of the game's stunning graphics is the top of The Wall, but I would rather say the artstyle is at its peak during the entirety of Sky Islands, especially in that glowy rooms (you know the ones ig)[/spoiler]

The lore is great as well, though you will probably have to watch a few videos explaining it because the game itself doesn't really explain it, in fact trying to straight up hide it from the player. I won't talk about the lore much because I want everyone reading this to play the game without seeing any spoilers so they can enjoy (and suffer) it fully.

Overall, Rain World isn't for everyone, but if you approach it with the right mindset and have some patience for the first few hours, you're gonna have some of the best experience of your entire life. And also, the Downpour dlc fixed most of the moments that were straight up frustrating and unfair, so be sure to check it out. It'll be worth it.

This game is unbelievably difficult. It'll throw a vulture at you when you haven't got a spear, have a wiggly worm thing with 2 glowing white eyes hold you underwater till you drown, put you right between two lizards, or just deny you food until the rain comes pouring down. You will cry, seethe, mald, scream, and lay in despair for your little slugcat and his/her never ending nightmare. This game though feels so rewarding to get enough food to hibernate, or trade with a scav. To explore its unloving landscape though treacherous is a godsend to gaming's rather bland levels and layouts that have permeated recent games. I'm only at the beginning and this makes me want to pull my hair out, in a good way though lol. The only thing I can say that's bad about this game is that multiplayer is only apart of the DLC.
The learning curve for this game is quite steep and you WILL struggle. But once you get the hang of everything it becomes much easier

where do i begin?
originally, i got this game i think 3 years ago? but because of my old laptop the game was more laggy than i can handle, i only got the the second to last room in the first area leading to the next one. Now, however, i have a new laptop, more experience with platformer's, and the privilege to bond over the game with friends. I dove back in, full force, and dont regret it.
The art direction is amazing, the enemy ai feels natural (with a few exceptions but nothing major), and the story, god's the story is something you wont expect.

But i will be honest, at times you will hate the game, you will feel anger, despair, tension, and fear. You will gnash your teeth at the unfairness of it all and wonder if you should quit. But thats also the appeal. You are prey in a world of predators, the world is against you and rarely works with you. There will be ones who welcome you, but not for long. While the vanilla game has so much content, downpour adds even more. Enriches the game even further.

So if you are looking for a game where it hates you, yet rewards you all the same, try it, and see where it leads you. And if you finish every campaign, the workshop offers endless options, you will not get bored for a very, very long time.

This is a game like no other. And it is a hard and frustrating game at first. It might not be for some people. But if you are feeling ready to face the challenge and get deep into this fascinating world, I can assure you that this will be one of the best games you'll every play.
Its amazing procedurally generated animations, its fascinating areas, the hard but satisfying controls, an AMAZING story and lore... there's no limit to how much you can play this game, it never gets boring (and the modding community does a great job too)
Go, try it for yourself, and buy the DLC too, it adds a TON of content

A difficult but fun platformer/exploration game, with a unique art style, great music, and interesting atmosphere. The DLC adds a lot of content, with many new characters with unique playstyles and stories, as well as new game modes which add tons of replayability. I somewhat dislike aspects of the DLC content, with Spearmaster's campaign having many text logs which I find annoying compared to the more natural storytelling of the base game. The Remix options I also find to be a bit too skewed towards lowering the difficulty through game and UI tweaks - there are 3 presets and I find even the "Vanilla" one to be a bit much IMHO, but that can be changed by adjusting the individual settings. I personally wouldn't recommend using the Remix options on a first playthrough. Modding support looks to be great, with Workshop support and a settings page in the main menu to adjust individual mod options.

The base game's main strength but also greatest weakness is it's obtuseness; you are left mostly on your own to find out what you need to do and how to get there. This results in a frustrating yet rewarding first playthrough. There are some areas (such as Farm Arrays), where a new player has no idea what they need to do to move forward, which can either ruin the experience (by them giving up or googling the solution) or be extremely satisfying when they solve it.

Edit: Forgot to mention, but default Keyboard keybinds are awful. I immediately rebound them to WASD + Space and ,  / to use my right hand for Grab Throw. I strongly recommend adjusting them or using a controller if you prefer.

I enjoyed learning how to play, exploring the game, unraveling the story and seeing all the complex creatures from this game and how they work, but the game is hard, even stressful at times and you don't always understand how to progress. I have played many hard games at my life but this one was a real challenge.

I love this game deeply, and it's so far been an amazingly beautiful and challenging experience. Anyone interested in a mix of Ori and the Blind Forest, Hollow Knight, and Celeste, give Rain World a try. One major thing I'd like to note is that, without any prior knowledge of goals, the plot, or the mechanics, the game can be confusing and downright punishing to new players that have absolutely no clue where to go and what to do. Please have no shame in looking at guides, maps, and asking questions. Lots of players will say to avoid all that at any cost to avoid spoiling yourself. But the thing is, you can't experience the many aspects of a game you can't beat. I would have never been able to complete the game at all without the use of maps and guides because I had literally zero idea of what was happening.
Have fun Rain Worlding!

P.S.

Rain World has stuck with me.

The first time I saw it was in my mid-childhood when I was... somewhere between six and ten years old. The second time I saw it was 14 months ago. Now I have over 500 hours in-game and at least fivefold that amount I've dedicated to Rain World outside of playing. It continues to stick with me, the same way it has from the start.

Personally, I consider Rain World to be more of a work of art than a game. It is absolutely unrelenting, disheartening at times, and it is not afraid to punish the player for events in or out of their control, but above all of that, Rain World is unforgettable. I will always recommend it to anyone who can get their hands on it.

In this game you play as a weird little creature called slugcats. 
You are in the middle of the food chain. 
You need to survive and find your purpose.
Along the way find various other creatures to feed on, fight, team up with, run from, etc. 
There are 8 different slugcats, each with their unique gimmick. They all also have a different story that happens at a different time. The world and locations are the same but seeing all the changes in the environment at a different point in the timeline is easily the best part of the game. Absolute peak environmental storytelling.


Your first run in this game will mostly just be like a rage game where you'll be dying alot until you master the platforming, the layout of the map and rng is in your favor. 
You need to really go out of your way to find actual lore. Your character will go through their own journey but it's not really related to the bigger picture.
But all the characters you unlock after that have a role to play and bring change to the world one way or another. Change which you can experience by the other characters that come afterward along the timeline. Its a very unique experience no other game come close to recreate.
If your up for a challange then hell yeah, play this.

This is a soft recommendation.

This game is brutal. Not just hard, a lot of the game is actively unfair. Enemies spawn in random locations, dying sets you further back than progressing pushes you forward, and it hides a lot of important information from you. But there's something refreshing about all that. The game doesn't want you to succeed, and it doesn't care if you fail. It doesn't feel like it's hostile, so much as... indifferent. Enemies will ignore you if something easier to catch is near them. They'll fight over resources, or just because. A lot of the game is observing enemy patterns. Almost like you're part of a broader ecosystem, which is a feeling I can't say a lot of other games have given me. 

I love this game, but it's not for every one.

The exploration in the game is fun, however the karma mechanic is such a poorly designed mechanic it makes Riot games look like a competent company. Instead of doing anything interesting when you die, the game takes away one level of karma, which has a max level of 5. All karma is used for is opening karma gates, and their sole existence is to stop the player's progression if they've died. Considering how easy it is to die to something off screen, it just makes the game feel so much more frustrating then it has any right to be. 

Fortunately, you can disable the karma requirement for gates in the remix menu, and I highly suggest you do should you decide to play this game. Aside from karma however, the game as mentioned before is pretty bs a lot of the time, enemies camping in locations you need to go to in order to progress is a common sight, and unless you have a nice even strip of ground you can basically forget about combat, as there is no aim assist or any aiming whatsoever outside of basic left/right.

In order to actually beat the game though, you have to do by far one of the worst platforming sequences I've ever had the displeasure of playing. Basically you're in a zero gravity area and have to jump between vines to vines avoiding these big spider things and any terrain with blue "x"s. If you touch them, it's insta death, and there's no checkpoint for like 15 screens. Gravity randomly switches on and off, and even when you jump there's a chance all your momentum gets eaten. This part of the game really does just feel like it's padding for time, and I ended up not finishing it since it's just not fun to play. 

Oh and you remember that karma requirement disable option? Yeah it doesn't work on the "Gate" in the final area of the game, you have to unlock the extra 5 karma levels by doing this garbage platforming area. The worst part? The ending is a 20 minute room where all you do is hold down. No fast travel option either, so when you get to this point and realise you're not allowed through, get ready to have to go 5 hours to and from (each, not combined) to the zero gravity area, then back to the ending area.

Final verdict? Just watch a youtube video of the full game. The gameplay consists of mindlessly walking with the occasional avoiding of enemies, or sitting around waiting for an enemy camping a choke point to either go away or for it to kill you. Instead of wasting 32$ on this, you could instead buy Hollow Knight AND Terraria and get significantly more fun out of either of those games.
