It is good... but it may be extremely frustrating, temporarily. I know much of my first playthrough was!
This was due to a lack of knowledge. The game isn't complex, but it doesn't teach you in the way most games do. You have to learn, and my recommendation is to try to eat or experiment with everything you find. The movement system is very complex and I don't understand most of the tricks you can do, but basic things like backflips and dropping items is something the game will not teach you but you should work out how to do.

The world is large. Even larger with DLC. You may find you have spent a lot of time travelling for nothing, and you have to be ok with that; the game has no character based progression, so if you go somewhere not needed for the story you are wasting your time, except for that your knowledge of the map will grow. You may feel like you're softlocked in some cases, but that is almost definitely due to your inexperience in dealing with the situations you're presented with, and you will overcome it. Do not anger the noodle flies.

When you start the game, a gooberous creature will lead to towards something. Know that there is little there of direct benefit to you, so expect to have to turn back. But I would recommend following anyway.

The DLC triples what you get out of the game so I believe it is definitely worth it. 6 (well, actually 7) more campaigns. If you found your first playthrough painful, I think you'll find the next ones are much more enjoyable as you learn more and more about how to beat the challenges the game throws at you. Even though the game gets harder it'll feel easier. Vultures become much less scary when you realise how sluggish their attacks are :)

In 42 hours, I've probably said more "wtf?" than I've done in any other game combined. 

I adore the fact that the world of Rain World just does not care about you. You're but a creature that exists in this world, but if you did not - nothing much would change. The cycles would continue as they had, just without you.

The combat is lovely, it's very carnal and basic, but we're basic creatures, sometimes fighting other basic creatures. Despite this the combat is well done, it's nice to get into fights, it's nice trying to learn how a creature behaves to avoid it.

The controls are amazing as well. So many mechanics that you simply learn by doing or by discovering them accidentally. The game provides you with very little information, you have to learn the rest.

The base Remix for Quality of Life things has tips and tricks during loading screens. After playing around 30 hours without it, it felt really patronizing after I turned it on for it to tell me things that I had learned the "hard way". I would really suggest playing with the tips and tricks turned off at first, and if you feel frustrated playing the game, turn them on.

It is shaping up to be a GOAT game.
Incredible game. You'll be tempted to give up ~5 hours in, but look up the movement guide and watch some videos - incredibly rewarding to push thru

The gameplay is designed to be non linear but this game takes it way too far. Even using online resources it is damn near impossible to navigate and to know whether you're making progress or if you are going in the wrong direction, leading to hours of backtracking. The game is criticised for its difficulty, but the real difficulty is knowing where to go. It's fair to be killed if you play poorly, but most of the game is just spent dying over and over again in the same difficult spots, ruining any chance for the game to be immersive. Would recommend as a cheaply made free game, would not recommend as a 50 dollar game after DLCs are purchased.

Edit: (Mild Ending Spoilers Ahead)
After completing the game I have changed my mind, the game is even worse than I thought. The ending is dragged on so much longer than it needs to be and is not well guided. I spent ten minutes swimming down (you are supposed to do at the ending) and gave up because I assumed that the ending of a game wouldn't have you hold down for ten minutes. I then swam back up only to realise 10 minutes later that that doesn't work either. I then swam back down 10 minutes, then another 10 minutes before finally making it to the swimming simulator 2 where I had to swim down another 10 minutes. Then the game ended abruptly with me having no idea what it was trying to convey in the ending cut scene other than some kind of happy ending. Needless to say I would strongly not recommend this game for it's poor design, lack of guidance, grind heavy aspects, and utterly insane price tag.

This game is a meat grinder and does not deserve to be reviewed as highly or praised as much as it is.

Is it pretty? Yes.
Is the AI technically impressive? Absolutely.
Does the game punish every failure and mistake like an abusive parent beating their child with a belt for getting the wrong size wrench out of the toolbox. Yeah pretty much.

The wrench analogy is appropriate, because this game is RNG heavy so it's hard to know what the "right" thing to do is.

The "Karma" system as its called isn't some oopsy woopsy mistake, it completely ruins the game and should never have been added to begin with. Why does dying REVERT PROGRESSION? What game does that, why would any game do that? It's like they made crashing a game and losing 2 hours of progress because you forgot to save an official mechanic.

Oh you died? Guess you need to go an entire day gathering food and you better not die again or you backslide even further. 

There's a reason so many positive reviews need to frontload the "This game isn't for everyone" line. It's because the game is too opaque for most people, and that's a failure of the game, not a quirk. It doesn't even teach you about the karma system you have to fucking look that shit up so you'll be confused why you're losing progress at first to begin with.

This can take a good amount of time depending on how much you need to farm. HOWEVER dying makes you lose a Karma level.  So you could die faster than you gain since a lot of things are instant death, I get flustered at the loss, and fail even harder and now I have karma level 1 and the door I need to go through requires 5, ugh.

to make matters worse is if you have a busy life and need to quit midway, you lose karma, crash? lose karma. So, I'd recommend getting a mod that permanently fortifies your karma so you won't have to deal with this struggle and turn it off when you decide to do expeditions.

This is such an amazing game. Certainly one of my top favorites! As infuriating and difficult as the game can be sometimes, the sheer amount of effort, style, and thought put into every enemy, creature, and environment makes up for it about as much as a million dollars would be as compensation for destroying your car. The story is vague, but made clear(ish) through environmental storytelling. I mean, I haven't felt this much wonder towards a game since I played Hollow Knight, especially after getting the (without going into spoilers) "Ascension" ending. I can easily understand why this game isn't for everyone, as only 9.8% (at the time of me writing this review) of all players have gotten the "Ascension" ending, but I can assure you that it was amazing for almost everyone who has. It's slow pace, and obscure mechanics, as well as unknown creature behaviors, can lead to feeling helpless, and at the bottom of the food chain. The largest struggle I had with the game was learning the mechanics and trying not to rage quite during situations like dying over 20 times in a single area. This game doesn't tell you much, but for every unique death, and biome explored, and every mechanic discovered, you learn. I could honestly gone on for a very long time about this game, but I will wrap it up with this....
If you love exploration, well thought out worlds, games with passion put into them, or just love a challenge, PLEASE play this game, and do it BLIND (I seriously can't stress this enough, don't look up stuff about it).
One final note... A tip: sometimes it's important to slow down and observe things around you, and try an idea you may have, it'll teach you a lot in Rain World.

[h1]You can (not) survive. Embrace it![/h1]
The less you know before playing, the better. Keep outside help, especially a wiki, to a minimum, as information is the crux of progression in this game. Don't stop yourself completely from seeking it, though, as the "no-spoilers" grift I'm going for is not completely inflexible.

With gorgeous pixel-art visuals inspired by graffiti, Rain World is filled with death and mystique, so going in with a fatally curious mindset is absolutely for the better. One of the game's standout choices is how far it goes to connect the player to their avatarthe game hands out nearly zero information beyond what the slugcat could believably know. The player's own abilities, in a similar fashion, are rudimentarily universal to a point where they can initially feel obtuse; it crams a lot into just three keys. Tutorialization is kept to a minimum, which can compound with alien systems like the movement and lead to death and frustration.
However, it is this that captured me and transformed the game into being about learning to survive and master a once-utterly alien ecosystem through your numerous deaths. Compounded with a beautiful "techno-Mayan" (dev's words, not mine) environment with a past that continues to deepen the further you travel, Rain World has become one of the most gruelingly fantastic experiences I've had the joy (and suffering) of playing through.

This game drops you into a fantastical ecosystem that is as intricate as it is deadly.  It's a hard game for sure, and it does not hold your hand in any way.  Beyond the basic controls, this game explains very little, but there are a ton of little movement optimisations and tricks to be discovered through experimentation.  Completely recommend.  The world feels both empty and full at the same time.  The feeling is melancholic.  I can't recommend it enough.

Rain World is an extremely frustrating, difficult and unfair experience... on purpose.
I love Rain World, but it's not for everyone, and that's okay.

[Slight spoilers for game-play] [Slight story spoilers]
This is a pretty wordy review so TLDR dot-points are at the bottom.

[IMMERSIVE WORLD AND DIFFICULTY]:

A massive part of Rain World is how immersive it is. You're not supposed to feel like some kind of hero or protagonist that is all powerful, instead the game wants to feel like you are a small insignificant part of the ecosystem that desperately struggles to survive in a cruel unpredictable world that doesn't care if you exist or not. You are not the center of the universe, you just happen to exist in it.

Rain World's difficulty is abnormally high because this feeds into the theme of you being just a normal wild animal surviving in the wild. After all it wouldn't make sense for a normal member of a small omnivorous species to suddenly flip into an apex predator that can survive anything. In the real world nature is unfair, cruel, uncaring, unfeeling, and brutal thus the game imitates this to be as immersive as possible.

You play as a Slugcat which despite the name is more similar to a sewer rat with human level intelligence than anything else. Even though you are capable of throwing spears and rocks, you were not built for combat. The vast majority of hostile creatures in the game can one-shot you, so you're expected to use your brain to outsmart and narrowly escape from predators. Although every predator is capable of dying and you can use various weapons (spears, the grenades crafted by Scavengers, rocks, Jellyfish, etc) combat can be extremely difficult at  first, especially if you haven't mastered the controls.

There are some games that have worlds claiming to be harsh and claiming that you're a normal nobody whereas in the actual game-play you're an overpowered god among ants, which can feel quite jarring and take you out of the immersion. Whereas the game-play of Rain World is completely consistent with the lore which helps a lot with it's immersion.

Even though I sometimes find the game infuriating, a part of me loves the feeling of slowly mastering the game and eventually triumphing over obstacles that at first felt impossible.

[ART]:

Even though pixel art doesn't allow for hyper-realistic extreme detail for every single blade of grass and speck of dirt, the atmosphere, colour pallet, architecture, and lighting all come together to make an extremely beautiful experience that more than makes up for the lack of detail.

[AI BEHAVIOR]:

Every creature in this game has it's own unique AI that makes them feel like they're real animals. There's an element of randomness to their behavior that I feel has been perfectly balanced. 
In games with elements of randomness it's important to strike a good balance, if there wasn't any randomness at all then you would be able to perfectly predict everything long before it happens, and If there's way too much randomness then it would feel arbitrary and inconsistent. Rain World's creatures do have certain patterns in their behavior that you can use to make general plans, but there's still enough unpredictability to keep you on your toes. After all, in the real world animals tend to follow patterns of behavior but it's impossible to consistently predict everything an animal will do.

Every creature in every section of the map is constantly being simulated regardless of whether you're near them or not, thus making the game feel even more immersive since in the real world animals don't just stop moving or existing whenever you're far away from them. Again, you are not the main character, each creature has it's own life that doesn't revolve around you. 
You would think that this would impact the frame-rate but I use the lowest settings and am playing on an old laptop (I don't know the specs but it's definitely not a gaming laptop) and the frame-rate has remained consistently smooth at all times.

[CONTROLS]:

The limited number of keys used makes the controls seem easy at first but there is an extremely wide variety of hidden movement techniques, tricks, and combinations that the game doesn't tell you about (the loading screen sometimes tells you some things but I'm pretty sure it doesn't tell you everything).
Learning to master the controls is difficult and feels a bit clunky but thankfully there are online documents and YouTube videos explaining how to do a variety of things such as back-flips, chaining rolling, sliding, throwing spears vertically, climbing poles really fast, and much more.

[SETTING AND DIRECTION]:

I'm not going to give any spoilers about the endings, what the Echos are, what caused The Rains, the exact dialogue of "Five Pebbles" and the exact dialogue of "Looks to the Moon" but I will give an introduction and description of the setting.

This game is on a planet that is not earth and I'm pretty sure the game never mentions earth. You are a Slugcat, a small omnivorous animal that lives in packs and seem to canonically have an intelligence somewhat similar to primitive humans since they use spears to hunt Batflys, build nests, make drawings, understand instructions (they don't ever seem to talk or make noise so I don't know how they communicate with each other), and trade with a chimp-like species called Scavengers by giving them Pearls.
You were accidentally separated from your family during one of The Rains.

The setting is similar to the post-apocalyptic genre except it's set in what I assume is either hundreds or thousands of years after the extinction of a technologically advanced civilization of people called The Ancients. The world is filled with atmospheric areas that have crumbled ruins, rusted metal structures, un-powered machines, disconnected pipes, broken poles and deteriorated scaffolding.

Your main goal is to survive but you can also explore the environment and there are two "characters" you can interact with. They are "Five Pebbles" and "Looks to the Moon", I'm not sure if they technically count as cyborgs but they're both city-sized supercomputers at least partially made of living materials and genetically modified organisms. They talk to you, providing exposition about the lore, and giving you instructions on how you could get an ending.

The game is called Rain World because there is a cycle of brief clear weather you can survive in followed by a tsunami of extremely heavy rain so strong that it crushes you if you're directly under it and so abundant that it completely floods underground areas. You need to eat enough food to be able to hibernate inside of little mechanical safe-rooms that lock up tight when you hibernate while you wait for The Rains to end and the underground areas to drain. 

[TLDR dot-points]:
[[Things I love about Rain World]]:
- You're not some special main character with god-like power, you are just a weak part of nature which is strangely humbling and refreshing.
- It's extremely immersive and feels like a realistic and believable alien ecosystem that truly feels alive.
- Even though the game is very difficult, that makes it more immersive and I like the feeling of getting more skilled over time and finally succeeding.
- The art is beautiful and very atmospheric.
- The AI has a nice balance of randomness, it's not too predictable and not too wildly unpredictable.

[[Things I dislike about Rain World]]:
- If you want to master the controls like doing back-flips, chaining rolls, and throwing spears vertically you will probably need to look up a guide.
- The game doesn't hold your hand so without an online guide you'll probably end up aimlessly exploring all over the place if you want to progress the story.
- You can only store one item in your stomach at a time and you can only carry one spear at a time.

Not everyone will enjoy Rain World, but I love this game and would encourage you to give it a try.

My god, this game is genuinely beautiful, 10/10. I have recommended it to all of my friends. I have the DLC, which is a lot on top of the base price, but that's one of the few minorly negative things I'd say about the game.

Pros:
- The story is so good. Deeply hopeless, but life continues on whether it's wanted or not. Past mistakes that caused great harm. A lot of hidden lore to find if you look for it and studiously bring it to be studied. And if you don't care about all that, haha funny scug do flip.
- Everything feels very natural, this world truly does feel like surviving as a small creature near the bottom of the food chain. Enemy AI is done quite well, with most creatures feeling unique and you develop strategies around them. Seeing them for the first time is a great terrifying experience. Sometimes they trip and fall or get stuck, sometimes they fight each other. You aren't the main character (well, you are, but man it almost never feels like it and in a really good way).
- Movement system is unique and a lot of fun to learn
- The world is absolutely beautiful, the style is completely on-point of this post-apocalyptic lonely world
- The game is super frustrating at times, which sounds like a con, but it makes learning so much more satisfying
- Heaps of content* (much more with DLC but the base game story is still great)
- Beautiful music. It's on YouTube if you're curious, but it also fits the style really well and is just a damn bop.
- More that I've missed, it's just such a good game. I could rant about it for hours. If you have the money and have bothered reading this far, absolutely get it.

Cons:
- Some controls are a little unintuitive (like holding down and tapping shift to drop something which unfortunately ends with a lot of items dropped when trying to grab something while sliding down a pole)
- Sometimes the game does feel unfair, just because you get unlucky with where the creatures are. It feels more natural, though, than having them all follow set paths.
- Occasional bugs like falling out of the map (irritating), lizards rarely failing to path and spinning (funny, can be excused as a lizard behaviour) and an asset or two on my scug's body not loading (was a tad distracting but I died before I started worrying), but nothing that ruins the experience.
- God DAMMIT RAIN DEER. HURRY UP (thankfully these fools are confined to only a few areas in the game).

**Rain World - A Timeless and Exceptional Journey**

**Overall Rating: 10/10**

**Review Summary:**
Rain World, a remarkable game released in 2017, remains an unparalleled and unforgettable experience. Its unparalleled atmospheric storytelling and unique gameplay mechanics continue to captivate me with every playthrough. Despite the challenges it presents, Rain World's brilliance shines through, making it one of the most exceptional games I've encountered.

**Music: 8/10**
Rain World's musical compositions beautifully complement each situation, seamlessly enhancing the emotional depth of the gameplay. The carefully curated soundtrack never feels out of place, skillfully adding to the immersive atmosphere of the world.

**Visuals: 9/10**
Rain World is a visual masterpiece that rewards players who take the time to truly immerse themselves in its intricacies. The stunning world design captivates with its attention to detail, and the cutscenes are skillfully crafted, offering breathtaking visuals that draw players deeper into the game's enigmatic universe.

**Character Design: 9/10**
The endearing slugcats, the game's central characters, exude an undeniable charm, evoking an emotional connection with players. Additionally, the intriguing design of (Medium to mild spoiler:) ||the iterators and|| other creatures enhances the game's unique allure, showcasing the developers' creative ingenuity.

**Originality: 10/10**
Rain World stands as a paragon of originality in the gaming world. Its innovative gameplay mechanics, atmospheric storytelling, and distinct art style make it a true one-of-a-kind experience. It defies conventional gaming norms, setting itself apart as an extraordinary and refreshing journey.

**General Gameplay: 10/10**
Rain World challenges players with its steep difficulty curve, demanding perseverance and skill. However, as players grow accustomed to its mechanics, the gameplay rewards them with a sense of accomplishment and mastery. Despite moments of intense frustration, the game never crosses the threshold of becoming discouraging, leaving players determined to conquer its trials.

**Story: 10/10**
The storytelling of Rain World is a marvel in itself. The manner in which it is woven into the gameplay creates a seamless and immersive storytelling experience. As players piece together the enigmatic lore of Rain World, they find themselves enthralled by its depth and intrigue, adding profound meaning to every step and pause of their journey. (Medium to high spoiler:) ||The game's dying world is just a completely tragic exploration to embark on. Constantly learning of the desperate frustrations of the beings of this world is beautiful in a sad way. I can't speak much on this, as I want whoever's going to read spoilers to still play it. Regardless of spoiler walls, the story is completely tragic. Even in the perfect end after going through all variations of gameplay, it's uniquely tragic in a bittersweet way.||

**Conclusion:**
Rain World stands as a timeless masterpiece that seamlessly combines captivating storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and unparalleled gameplay mechanics. It is a game that challenges players while simultaneously rewarding their dedication and tenacity. As the years pass, Rain World remains etched in the memories of those fortunate enough to have embarked on its tragic, frustrating journey. Without a doubt, it deserves a place among the greatest and most unforgettable gaming experiences of all time. Absolute must-play in my book, if you're willing to commit to the turmoil that is it's beginner's wall of frustration. I mean, damn.. the first award only has 26% achievement rate.

[b]Score:[/b] 9/10
[b]Pros:[/b] A slow pace experience game that has a grand world and story behind it's rather simple mechanics. You play as a slugcat, trying to complete each one's objective in a metroid-vania like world. But the big seller is that the game makes you feel like prey. Everything that could possible kill, harm or eat you will, and it's your objective to get pass all these while trying to learn about the world, eat enough to survive, and find shelter before the rains fall. The game does a great job of making you feel vulnerable without being unreasonable. Sometimes the deaths may feel unfair, but that's just how nature is. Caution is needed when exploring, watching and learning how creature interact, hell even learning how to tame some creatures to help you are all optional yet major parts of the game. Sure you can ignore all the nuance in the mechanics, but then you can play lesser games for the cheap and small hit of dopamine. Mastering the systems, learning all you can, and engaging in fun and unique ways really make this game. The art is fantastic as well, and the blends of styles are really quite interesting. The subtle soundtrack is absolute fitting and refreshing, never once did I feel the sound or atmosphere has hurt by it which is a rare feat these days.
[b]Cons:[/b] It can be unforgiving and unfair cause it is trying to simulate a realistic nature with all the AI and coding going on. Rage quitting can happen after a long string of losing all the Karma you earned over and over from cheap kills. 
[b]Recommend to:[/b] Patient folks who like deep worlds and interesting mechanics and ideas. Fan of folks who like simulations and AI based actions instead of predictable and expected results.
[b]Overall:[/b] Again, Indie devs nail it. Rain World is a beautiful peace of art that really deserves more attention then it got.

Rain World is a vibrant world full of plants, animals, and ancient machines. You start with whatever you can find on the ground and your ability to learn. You will find no upgrades for your slugcat or the weapons in the core game. Figuring out the world's backstory and its creatures might be a bit tricky, but it's all there.

If you're into games that let you move around freely and experiment, Rain World is a 10/10.
BUT if you don't like experimenting, you might need to look for another game to play.

Parts of this game infuriate me, while parts of it make me want to play more and more.
This game is a master at making you feel like you belong in the ecosystem, and is very atmospheric, drawing you in.

However, in a game that's all about exploring, it's pretty cruel and unforgiving, and makes you do things over and over again due to the one shot dying present in all aspects of the game.

All in all, 8/10, I'd wait for it to go on sale. Also, Downpour is an S Tier addition to the base game, would recommend it as well.

I don't doubt this game can be interesting and fun, but the controls kill the experience for me. It just feels like I'm fighting the movement of the character more than the actual enemies of the game. Why does it have to be 'z,' 'x,' and 'shift' with the arrow keys instead of the regular 'wasd' with the space bar? It's just so weird, and it doesn't help that every enemy in the game has jacked out movement. It's like I have to deal with these agile creature whilst also slamming my keyboard into my desk because that's how unorthodox the controls are. I don't get it. 
Sad part is I love the concept of navigating a complex ecosystem and having to deal with these unique situation with a variety of animals. I love every aspect of this game except for the fucking controls. Why should any player care about the world they're exploring if the controls make everything so sluggish? I feel like I'm pulling teeth just trying to figure out how to perform a simple wall jump after leaping off of a stick. So frustrating. 
Also, side note: Why do people draw similarities between this and Outer Wilds? They're on completely different ends of the gaming spectrum. The main appeal of this game initially for me was because I had seen people say they two were similar when they are very clearly not. 
Idk, maybe I'm just bad at the game.

:3 REVIEW UPDATE :3 

i have spent at least half of a year or even more playing this dumb silly game and i still pick it over most games i have in my library from how much replayability it has. 

Something else to mention , all of the campaigns are amazing , though they do sometimes lack stuff like for example:
-considering monk&survivor have an intro cutscene , others don't and it's a missed opportunity.-

The Downpour DLC is really good too and it has at least double the size of content , that the vanilla game had. As for the new slugcats , they're all amazing in their own ways , some might not stick with you and some you might instantly fall in love with.

If i could , i would write a more unbiased review but since the day i bought this game , it still manages to surprise me , make me hate it , rip my hair off and have fun. 

For people who have friends !! i recommend you to try out CO-OP , yes it may be buggy at times and steam together play is wacky , but if you do manage to get it working , CO-OP makes the game 100x times more fun and even more silly. (P.S. you'll need you/your friends to have controllers to play co-op , one player can be on keyboard and every other person on controllers , its weird but i'm not the one who created this game) And finally , yes , the mods for this game are really fun too and i mostly use the DMS mod ("Dress My Slugcat") because all the OC and not OC slugcat designs look beautiful. The community can be a little annoying but i just don't interact with it, i recommend you doing the same too if you're afraid of communities. 

As my for my final word or something ? 8/10 , has its flaws and has its pros , all in all , great game. ALSO PLEASE , DON'T PUT ON ANY MODS BEFORE PLAYING ALL THE CAMPAIGNS , IT *WILL* RUIN YOUR EXPERIENCE AND YOU WON'T BE ABLE TO COME BACK TO PLAYING WITHOUT MODS , JUST COMPLETE THE GAME AND THEN PUT ON YOUR SILLY LITTLE MODS. 

Thank you for reading ! :3

Having finished Rain World, its kind of difficult to actually recommend this game to just anyone , most people who have left a review have probably said something similar but actually getting any progress done as a new player is laughable, for me it took me around 10 hours to get to the second area of the game because the first two attempts at a playthrough i took a wrong turn unbeknownst to me and went to the late game area which is accessible from the tutorial region and spent god lords how long going between claustrophobic pipes and like 10 predators in filtration systems. I think that actually encapsulates rain world in a nutshell, a completely hostile world that wont hold your hand nor tell you if youre doing anything wrong, in any case just follow the little yellow guy because it really does show you the right way though navigating around can still be extremely confusing as the map i think mightve been made the way it is to be almost unreadable as its extremely hard to route out long distance travel as its pretty zoomed in and not layed out flat.
Apart from taking a wrong turn, fucking around and finding out,  the game is also not exactly supposed to be the definition of fun all around but rather a mix of emotions: frustration, confusion, fear, fascination and more as the developers went above and beyond to make the most gigantic map ive ever seen in a game that never misses in quality as the background and art is incredibly beautiful and diverse really selling the setting at all times.
At 20 hours i barely even got to scrape all systems the game has to offer and the incredibly diverse moveset that slugcat comes equipped at all times (which is never explained at all so good luck finding out all this junk without the remix menu option "loading menu tips") but is not exactly needed to beat the game, you're left at the mercy of predators if you dont learn to fully utilize all these secret techniques or the fact that [spoiler]theres a reputation system in the game which means you can tame lizards and other animals and then become a non prey to them (how tf are you supposed to learn this, welp by being creative enough to think you could tame them i guess lol) [/spoiler].
If you find any idea of being dropped into a fully living world and living out the expirience of being a vulnerable defenseless little creature at the mercy of everything around you then give the game a try and dont be scared to reset the game if needed, took me like 4 resets though thankfully all your maps are saved from any past attempts. 

ALSO download the screen scrolling mod from the workshop  thats probably the one unforgivable flaw in the game, getting one shotted from something off screen is kind of asinine.

Rain World is a comically difficult game where you play as a small rat in the sewers of Detroit. It's an immersive sim first and a platformer second; the virtual ecosystem this game creates through procedural animation and complex animal AI interactions does not care in the slightest about the player, and that's why I love it so much. The horrifying affronts to God you'll witness on your journey think and act unpredictably, and that makes certain scenarios a little unfair and sometimes impassable without simply waiting a few minutes for them to screw off.

And the difficulty doesn't stop there! The developers have cleverly hidden literal pages of some of the cleanest movement tech I've ever seen behind WASD + 2 buttons, some of which is required to traverse a select few routes. But if you ask most people, they'll say it's clunky because none of it is ever explained.

On top of that, the lore of this game is delivered via you choking down one of 30 hidden rocks, travelling across the entire treacherous world I just mentioned *on foot* to its easternmost point, and vomiting up said rock so that a Muppet WALL-E thing can read it to you and tell you that the divine wisdom you worked so hard to acquire is a Buddhist liquor store receipt.
 
There are also 8 different campaigns that offer wildly different experiences and take place at different points in the timeline. Interestingly, the 6 campaigns you *don't* have the ability to play immediately offer relatively direct storytelling at their midpoints and endpoints. Meaning that the first impression most players get is almost fully devoid of details on this intriguing world outside of the aforementioned rock regurgitation fest most players will never actually go through with, rendering the first playthrough more of an extended tutorial about discovering how the game works, and how to survive.

I've joked a lot at the game's expense thus far, but I truly do love Rain World. The thing is, it really is a game driven by discovery. Sure, it's frustrating to not understand much of anything at first, but the feeling this game provides of eking out an understanding of a brutal, cryptic world is unique and potent. For that reason, I don't want to spoil any specifics, so just trust me when I say that you should at least give this game a few hours if it looks interesting to you. It's scary and unforgiving but beautiful all the same.

***NO SPOILERS***

DISCLAIMER: Even though I'm giving a thumbs up I am not recommending this game for everyone! This game WILL be frustrating for new players and there are going to be moments where you feel you need to step away.

Do you think games are getting stale, old or boring? does it feel like you're repeating the same game over and over? If you answered yes then you're probably itching for a new experience, right? Well guess what, you just found one of the most unique games I've ever played and probably ever will play! Rain World is a game about adapting to an unforgiving, harsh ecosystem and overcoming tremendous odds as a small inexperienced creature.

You may have been told to be especially careful of spoilers and if you're curious why, let me tell you. If you see something new it's never obvious what anything is gonna do, which can change how you interact and learn about that element which can have MAJOR effects later on. an example would be my interactions with a large number of pretty huge beasts blocking where I needed to go, which I assumed were dangerous during my first few encounters with them. My fear of them had me backtrack to try and find another way through which took actual hours.

There are also many, MANY complexities when it comes to how things in the world interact with YOU. There is a particular system in Rain World that will decide whether you will delve into an nigh unwinnable war and become a wandering badass, or end up with all the riches in the world. Even when things are decided by RNG though, you can always gain back control. Even when you have no food on an empty stomache and are surrounded with the deadliest creatures this game has to offer, you can still make a come back. I did in the very worst of circumstances.

Ultimately, it's a very challenging and often frustrating title, with the freshest elements a game can have in the modern day. I would recommend it for those bored with games or craving a new experience, but warn those who aren't as patient to be warry.

I deleted my last review of Rain World because I genuinely want to praise this amazing game.

Like everyone else I bought Rain World, was confused on what to do, was wondering why this funny white cat isn't properly moving the way I want it to, and got really lost on what my objective was. Then I quit the game and realized I couldn't refund the game because I've already played it for more then 2 hours. So then it sat in my steam library taunting me everyday when I saw it. After many months of Rain World collecting dust in my library I decided to sit down and actually try and finish the game, just so I didn't feel cursed by it anymore. The game took a while to click with me, but when it did it clicked. I was soon in love with this funny slimy creature, the movement, and the amazing art and backdrops. But the one thing that always made me wanna play the game more was the music and the mastering of the movement, [spoiler]there is a 87 page google document with the most complex things imaginable.[/spoiler] You can notice when you are learning how to control the slugcat and master the combat. Soon after the lizards don't become a fearful thing you are scared to get close to, they instead become a creature that is insanely fun to engage with. Scavengers become something you always wanna fight with instead of trying to become Chieftain. The music always slaps no matter what, from the calming shoreline, to the aggressive dynamic threat music when you are fighting for survival. All the music feels like a reward, a accomplishment that you over came to listen to and relax. I don't really wanna go into story details because that will ruin the experience of accomplishing the goals in the game, but I wanna tell you to keep playing and don't give up because the game doesn't tell you anything. Rain World is probably my favorite game ever made, because the game feels like its own ecosystem that continues even when you are not even playing. Rain World is a amazing little indie game, and I recommend if you purchase it you also get Downpour.

Good game, but with many faults, to the point of it feeling like an overambitious and unfinished early access title. 

Let's start with the good: the enviroments are beautiful, and they're a very good representation of what pixel art can do when it's done right. Sound design is great, music too - though maybe less so, as sometimes it feels too intrusive. If the intention was to imitate minecraft's music system, it didn't land quite well. 

You have a lot of freedom to explore the world, to the point where you can visit endgame location before the "intended" next one, which I did. This caused me a great deal of confusion, as in not understanding why the game is smashing my head with a brick. Luckily, community was quite eager to point out that it was a common case of "skill issue", and eventually I managed to find the "intended" path by going to the left instead of right.

The physics based movement system feels great to play with, but it does get tiring after some time. Slugcat deciding to explore vents and shafts with their behind first seems amusing, but it does lead to some stress when encountering the enemies that decide not to do the same.

Speaking of the enemies, their AI tends to be very broken, but Rain Deer is the biggest offender there - one of the only creatures I actually know the name of, because I had to look up their extremely wonky behavior, to ensure that's somehow not an issue only for me. How delightful.

Lastly, audio has the nasty habit of "deep-frying" itself sometimes, requiring relaunch - sounds funny, until you experience it mid-cycle and have to either risk ear damage, play without an important source of information, or lose progress.

Not that it matters, as you'll lose progress either way, with game randomly deciding to eat parts of your savedata from most recent session. This is a great deal to me, especially considering how difficult and borderline trial-and-error it gets in some areas. I want to play it more, but as it stands it's sadly not possible, with it being a pretty common occurence.

Overall, I can definitely say that this is a very one-of-a-kind experience. With how unusual it is, it's likely you might be suprised how much you'll like it. I can't recommend it however, for reasons mentioned above. Developers deciding to release a DLC instead of improving the game has only ensured me this won't change.

This game has pros and cons, but if you're a loyal player, there is SOOOO much to this game.

Pros:
-Uses procedural generated movement to create both very funny moments, and when a lizard isn't spinning in circles for 5 minutes, makes for a very realistic movement system.
-A super diverse ecosystem, where everything feels real. A basic example of this is Batfiles to Slugs, Slugs to Lizards, Lizards to Vultures. But, depending on where you look, or what animal you are stuffing into the ecosystem, it all fits in.
-The animals think like real animals. Take Scavengers, who have complex emotions, signals, and even a loyalty system that, unless you don't pay attention, really make for a fun experience.
-There's always some level of stress in the form of the deadly rain showers, but it's that fun stress where you're planning ahead. It forces you to think.
-The pixel-like in-game graphics, combined with the vibrant art style of cut scenes creates a immersive experience you just aren't going to get in other games like this.
-The story is complicated, but not so complicated you're going to be smashing your head on your desk, which is a breather compared to most story-driven games (although I wouldn't exactly classify Rainworld as one).
-There's a DLC that gives you literally a game's worth of new content; new Skugs with different attributes, food requirements, stories, timelines, endings, and regions. It also expands upon the story of this dystopian world. If you like the stock game, definitely check out the DLC. (it's named "Downpour", for those of you who are interested.)

Cons:
-The procedural generation movement system can end up being terrible sometimes. Rain deer are an obvious example of this goofy jank, which really sucks as they're required to cross a certain biome.
-You're going to die a lot. This isn't really a problem when you're skilled, or are completely fine with trial and error systems, but if you're the perfectionist kind who will smash in your monitor when you die twice in a row, stay away.
-There's a very high skill ceiling. As mentioned in the last con, dying isn't exactly a problem once you're a skilled player, but it takes a LONG time to become said "skiled player."
-The game's pretty long. Between the deaths, story, skill ceilings, and creature spawns, most first playthroughs are lengthy. I haven't beat the game yet, but I haven't even got to the first major plot point in 3 hours, and there's still 2 more with like, 5 biomes between them each. Told you it was lengthy.

So, overall, if you're just a casual gamer, should you buy this? Yes! It's an awesome indie game that needs more attention despite how much it already has. However, maybe stray away from it if you are more of a perfectionist gamer.

One of the most enigmatic games on steam. Sometimes it feels unfair, but its all part of the experience. This devs made so many polarizing choices, from the difficulty to the story progression. If thats not for you, thats ok! But if you give it a chance, I think Rainworld does a few things exceptionally well. The art direction in the game is amazing. The procedural animation used for the creatures and the detailed backgrounds go together really well. Another thing Rainworld does really well is exploration and difficulty. Theres no handholding in Rainworld, and I think thats a refreshing take on the modern consumer-friendly game formula. Of course, making things really hard had its downsides, hence the not overwhelmingly positive reviews. Anyways, you should try it!!! Get it when its on sale or something. This game has a great community, awesome furry devs, and it will probably be my fav game on steam for a while.

Such a frustrating, badly-designed, experience. It's a beautiful & extremely atmospheric game that was terribly implemented.

I purchased this game after hearing about how difficult it was. I love difficult, challenging games, and most of the negative reviews here are complaints about the difficulty. There's more to it though. The game isn't difficult just because it's challenging; the difficulty mainly comes from bad gameplay design. Two specific examples -

Many portions of the map expand across multiple screens, but you can't see the other side until your character actually moves there. There's no scrolling or preview before your character moves to the next section, it's just an abrupt transition from one area to the next. This means there are no shortage of times where you move to the other side of the map and are instantly consumed by an enemy that you couldn't see previously. This is a terrible design that has been fixed in games like this long ago by just showing a small preview of the other side as your character approaches. It's incredible that the devs couldn't think of doing anything similar in a game where dying literally sets your progress back.

The other aspect I want point out is the "karma" and "karmic gates" system (what does "karma" have to do with being eaten by a lizard? The name alone makes no sense). You have to have a successful cycle in order to gain "karma" points, which are required for progression.... Why? What purpose does this serve? It wouldn't be too much of an issue if it weren't for the issue described above, and for the simple fact that there are MANY instances where your success is entirely reliant on the RNG enemy placement. There are no shortage of situations where you simply CANNOT escape death. A game containing both of these elements together makes no sense, and again, is just terrible game design.

I saw a comment about how the main developer was "surprised" by the mostly negative reviews on this.... Really? I can't fathom how detached from reality someone would have to be to not think that this niche-game is going to be praised by the world, even without the glaringly bad design decisions listed above. Such a shame as it clearly had so much promise.

As someone that very much enjoys atmospheric / open world / metroidvania type games, this seemed right up my alley.  I really wanted to enjoy this, but after around 8 hours of banging my head into a wall only to be met with sheer disappointment at my destination, I relented, and decided to move on the the next game on my steam library.

I never though I that I would say these words, as someone that is generally against these two things, but I feel like I would have enjoyed this game significantly more if you were told explicitly where to go,or there was fast travel.  I spent my 8 hours of playtime trudging my way to the east side of the map, because I thought that was where I was supposed to go, and once I got there, I was met with an npc that I had no idea what to do with, and the prospect that if I wanted to go further in this game I would have to go all the way back through what I just did.

Part of my issue is that everything in this game is slow.  Movement is slow, climbing is slow, eating is slow, waiting for enemies to move is slow, regaining your karma is slow.  As an art piece and a novel concept, its an incredible experience for the first few hours.  But once you contend with the prospect of actually progressing, it becomes much more of a drag.

TLDR:
This game is beautiful and the atmosphere and combat is one of the coolest ideas I've ever experienced in a game; but once you contend with the the idea of slowly backtracking through punishingly difficult areas towards a destination that is either unfulfilling or the wrong destination entirely, it becomes way less fun as a video game.

An amazingly unique game

Pluses:
+ Physics - The game feels very smooth in its animations and movements. Looks and feels uniquely nice
+ AI (artificial intelligence) is great! - probably the best and most interesting AI I have ever seen in real-time games. Every enemy has its own specific AI (and abilities, that this AI manages). They interact with their environment and other creatures, they travel around the map just as you do, some even can be befriended. Even observing other creatures is often fun. Really cool!
+ Very atmospheric - both visuals and sounds work for creating a strong sense of a natural atmosphere, even despite the game being a 2d pixel art
+ Realistic wild nature simulation - all higher points work for this specific feeling of a realistic, gloomy wild world, where you have to be really careful in order to survive.

 Story - there are some world descriptions here and there, and there are some plot points, but mostly there is no story
 Difficult - the game is really difficult (and it rises as you get to later locations), and mistakes can be brutal. Often (though not always) you will die in a single hit. Get ready to retry from last checkpoint a lot. This is the main gameplay feature of the game, it wanted to be difficult, so this means the game is not for everyone and requires patience.
 May feel repetitive, due to its high difficulty. It's a minus because it gets boring - but it's also a plus because you can just close the game and continue it later))

- Advanced controls are hard - I couldn't stably repeat some tricks written in the wiki while playing on my controller joystick outside of danger (and practically never could do it when chased). On monk (easiest) difficulty It's not too crucial, but on hunter (the hardest one) you will definitely appreciate using some advanced movements for hunting. Not cool (though I might need to check mods for this).

All in all: feels like a Hollow knight + Don't starve mashed together with amazing physics and AI. Difficult, very atmospheric adventure game, that feels like a sandbox at times. Sometimes it feels really pleasant just to move slowly and observe (or tame) other creatures. It's hard to sit in this game for too long in a single go, but that is probably a good point)

What a beautiful but inscrutable game. This is one of those titles that drips with atmosphere. The games pixelated post-apocalyptic, damp, overgrown setting is somehow both bleak and wondrous with a subtle electronic score that serves as a reminder that predators lurk around each corner.

This game is a simulated ecosystem where you have both the prey you hunt to survive and the predators trying to hunt you. The world learns from your actions and responds to how you interact with it. The challenge then is to explore, eat, and find safe shelter from the routine giga storm that will kill you if you remain exposed when it shows up - a genuinely tense experience as the rumbling begins and water starts consuming the world.

The gameplay however is stiff and clunky. Movement is key to survival as predators pursue you but aside from the long jump the rest of the game's many movement options are hidden and don't execute smoothly. Grabbing while falling, climbing vertical bars, wall jumps tied to an invisible stamina bar, and crawling up sheer edges are all unintuitive and frustrating to execute consistently, especially when it counts.

It takes trial and error to learn how the ecosystem works but that isn't enough. There's a knowledge gate very early on that you aren't taught how to pass. After 3 years I looked at a guide only to discover I was unknowingly trapped in the earliest areas because it doesn't tell you that a necessary interaction is even possible to perform. I thought the game was enigmatic, turns out it's just obtuse for no perceptible reason.

It's an impressively complex game set in an charming world that I still want to delve into deeper, but the dedication to hiding key info from the player makes it an intentionally impenetrable experience that disappointed me. High points for creativity, anxiety inducing gameplay, and rich atmosphere, but points off for going out of its way to impede progress. Play it but just read the player guides and save yourself the pointless struggle.

Oh my goodness! it all started just before new year when i saw a video by CURIOUS ARCHIVE. with the year 2022 nearly done and my first year at secondary school in my belt, i collapsed onto the sofa to watch a video titled "The most complex ecosystem of any video game" (check out the first half of the video by the way as it shows a lot about rain worlds complexity, do refrain from watching till the end though: SPOILERS!) although at first apprehensive, soon i let the game into a well earned space in my heart. I was on a new year's sleepover so i had to tame my monstrous hunger to buy it by re watching CURIOUS ARCHIVE's video over and over as well as looking for any other decent you tubers and that's how i found both the wiki and where to get the game: steam. Click on my account and you'll see i have done steam reviews before and i knew i could buy the game with my Christmas money!

And then i got the game...

At first i wasn't sure how i felt; this game is a very weird one to play, and at times frustrating! yet i couldn't help but love how the creature design, karma system, combat and PROCEDURALLY GENERATED ANIMATION BRO, made this game so immersive. And by the time i got mover my essential difficulties i soon knew what i was doing and began to truly enjoy myself.

So what are my thoughts after buying downpour (haven't finished it yet) and having completed a survivor run?

Well...

It was a great experience and although sometimes i cried, sometimes i (internally) sreamed in frustration! but there are so many amazing interactions, satisfying moments, awesome discoveries (AND THE ANIMATION). You'll find yourself in a dynamic ecosystem the is being simulated all around you (,yes the game simulates stuff even a long way away from you meaning you may bump into fights, hunts and creatures literally anywhere at any time) Learn to move and fight your way through one of the greatest games of all time! Tell me if you want to hear more from this review BTW!

P.S. I love lizards! they are so cool!

Deliciously soulslike with immersive gameplay and a never-ending slew of creatures, environments, and game modes to adapt to. I'd consider this a Metroidvania - despite the very minimal hand-holding from the developers, it's impossible to navigate the world without running familiar paths that cross over themselves. While you don't often gain new abilities or powerups to move forward, you DO become more familiar with the limits of your slugcat and just how much you can push them.

Every time I open up this game I learn something new about it. It's effin' fantastic. My understanding of the game and knowledge of its mechanics continues to build on itself without being overwhelming or needlessly overcomplicated; you learn to BE the slugcat, not just move it around on-screen. sound design is impeccable. ost is atmospheric, gameplay-dynamic and immersive. I can recognize what creatures are around me just by listening. (I've played with and without sound, and while you don't NEED audio to survive, it's strongly recommended. Don't handicap your scug if you don't have to <3) The controls have a bit of a learning curve to them, but it's like learning to ride a bike; the more you move around, the easier and more natural it becomes, and the more sick tricks you can pull off.

I bought the game + DLC while it was on sale, but I did NOT hesitate to drop the full $40 a few days later to get it for a friend. Rain World has a complexity and level of detail and care poured into it that continues to amaze me and inspires ideas for games of my own. Never would've even considered rigged pixel animation as a viable option before playing this. 


11/10. The game lives in the same brain-box-of-respect as Hollow Knight. My review is probably incomprehensible, but I really cannot express how much I adore this game and its ecosystem. You really just need to play it for yourself.

Flung away from my loving family, I'm now stuck in hostile wilderness with no survival skills whatsoever. Guess I'll take instructions from a glowy worm in the walls. after so many hours of exploration and death I am eventually lead to a ruined little machine life form. not knowing what to do, I eat the little glowy thingys and the creature dies. I still don't know why I'm here or if I'm going in the right direction but at least my only guide has abandoned me. Now I'm glowing, confused, and can suddenly see ghost worms all going in the same direction. Following these ghost worms, I come to a blackened and ruined area devoid of life besides some bioluminescent critters that scamper around. The ghost worms are no help now so I attempt to explore on my own. After a very frustrating while I eventually find my way to a place I'd been months ago, absolutely killing me inside. Persisting my exploration despite low spirits, I realize that this is but an intermission as I quickly find another entrance to a new area. This place is yellow, sickly, and Incredible dangerous. It doesn't seem to lead anywhere good, but what choice do I have; I've got to keep going ... for some reason.

Huge caveats to recommending this game; you must use the settings menu and disable core mechanics of the game for me personally to recommend it to anyone. 

Before I begin, let it be known that this game has a large cult following, and rightfully so. As such, any criticisms of the game are immediately attacked. I always leave comments on in my reviews; if you see someone dismissing my points without a good counter, or otherwise just being a fanboy, simply discredit them and move on. Not worth arguing with the die-hards of any subject.

Pros:
- Art style and atmosphere in this game is absolutely phenomenal. Each area is wholly unique, filled with wholly unique flora and fauna, and is NEVER boring. Just the desire to see what the next area looks like and what life it is home to forces me to march onward.
- Enemy variety is very high and literally every single creature is awesome. Even the annoying creatures that will have you cursing at the screen are a treat to look at and just as cool to try and avoid. Wildlife AI is stupid good in this game, it's honestly hard to describe how "real" their behaviors feel.
- Very demanding game in terms of skill required. (more on this later in the cons). In terms of pure gameplay, the game is usually very fair but asks a ton of attention from the player to make precise jumps, smart maneuvers, etc.
- The sense of exploration is generally fantastic, though I'll touch on this in the cons.
Overall, the Pros are: this is a visual treat to look at (the animations are procedurally generated and makes everything look amazing!), feels like you're traversing a living, breathing alien world in a way I've never seen before.

Neutral:
- Story is basically non-existent. Die-hards will tell you it's much deeper than it is. There's effectively no exposition, simply a few still-images that serve as cutscenes and show you a handful of emotions. The rest is lore you'd REALLY have to dig for to make any sense of. 
- Controls and movements for your character are surprisingly deep, but the game does not do practically anything to teach you how to do them. I've seen die-hards say that it's intentional and that "part of the game is discovering the moveset". That's dumb. fighting games have move lists so you KNOW HOW TO PLAY THE GAME. The game has a seriously cool amount of movement options that require precise timings or inputs and it explain nothing but how to jump and climb. People have made (literally) 20 page documents covering the depth of the movement system in this game; I could have used a few more tutorials on essential movement mechanics. People forget that this is a video game. I want to play it. Teach me how to play it. Teach me the rules of the game world, teach me how to maneuver, THEN you can let me figure out the mysteries of the world using those tools. 
- The game is simply too open ended. You will find countless threads on Steam and Reddit asking "Where do I go?", and it's not because everyone is dumb (though people are dumb, I know lol). The game is (barring Karma requirements) totally open. There is a little helper that shows some pictograms once in a while to help guide you through the first "act" of the game, but after that, you're on your own almost exclusively for the second act. There's a reason metroidvania games give you a general direction of where to go but don't show you how to get there. That's all you need to give the players some direction while still letting them explore the world. This game could have used that, just a bit bigger nudge, to get players going East instead of West after act 1, for example.


Cons:
I need to preface this by saying to the die-hard following: I agree that this game has a lot of amazing parts to it. Try to quell your insatiable desire to roast me alive for these criticisms.

- Outside of the normal controls and gameplay of platforming and combat, there are 3 main game mechanics that make up the gameplay loop; Rain, Karma, and Gates. None of these three mechanics are implemented well AT ALL.
- Rain is effectively a timer. You have a timer to go from one checkpoint to another, and you have to have collected enough food along the way to your next checkpoint to be able to "hibernate", which lets you save your game at that checkpoint. If the timer runs out and it starts to rain, you die. 
These timers, in some areas, are absolutely brutal as it requires practically zero mistakes on your way to the next checkpoint. This game, unlike most games, doesn't have consistent enemy spawns; the enemies kind of roam the map in a living eco-system. This by itself is totally awesome! However, it makes for a frustrating time when paired with a timer that kills you. Imagine all the long boss runs in the original Dark Souls, except you're on a timer that kills you if it runs out and the enemies are spawned almost randomly, making some of them directly block your path to the next boss/bonfire/etc. Eventually, that timer starts to annoy you.
- To make things worse, the Karma/Gate system comes into play. When you start the game, you have a total of 5 Karma points. Every time you die, you lose 1 point. Every time you hibernate at a checkpoint with enough food in your belly, you gain 1 point. Simple enough.
Karma points are like "skill" checks that allow you to pass through Gates (Gates being large doors that block off each zone from one another). Lets say you reach a Gate in a zone you've already explored and you're ready to move on to the next zone. If the gate requires 4 Karma, it will not open unless you have 4 Karma out of 5. 
The problem lies within the tedium of all 3 of these systems put together. It goes something like this:
- You die a LOT in this game because it is a very challenging game to learn and an even harder one to master. You inevitably will end up with 1-2 Karma from dying so often.
- You will finally make some progress and find the Gate to the next area, only to find that it requires a higher Karma count than you currently have. So, you head back to find food and rest at the same checkpoint form before so you can gain a Karma point.
- You are forced to sleep/hunt for food/repeat multiple times to build up the Karma needed to progress the game. Mind you, grabbing berries and bats is not hard, it is simply tedious after a while. It does not increase the challenge, just as farming for Blood Vials in Bloodborne didn't increase the challenge there.
- When you have enough Karma to open the gate, you must make it to the gate without dying, while collecting food to prepare yourself for the next checkpoint, and make it far enough in the next area to find the next checkpoint without dying. If you die before you find the next checkpoint, the gate will close, and you must repeat the hunt/sleep/repeat cycle again because when you died, your karma fell below the threshold.
- All the while you're repeating this same hunt/sleep/run to the gate/try to find next checkpoint cycle...you're on a timer. The clock is ticking and if it starts to rain, you're dead. Dead = hunt, sleep, hunt, run to gate, try to find checkpoint again.

It is beyond tedious. 

Outside of the die-hard fans, the general public agrees with me on all of these points, which is why in the "Remix" settings they added to the game, they allow you to turn off all 3 of those mechanics. It even warns you that it's "not the intended way to play" and all that, yet I find myself having a great time since I turned that crap off. The game is still immensely hard without a constant death timer and the tedium of grinding for Karma. 

I find myself day dreaming about playing this game because when it's good, it's SOOOO good, but I probably would have stopped playing had those core mechanics not been turned off. I wish developers would learn that tedium is NOT difficulty.
The rest of the game though is amazing and offers an incredible challenge, even with the rain timer and karma gates turned off.

This game, despite it's flaws, is my FAVOURITE GAME OF ALL TIME.

I love the feeling of this not being just a game that the main character rules, but instead an ecosystem that you're apart of. I have not finished it because it can be quite tough but, personally, I find that battle very rewarding and it makes me enjoy the game even more. Also, the music this game carries is incredible and every time I get to a new environment, it feels like the end of a huge journey. The scenery and design of this game is very gorgeous and I love the personality creatures can have. I'm definitely buying the soundtrack and have already bought the DLC because I know I'll love it.

However, as I said before, this game can be and will be challenging. Especially in the harder stages(?). The amount of times I've died has left me very frustrated but I've learnt that it's more part of the process rather than failing. You learn something new every death, you know? Sometimes luck is just not on your side and you have to give up, it happens. As for the price, I personally think it fits the game perfectly as you can get a LOT of hours and content out of this game but obviously it's a lot and I know not everyone is willing to waste that much on one game.

This is obviously a very biased review but I hope it helps(?) at least some people. This may be my perfect game but I know it won't be for others, and that's fine.

Hard? Yes. Cute? Yes. Stressful? A little. Fun? Absolutely.

The amount of stress and anxiety I feel from traversing areas with large gaps should qualify this is game as Psychological Horror.



On a serious note though, this game is very unfair. You will die by seemingly random chance. Predators might just block your path. The game is bullshit, it's unfair, and difficult, but that's how nature simply is. You adapt, survive, and learn. Give this game a shot, try it blind, try to stick with it, if you don't like it, if you hate dying over and over due to complete bullshit, put it down, it's probably not for you. But if it clicks, if you push through the bullshit, if you get good, if you learn your place in this ecosystem, this game will be one of your favorite games of all time. You will understand all the creature's behavior, you will learn how to deal with each creature, you will learn the map, your place in the ecosystem, and it might be one of your favorite games of all time.
